title: MBNA America Bank v. Christianson
description: In this action, the court examines the authority of an arbitrator to rule where the existence of an arbitration agreement is disputed.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				MBNA America
      Bank, N.A., Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Mark
      Christianson, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4349
Heard February 5, 2008 â€“ Filed March 4,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Edward E. Gilbert, of North Charleston, for Appellant.
				David C. Alford, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

SHORT, J.:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  MBNA America Bank, N.A. (MBNA) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s grant
  of Mark Christiansonâ€™s motion to vacate an arbitration award.Â  We affirm. Â 
FACTS
MBNA filed an arbitration claim against Mark
  Christianson in the National Arbitration Forum (the Forum) alleging he had
  entered into and defaulted on a credit card agreement.Â  Christianson responded
  several times asserting he never agreed to arbitrate.Â  Despite Christiansonâ€™s
  assertions, the Forum continued with the claim and determined the parties
  entered into an arbitration agreement.Â  The Forum awarded MBNA $13,579.57. 
 
MBNA filed an application for confirmation
  of the arbitration award in the circuit court, and Christianson filed a
  motion to vacate the award.Â  MBNA filed a Memorandum of Law in response and
  attached an unsigned, undated photocopy of one page of a pamphlet it alleges is
  the arbitration agreement.Â  MBNA provided no other evidence of the existence of
  an arbitration agreement between these parties.Â  Â 
The circuit court found MBNA failed to provide evidence
  Christianson agreed to arbitration and the Forum had no jurisdiction to hear
  the matter absent an arbitration agreement.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court granted
  Christiansonâ€™s motion to vacate the award.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Unless the parties otherwise provide, the question of
  the arbitrability of a claim is an issue for judicial determination. Â Zabinski
    v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 596, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001). Â Determinations
  of arbitrability are subject to de novo review, but if any evidence reasonably
  supports the circuit courtâ€™s factual findings, this court will not overrule
  those findings.Â  Stokes v. Metro. Life Ins. Co., 351 S.C. 606, 609-10,
  571 S.E.2d 711, 713 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  The South Carolina
  Uniform Arbitration Act and the Federal Arbitration Act (FAA)
The
  parties to this appeal cite to South Carolina and federal law governing
  arbitration.Â  Christianson argues MBNA â€œshould not be allowed to argue federal
  or state [law] at its whim.â€Â  Accordingly, we initially address this conflict
  of laws issue.Â  Unless the parties have otherwise contracted, the FAA applies
  in federal or state court to any arbitration agreement regarding a transaction
  that involves interstate commerce.Â  Munoz v. Green Tree Fin. Corp., 343
  S.C. 531, 538, 542 S.E.2d 360, 363 (2001).Â  â€œâ€˜[I]nvolving commerceâ€™ is the same
  as â€˜affecting commerce,â€™ which has been broadly interpreted to mean Congress
  intended to utilize its powers to regulate interstate commerce to its full
  extent.â€Â  Blanton v. Stathos, 351 S.C. 534, 540, 570 S.E.2d 565, 568
  (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œTo ascertain whether a transaction involves commerce within
  the meaning of the FAA, the court must examine the agreement, the complaint,
  and the surrounding facts.â€ Â Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 594, 553 S.E.2d at
  117.Â  Here, the underlying facts involve interstate commerce.  
Despite application of the
  FAA, however, South Carolina law applies to the initial determination of
  whether an arbitration agreement exists.Â  See Munoz, 343 S.C. at
  539, 542 S.E.2d at 364 (General contract principles of state law apply in a
  courtâ€™s evaluation of the enforceability of an arbitration clause.).Â  See
    also MBNA Am. Bank, N.A. v. Straub, 815 N.Y.S.2d 450, 452 (N.Y.
  City Civ. Ct. 2006) (â€œJudicial review of the petition should commence under the
  New York provisions governing confirmation of an arbitration award, but if the
  written contract and cardholder agreement are established by the petition the
  manner of service of the notice and award and treatment of supplementary
  information should be considered under the Federal Arbitration Act provisions .
  . . .â€).Â  Accordingly, we apply South Carolina law to the initial determination
  of arbitrability but look to federal law for additional guidance.Â Â Â  Â Â 
II. Motion to Vacate the
  Arbitration Award
MBNA argues the
  circuit court erred in granting Christiansonâ€™s motion to vacate the arbitration
  award because the motion was filed more than ninety days subsequent to the
  entry of the award.Â  We disagree.
An application to vacate,
  modify, or correct an arbitration award must be made within ninety days. Â S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 15-48-130(b) (2005) (â€œAn application [for vacating, modifying, or
  correcting the award] shall be made within ninety days after delivery of a copy
  of the award to the applicant.â€).Â  See also 9 U.S.C.A. Â§ 12 (1999) (â€œNotice
  of a motion to vacate, modify, or correct an award must be served upon the
  adverse party or his attorney within three months after the award is filed or
  delivered.â€).
However,
  in this case, Christianson disputed the existence of an agreement to arbitrate
  with MBNA prior to entry of the award.Â  â€œOn application, the court may stay an
  arbitration proceeding commenced or threatened on a showing that there is no
  agreement to arbitrate.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-20(b) (2005).Â  Similarly, the
  FAA provides:

	A party
  aggrieved by the alleged failure, neglect, or refusal of another to arbitrate
  under a written agreement for arbitration may petition any United States
  district court . . . for an order directing that such arbitration proceed. . . .Â 
  If the making of the arbitration agreement or the failure, neglect, or refusal
  to perform the same be in issue, the court shall proceed summarily to the trial
  thereof. Â If no jury trial be demanded by the party alleged to be in default .
  . ., the court shall hear and determine such issue. . . .Â  [If a jury trial is
  demanded and] the jury find[s] that no agreement in writing for arbitration was
  made . . . the proceeding shall be dismissed. 

9 U.S.C.A. Â§ 4 (1999).Â   
We
  find support from the Kansas Supreme Court in MBNA America Bank, N.A. v.
    Credit, 132 P.3d 898 (Kan. 2006).Â  Therein,
  the Court noted MBNA could not rely on the debtorâ€™s tardiness in
  challenging the award if the arbitrator never had jurisdiction to arbitrate and
  enter an award.Â  Credit, 132 P.3d at 900. Â The Kansas court stated:Â  â€œAn
  agreement to arbitrate bestows such jurisdiction. Â When the existence of the
  agreement is challenged, the issue must be settled by a court before the
  arbitrator may proceed.â€Â  Id. (citing 9 U.S.C. Â§ 4 (2000); Kan. Stat.
  Ann. Â§ 5-402).[1]Â 
  The court found that â€œ[u]nder both federal and state law, [the debtorâ€™s]
  objection to the arbitrator meant the responsibility fell
  to MBNA to litigate the issue of the agreementâ€™s existence. Â Neither MBNA, as
  the party asserting existence of an arbitration agreement, nor the arbitrator
  was simply free to go forward with the arbitration as though [the debtor] had
  not challenged the existence of an agreement to do so.â€ Â Id. at 900-01
  (citing 9 U.S.C. Â§ 4; Kan. Stat. Ann. Â§ 5-402). Â The Kansas court looked â€œto
  MBNA as the appellant to demonstrate that the objection was somehow ineffective
  to trigger its responsibility to seek court intervention to compel arbitration.â€Â  Id. at 900.Â  
 

	If
  there is a challenge to the arbitration, it is for the courts, not the
  arbitrator, to decide whether the agreement to arbitrate exists and whether the
  issue in dispute falls within the agreement to arbitrate. . . . Under either the Federal
  Act or the Kansas Act, the arbitratorâ€™s power to resolve the dispute must find
  its source in the agreement between the parties. The arbitrator has no
  independent source of jurisdiction apart from consent of the parties . . . . Â 

Id. at 901 (quoting Dreyer, Arbitration Under the
  Kansas Arbitration Act: The Role of the Courts, 59 J. Kan. B. Assâ€™n. 33, 35
  (May 1990)) (omissions by court).Â  Accordingly, once Christianson disputed the
  existence of an arbitration agreement, the Forum did not have jurisdiction to enter
  an arbitration award until MBNA petitioned the courts to compel arbitration. 
 
Furthermore,
  MBNA did not demonstrate to the circuit court that Christianson had agreed to
  arbitrate.Â  Before a circuit court confirms an arbitration award subject to the
  Federal Arbitration Act, there must be evidence of an arbitration agreement.Â  9
  U.S.C.A. Â§ 13 (1999).Â  The Kansas Supreme Court, addressing this issue in Credit,
  found:

	MBNA
  failed to attach a copy of the arbitration agreement to its motion to confirm
  the award. Â This violated the Federal Arbitration Act for which MBNA intermittently
  expresses respect. . . . This alone would have justified
  the district court in its decision to deny MBNAâ€™s motion to confirm the award.Â  
	

132 P.3d at 901 (citing 9
  U.S.C. Â§ 13 (2000)).Â Â  According to 9 U.S.C.A. Â§ 13:

	The
  party moving for an order confirming, modifying, or correcting an award shall,
  at the time such order is filed with the clerk for the entry of judgment
  thereon, also file the following papers with the clerk:
	(a) The agreement; the selection or
  appointment, if any, of an additional arbitrator or umpire; and each written
  extension of the time, if any, within which to make the award.

9 U.S.C.A. Â§ 13 (1999).Â  MBNA denies this code section requires it to file the
  agreement with its application for confirmation of the award.Â  MBNA argues the
  statute merely requires the agreement to be filed before the clerk performs the
  ministerial act of entering the judgment.Â  We again look to foreign
  jurisdiction for guidance in rejecting this argument.Â  See, e.g., MBNA
    Am. Bank, N.A. v. Boata, 893 A.2d 479 (Conn. Ct. App. 2006); MBNA Am.
      Bank, N.A. v. Berlin, 2005 WL 3193850 (Ohio Ct. App. 2005). Â As stated by
  the Kansas Supreme Court, â€œGiven MBNAâ€™s casual approach to this litigation, we
  are not surprised that [a national trend in which consumers are questioning
  MBNA and whether arbitration agreements exist] may be growing.â€Â  Credit,
  132 P.3d at 902.
Accordingly,
  we find no error by the circuit court in granting Christiansonâ€™s motion to
  vacate the arbitration award.
III.Â  Notice
MBNA next contends
  the circuit court improperly relied on issues Christianson raised for the first
  time at the hearing.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for appellate review. 
 
Christianson
  proceeded pro se in filing his motion to vacate the arbitration
  award.Â  Before the hearing on the motion to vacate and MBNAâ€™s motion to confirm
  the award, Christianson obtained counsel, who filed a memorandum.Â  MBNAâ€™s
  counsel could not attend the hearing but sent another attorney in his stead.Â  At
  the hearing, this attorney did not raise the issue that MBNA lacked notice of
  Christiansonâ€™s memorandum, nor did the attorney ask for a continuance.Â  Accordingly,
  this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See In re Michael H., 360 S.C.
  540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may not be
  raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In order to preserve an issue for appeal,
  it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€); Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 510-11, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004) (â€œIt is well settled that, but for a very few exceptional
  circumstances, an appellate court cannot address an issue unless it was raised
  to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€).
CONCLUSION
For the
  foregoing reasons, the order on appeal is
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON
  and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1] The Kansas statutes, relied upon by the Kansas
  Supreme Court, are identical to our corresponding statutes.Â  See Kan.
  Stat. Ann. Â§ 5-402 & S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-20 (proceedings to compel or
  stay arbitration); Kan. Stat. Ann. Â§ 5-411 & S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-120
  (confirmation of an award); Kan. Stat. Ann. Â§ 5-412 & S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  15-48-130 (vacating an award).

title: Hooper v. Ebenezer Senior Services
description: In this civil appeal, the Appellant contends the circuit court erred: (1) in not equitably tolling the statute of limitation; (2) in failing to apply the amended version of Rule 3(a), SCRCP; (3) in failing to conclude that the assertion of the statute of limitation as a defense would be unjust; and (4) in failing to rule, pursuant to Rule 86, SCRCP, application of the amended version of Rule 3(a), SCRCP, would work an injustice so that the former procedure should apply, and that service under that procedure was completed within a reasonable time after delivery to the Sheriff.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Floree
      Hooper, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Albert L. Clinton,
      Deceased, Appellant,
				v.
				Ebenezer
      Senior Services and Rehabilitation Center, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
Â S. Jackson Kimball, Special Circuit Court
  Judge
and Master-in-Equity
Opinion No. 4350
Heard March 4, 2008 â€“ Filed March 10, 2008

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				John S. Nichols, of Columbia and Robert V. Phillips, of Rock Hill,
  for Appellant.
				R. Gerald Chambers and R. Hawthorne Barrett, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON, J.: In
  this action for wrongful death and negligence under the survival statute,
  Floree Hooper appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment toEbenezer Senior Services and Rehabilitation Center (Ebenezer) based on the statute of limitations.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
In February 2003, Albert Clinton became a resident of
  Ebenezer, a nursing home facility.Â  Two months later, Clinton was taken to a
  hospital and remained there until his death on May 15, 2003.Â  Hooper, as
  Personal Representative of Clintonâ€™s Estate, filed an action against Ebenezer on
  February 6, 2006, for negligence under the survival statute and wrongful death.
When Hooperâ€™s attorney (Counsel) received the filed
  pleadings from the clerk of court, he called Ebenezerâ€™s telephone number.Â  A
  receptionist answered, â€œAgape Rehabilitation.â€Â  Counsel inquired about Ebenezer
  Senior Services and was told the business had been sold and was now Agape
  Rehabilitation (Agape).Â  A telephone search revealed Agape had the same street
  address as Ebenezer.Â  Counsel drove to the location, and signage identified the
  facility as â€œAgape Rehabilitation of Rock Hill.â€Â   
Counsel searched the South Carolina Secretary of
  Stateâ€™s website and found a current listing for Ebenezer as a domestic entity
  in good standing listing a registered agent: â€œJack G. Hendrix, Jr., 1415 Richland Street, Columbia, SC.â€Â  Counsel forwarded the pleadings to the Richland County
  Sheriffâ€™s office for service upon Hendrix, but service was not accomplished
  because he â€œmoved to an unknown address on Assembly St.â€Â   
Counsel hired an investigator to locate Hendrix.Â  The
  investigator discovered an address in Pelion, and Counsel again sent the
  pleadings to the Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department for service.Â  The
  Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department returned the pleadings because the address
  was in Lexington County.Â  Counsel transmitted the pleadings to the Lexington
  County Sheriffâ€™s Department for service, and the Sheriffâ€™s office responded
  with an affidavit stating the department was unable to serve the pleadings
  because â€œper neighbor [Hendrix] left his wife a year ago and unknown where he
  lived now.â€Â   
Having exhausted his options of service by sheriff,
  Counsel hired an investigator to take the papers to Agape.Â  The investigator
  served the pleadings upon Janet Inkelaar, the administrator of Agape
  Rehabilitation, on June 15, 2006, at the facility.Â  Inkelaar indicated she was authorized
  to accept service on Ebenezerâ€™s behalf.Â  By Hooperâ€™s calculation, service was
  completed 129 days after the filing of the summons and complaint.Â   
Ebenezer moved the circuit court to dismiss the
  action, asserting it was not commenced in a timely fashion pursuant to Rule 3,
  SCRCP, and section 15-3-530 of the South Carolina Code, the three year statute
  of limitations.Â  Hooper argued: (1) the statute of limitations should be
  equitably tolled; (2) the 120-day period under Rule 3(a), SCRCP, should not begin
  to run until the end of the limitations period; (3) Ebenezer should be estopped
  from asserting the statute of limitations due to its own unlawful actions; and
  (4) under Rule 86, SCRCP, the former version of Rule 3, SCRCP, should apply to
  permit service within a reasonable time after filing following delivery to the
  sheriff.Â   
The Master in Equity, sitting as a Special Circuit Judge,
  ruled the action was not timely commenced because it was not served within 120
  days of filing.Â  Hooper sought reconsideration of the courtâ€™s order, and a
  hearing was scheduled.Â  Hooper then served notice of appeal from the dismissal,
  and the hearing on reconsideration was not held.
ISSUES

	
		
			1.  
			Did the 120 day period for 
			service under Rule 3(a), SCRCP, commence when the action was filed or when the limitations period
  expired?
 
		
		
			2. 
			Did the circuit court properly 
			refuse to equitably toll the statute of limitations?
 
		
		
			3.
			Is it unjust and inequitable to 
			permit Ebenezer to assert the statute of limitations as a defense?
 
		
		
			4. 
			Should the circuit court have 
			applied the former Rule 3(a), pursuant to Rule 86, SCRCP, and determined that service was timely when
  completed within a reasonable time after delivery to the sheriff?
		
	

STANDARD OF REVIEW

	Summary judgment is defined by Rule 12(c), SCRCP:
	
		If, on a motion for judgment on the pleadings, matters
  outside the pleadings are presented to and not excluded by the Court, the
  motion shall be treated as one for summary judgment and disposed of as provided
  in Rule 56, and all parties shall be given reasonable opportunity to present
  all material made pertinent to such a motion by Rule 56.
	

Id.
When
  reviewing a grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same
  standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary
  judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and
  the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. Â Pye v. Estate
    of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, 633 S.E.2d 505 (2006); Houck v.
      State Farm Fire & Cas. Ins. Co., 366 S.C. 7, 11, 620 S.E.2d 326,
  329 (2005); Bradley v. Doe, 374 S.C. 622, 649
  S.E.2d 153 (Ct. App. 2007); Bennett v. Investors Title Ins. Co. 370 S.C. 578, 635 S.E.2d 649 (Ct. App. 2006); see Rule 56(c), SCRCP (â€œThe judgment sought
  shall be rendered forthwith if the pleadings, depositions, answers to
  interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any,
  show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving
  party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€). Â In determining whether
  any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences
  therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party. Â Helms
    Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 611 S.E.2d 485
  (2005); Medical Univ. of S.C. v. Arnaud, 360 S.C. 615, 602 S.E.2d
  747 (2004); Hackworth v. Greenville County, 371 S.C. 99, 102, 637 S.E.2d
  320, 322 (Ct. App. 2006); Rife v. Hitachi Constr. Mach. Co., Ltd., 363 S.C. 209, 609 S.E.2d 565 (Ct. App. 2005).
The
  purpose of summary judgment is to expedite the disposition of cases which do
  not require the services of a fact finder.Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C.
  58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 438 (2003) (quoting George v. Fabri, 345 S.C.
  440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001)); Moore v. Weinberg, 373 S.C. 209,
  217, 644 S.E.2d 740, 744 (Ct. App. 2007); Mulherin-Howell v. Cobb, 362
  S.C. 588, 596-97, 608 S.E.2d 587, 592 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Because it is a drastic
  remedy, summary judgment should be cautiously invoked to ensure that a litigant
  is not improperly deprived of a trial on disputed factual issues.Â  Helena
    Chem. Co. v. Allianz Underwriters Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 631, 644, 594 S.E.2d
  455, 462 (2004); B & B Liquors, Inc. v. Oâ€™Neil, 361 S.C. 267, 270,
  603 S.E.2d 629, 631 (Ct. App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â 
  Timely Service under Rule 3(a)
Hooper
  maintains the trial court erred in granting Ebenezer summary judgment, arguing
  under Rule 3(a), SCRCP, the 120 days for service did not commence until the
  date the limitations period expired, as opposed to the filing date.Â  We
  disagree.

	Rule
  3(a), SCRCP, provides:
	
		A civil action is commenced when the summons and
  complaint are filed with the clerk of court if:
		(1) the summons and complaint are served within the
  statute of limitations in any manner prescribed by law; or
		(2) if not served within the statute of limitations,
  actual service must be accomplished not later than one hundred twenty days
  after filing.
	

Id.

	The
  rule is consistent with section 15-3-20 of the South Carolina Code:
	
		(A)
  Civil actions may only be commenced within the periods prescribed in this title
  after the cause of action has accrued, except when, in special cases, a
  different limitation is prescribed by statute.
		(B) A
  civil action is commenced when the summons and complaint are filed with the
  clerk of court if actual service is accomplished within one hundred twenty days
  after filing.
	

Id.
This
  Court explained the importance of statutes of limitation in Blyth v. Marcus,
  322 S.C. 150, 470 S.E.2d 389 (Ct. App. 1996):

	A
  statute of limitations reduces the interval between the accrual and
  commencement of a right of action to a fixed period, thereby putting to rest
  claims after the passage of time.Â  This procedural device operates as a defense
  to limit the remedy available from an existing cause of action.Â  Unless an action
  is commenced before expiration of the limitations period, the plaintiff's claim
  is normally barred.

Id. at 152, 470 S.E.2d at 390
  (citations omitted).
The purpose
  of statutes of limitation is to ensure litigation is â€œbrought within a
  reasonable time in order that evidence be reasonably available and there be
  some end to litigation.â€Â  City of North Myrtle Beach v. Lewis-Davis, 360
  S.C. 225, 231, 599 S.E.2d 462, 464 (Ct. App. 2004) (quoting Webb v.
    Greenwood County, 299 S.C. 267, 276, 92 S.E.2d 688, 691 (1956)).Â  â€œ[S]tatutes are designed to promote
      justice by forcing parties to pursue a case in a timely manner.Â  Parties should
      act before memories dim, evidence grows stale or becomes nonexistent, or other
      people act in reliance on what they believe is a settled state of public affairs.â€Â  State ex
        rel. Condon v. City of Columbia, 339 S.C. 8, 19, 528 S.E.2d 408, 413-14
  (2000).

	Statutes
  of limitation . . . protect people from being forced to defend themselves
  against stale claims.Â  The statutes recognize that with the passage of time,
  evidence becomes more difficult to obtain and is less reliable.Â  Physical
  evidence is lost or destroyed, witnesses become impossible to locate, and
  memories fade.Â  With passing time, a defendant faces an increasingly difficult
  task in formulating and mounting an effective defense.Â  Additionally, statutes
  of limitation encourage plaintiffs to initiate actions promptly while evidence
  is fresh and a court will be able to judge more accurately.

Moriarty v. Garden
  Sanctuary Church of God, 334 S.C. 150, 163-64, 511 S.E.2d 699, 706 (Ct. App.
  1999), affâ€™d, 341 S.C. 320, 534 S.E.2d 672 (2000).

	Statutes
  of limitations are not simply technicalities.Â  On the contrary, they have long
  been respected as fundamental to a well-ordered judicial system.Â  Statutes of
  limitations embody important public policy considerations in that they
  stimulate activity, punish
  negligence, and promote repose by giving security and stability to human
  affairs.Â  One purpose of a statute of limitations is to relieve the courts of
  the burden of trying stale claims when a plaintiff has slept on his rights.Â 
  Another purpose of a statute of limitations is to protect potential defendants
  from protracted fear of litigation. 

Moates v. Bobb, 322 S.C. 172,
  176, 470 S.E.2d 402, 404 (Ct. App. 1996) (internal citations and quotations
  omitted).

	The
  cornerstone policy consideration underlying statutes of limitations is the
  laudable goal of law to promote and achieve finality in litigation.Â 
  Significantly, [s]tatutes of limitations provide potential defendants with 
	certainty that after a set period of time, they will not be hailed [sic]
  into court to defend time-barred claims.Â  Moreover, limitations periods
  discourage plaintiffs from sitting on their rights.Â  Statutes of limitations
  are, indeed, fundamental to our judicial system.

Carolina Marine Handling,
  Inc. v. Lasch, 363 S.C. 169, 175-76,
  609 S.E.2d 548, 552 (Ct. App. 2005) (alterations in original) (internal
  citations and quotations omitted).
The
  statute of limitations period for wrongful death and negligence actions is
  three years.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(5), (6) (2005) (â€œWithin three years: (5) an action for assault, battery, or any injury to the
  person or rights of another, not arising on contract and not enumerated by law,
  and those provided for in Section 15-3-545; (6) an action under Sections
  15-51-10 to 15-51-60 for death by wrongful act, the period to begin to run upon
  the death of the person on account of whose death the action is broughtâ€); S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-20(A) (2005) (â€œCivil actions may only be commenced within the
  periods prescribed in this title after the cause of action has accrued, except
  when, in special cases, a different limitation is prescribed by statute.â€).Â  The statute of limitations on a negligence claim accrues at the
  time of the negligence or when facts and circumstances would put a person of
  common knowledge on notice that he might have a claim against another party.Â  
Kreutner v.
    David, 320 S.C. 283, 285, 465 S.E.2d 88,
  90 (1995).Â 
  This standard is known as the discovery rule.Â  Id.Â  â€œThe statute is not
  delayed until the injured party seeks advice of counsel or develops a
  full-blown theory of recovery; instead, reasonable diligence requires a
  plaintiff to â€˜act with some promptness.â€™â€Â  Maher v. Tietex Corp., 331
  S.C. 371, 377, 500 S.E.2d 204, 207 (Ct.
  App. 1998) (citations omitted).Â   
â€œUnder
  Rule 3(a), SCRCP, a civil action is commenced by the filing and service of a
  summons and complaint.â€Â  Louden v. Moragne, 327 S.C. 465, 468, 486
  S.E.2d 525, 526 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œService of the summons brings the defendant
  within the courtâ€™s jurisdiction and gives the court the power to render a
  personal judgment against the person served.â€Â  Id. (citing James F.

  brought under the Tort Claims Act, the defendant claimed the statute of
  limitations as a bar, and the plaintiff argued the defendant was equitably
  estopped from asserting the statute.Â  The plaintiff based her equitable
  estoppel argument on the fact the defendant's employees assisted her in
  completing certain claim forms.Â  She argued that this assistance â€œcaused her to
  believe she had done all that she needed to do.â€Â  Vines, 314 S.C. at
  308, 443 S.E.2d at 911.Â  The trial court rejected this argument and granted the
  defendant's motion for summary judgment based on the statute of limitations.Â  On
  appeal, this Court affirmed, finding there was no showing that the plaintiff
  had delayed filing suit in reliance on the defendant hospitalâ€™s conduct.Â  Id.

Black v. Lexington School
  Dist. No. 2, 327 S.C. 55, 61, 488
  S.E.2d 327, 330 (1997).
In
  the case at bar, Hooper was not delayed from filing her action, but she
  advances Ebenezerâ€™s failure to maintain a registered agentâ€™s current address hindered
  service.Â  No evidence suggests Ebenezerâ€™s omission in updating the Secretary of
  State was intended to defraud or conceal facts from Hooper.Â  Ebenezer had no
  knowledge Hooper would rely on the information to attempt service.Â  When
  questioned by Hooperâ€™s investigator, Inkelaar freely admitted she was
  authorized to accept service for Ebenezer.
Ebenezer
  did not engage in conduct warranting estoppel to preclude the assertion of the
  statute of limitations as a defense.Â  The trial court correctly rejected
  Hooperâ€™s estoppel argument.
IV.Â  Rule 86 to Resurrect
  Former Procedure
Hooper posits because of Rule 86, SCRCP, the trial
  court erred in failing to apply the previous version of Rule 3, SCRCP, instead
  of the current rule.Â  We disagree.

	Rule 86(a) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil
  Procedure states:
	
		These rules shall take effect
  on July 1, 1985.Â  They govern all proceedings in civil actions brought after
  they take effect and also all further proceedings in actions then pending, except
  to the extent that in the opinion of the court their application in a
  particular action pending when the rules take effect would not be feasible or
  would work injustice, in which event the former procedure applies.
	

Id.
The former â€œRule
  3(b), SCRCP, tolls the statute of limitations once a plaintiff files his
  summons and complaint and delivers the pleadings to the sheriff of the county
  where the defendant was known to last reside for service upon the defendant,
  provided actual service occurs within a reasonable time thereafter.â€Â  Montgomery
    v. Mullins, 325 S.C. at 504, 480 S.E.2d at 469 (citing Hughes v. Water
      World Water Slide, Inc., 314 S.C. 211, 442 S.E.2d 584 (1994)).
In
  2002, the legislature amended S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-20 to add: â€œ(B) A civil action is commenced when the summons and complaint are filed with the clerk of
  court if actual service is accomplished within one hundred twenty days after
  filing.â€Â  Id.Â  Rule 3, SCRCP, was revised to conform it to the amended
  statute.Â  The revised rule took effect April 27, 2004.
Rule
  86, SCRCP, only applies to cases pending when the new rule takes effect.Â  In
  the case sub judice, the rule changed almost two years before Hooper
  filed the complaint on February
  8, 2006.Â  This case was not
  pending when the rules changed, and Rule 86 does not apply.Â  The trial court
  did not err in failing to apply the former version of Rule 3 in lieu of the
  current version.
CONCLUSION
We
  hold Hooper did not commence her action within the statute of limitations due
  to the fact she served Ebenezer after the running of the statute and outside
  120 days of filing.Â  We rule the doctrine of equitable tolling is inapposite because
  nothing prevented Hooper from timely filing her suit, and there were no extraordinary circumstances or encumbrances to hinder
  timely service by a diligent plaintiff.Â  We conclude Ebenezerâ€™s failure to
  update its registered agentâ€™s information with the Secretary of State did not
  rise to false representation or concealment to warrant estoppel.Â  Current Rule
  3, SCRCP, is controlling rather than a former version.
Accordingly, the
  order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.Â  
SHORT
  and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				In the Matter
      of the Care and Treatment of Anthony Valentine, Respondent,
				v.
				The State of South Carolina, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 4351
Heard September 11, 2007 â€“ Filed March 10,
  2008
REVERSED and REMANDED 



	
		
			
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, Assistant
  Attorney General Brandy A. Duncan, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare and 
				Appellate Defender LaNelle C. DuRant, both of Columbia, for 
				Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  The
  State appeals the circuit courtâ€™s determination that there was no probable
  cause to believe Anthony Valentine was a sexually violent predator.Â  We reverse
  and remand.
FACTS
In October of 2003, Anthony Valentine sexually
  assaulted his daughterâ€™s friend by grabbing and squeezing her breasts and
  buttocks.Â  When the victim, who was fourteen years old, notified police, Valentineâ€™s
  step-daughter also accused him of fondling her breasts and vaginal area on multiple
  occasions when she was between the ages of twelve and fourteen.[1]Â 
  On February 26, 2004, Valentine pled guilty to one count of lewd act on a minor
  under the age of sixteen in response to the allegations made by his daughterâ€™s
  friend.Â  On the same day, Valentine also pled guilty to one count of assault
  and battery of a high and aggravated nature (â€œABHANâ€) in response to the
  allegations made by his step-daughter.Â  Valentine was sentenced to fifteen
  yearsâ€™ incarceration, suspended upon the service of five yearsâ€™ confinement and
  five yearsâ€™ probation for the lewd act conviction, and a concurrent sentence of
  ten years suspended to five yearsâ€™ confinement and five yearsâ€™ probation for
  the ABHAN conviction.Â   
While incarcerated,
  Valentine was convicted of possession of marijuana and cocaine with intent to
  distribute.Â  Prior to Valentineâ€™s release from the South Carolina Department of
  Corrections, the Multi-Disciplinary Team reviewed his case and determined there
  was probable cause to believe Valentine was a sexually violent predator as
  defined by the Sexually Violent Predator Act (â€œActâ€).[2]Â 
  The Prosecutorâ€™s Review Committee ratified the determination made by the
  Multi-Disciplinary Team, and accordingly, the State filed a petition seeking
  Valentineâ€™s civil commitment to the South Carolina Department of Mental Health
  for long term control, care, and treatment as a sexually violent predator.Â  
 
On
  February 2, 2006, the Honorable Deadra L. Jefferson found the Stateâ€™s petition
  set forth sufficient facts to establish probable cause to believe Valentine met
  the statutory criteria for confinement.Â  Thereafter, a probable cause hearing
  was held on March 10, 2006, before the Honorable R. Markley Dennis.Â  The only
  issue before the court was whether the State could demonstrate probable cause
  in showing that Valentine was a sexually violent predator.Â  In order to make
  such a showing, the State argued that Valentine suffered from the mental abnormality
  of pedophilia.Â  In support of this argument, the State submitted evidence to
  the court concerning several risk factors suggesting Valentineâ€™s propensity to
  re-offend in future acts of sexual violence.Â  The risk factors included:Â  (1)Â 
  multiple victims, (2) the victims were between the ages of thirteen to fifteen,
  (3) prior non-sexual convictions,[3] (4) Valentineâ€™s â€œfour sentencing dates which are criminal in nature,â€ (5) a
  victim he was not related to, (6) his length of sexual offending was between
  one and six years, (7) he victimized two or more age groups, (8) a pattern of
  substantial substance abuse, and (9) one major discipline report while
  incarcerated.Â   
Judge
  Dennis found the State produced insufficient evidence to demonstrate Valentine was
  a sexually violent predator as defined by the Act.Â  In so finding, he relied on
  the Stateâ€™s reduction of one lewd act charge to an ABHAN charge, the
  availability of treatment during Valentineâ€™s probationary sentence, the absence
  of a psychological exam, and the fairly lenient sentence Valentine received. Â This
  appeal followed.Â   

STANDARD OF REVIEW

â€œ[O]n review, the
  appellate court will not disturb the hearing courtâ€™s finding on probable cause
  unless found to be without evidence that reasonably supports the hearing courtâ€™s
  finding.â€Â  In re Care & Treatment of Beaver, 372 S.C. 272, 278, 642
  S.E.2d 578, 582 (2007).Â Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
The State asserts
  the hearing judge based his conclusion on impermissible speculation.Â  We
  agree.Â   
I.  SEXUALLY VIOLENT
  PREDATOR ACT
Sections
  44-48-10 to 44-48-170 of the South Carolina Code of Laws (Supp. 2006), provide
  for the involuntary civil commitment of sexually violent predators who are
  â€œmentally abnormal and extremely dangerous.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-20 (Supp.
  2006).Â  The Act is not intended to be punitive in nature, nor is it intended to
  stigmatize the mentally ill community.Â  Id.Â  â€œ[T]he purpose of the
  requirements in the SVP Act is to ensure that these involuntary commitment procedures
  are only used to control a limited subclass of dangerous persons and not to
  broadly subject any dangerous person to what may be indefinite terms.â€ In re
    Care and Treatment of Harvey, 355 S.C. 53, 584 S.E.2d 893 (2003).Â  
 
The Act
  defines a â€œsexually violent predatorâ€ as a person who: â€œ(a) has been convicted
  of a sexually violent offense; and (b) suffers from a mental abnormality or
  personality disorder that makes the person likely to engage in acts of sexual
  violence if not confined in a secure facility for long-term control, care, and
  treatment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30 (1) (Supp. 2006).Â  When a person has
  been imprisoned for one or more of the sexually violent offenses identified in
  section 44-48-30, the Act requires the agency with jurisdiction over that
  person to notify the Attorney General and a multidisciplinary team designed to
  evaluate the particular offender prior to his release.Â  See S.C. Code Â§
  44-48-40(A) (Supp. 2006).Â   
The
  multidisciplinary team reviews relevant records to determine if probable cause
  exists that the offender satisfies the definition of a sexually violent
  predator under the Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-50 (Supp. 2006).Â  These records
  may include, but are not limited to, the personâ€™s criminal offense record, any
  relevant medical and psychological records, treatment records, victimâ€™s impact
  statement, and any disciplinary or other records formulated during confinement
  or supervision.Â  Id.Â  If the multidisciplinary team determines probable
  cause exists that the person meets the statutory definition, the team forwards
  its assessment and all relevant records to a prosecutorâ€™s review committee.Â  Id.
The
  prosecutorâ€™s review committee then undertakes its assessment of whether
  probable cause exists to believe the individual is a sexually violent
  predator.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-60 (Supp. 2006).Â  In addition to the records
  and reports from the multidisciplinary team, the committee must consider any
  information provided by the circuit solicitor who originally prosecuted the
  person.Â  Id.Â   
If the prosecutorâ€™s
  review committee finds probable cause, the Attorney General files a petition
  with the court in the jurisdiction where the person committed the offense.Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-70 (Supp. 2006).Â  A probable cause hearing is then held
  to determine whether sufficient evidence exists that would lead a reasonable
  person to believe the person named in the Attorney Generalâ€™s petition is a
  sexually violent predator.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80 (Supp. 2006).Â  At the
  hearing, the law instructs the court to:Â  (1) verify the detaineeâ€™s identity;
  (2) receive evidence and hear arguments from the detainee and the Attorney
  General; and (3) determine whether probable cause exists to believe the
  detainee is a sexually violent predator.Â  Id.Â  The detainee is
  guaranteed: (1) to be represented by counsel; (2) to present evidence on his
  own behalf; (3) to cross-examine witnesses who testify against him; and (4) to
  view and copy all petitions and reports in the court file.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  44-48-80(B) (Supp. 2006).Â   
It is important to
  emphasize that a finding of probable cause at the probable cause hearing does
  not finally decide the question of whether the detainee is a sexually violent
  predator.Â  Beaver, 372 S.C. at 275, 642 S.E.2d at 580 n.2 (citing S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§Â§ 44-48-80 through 90 (Supp. 2006)).Â  On finding probable cause, the
  detainee is transferred to an appropriate secure facility for an evaluation as
  to whether he, in fact, suffers from a mental abnormality or personality
  disorder that meets the statutory criteria for commitment under the Act.Â  Id.Â  After the evaluation, a trial is held to determine whether the person is a
  sexually violent predator.Â  Id.Â  This trial is before a judge, unless
  the detainee or Attorney General requests a jury trial.Â  Id.Â  The State
  must prove the person is a sexually violent predator beyond a reasonable
  doubt.Â  Harvey, 355 S.C. at 60, 584 S.E.2d at 896; see also S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-100 (Supp. 2006).
II.  PROBABLE CAUSE
  STANDARD
Â â€œProbable
  cause is a flexible, common-sense standard.Â  The very term itself does not
  import absolute certainty.Â  Probable cause may be found somewhere between
  suspicion and sufficient evidence to convict.â€Â  Care and Treatment of Brown
    v. State, 372, S.C. 611, 619-20, 643 S.E.2d 118, 122 (Ct. App. 2007)
  (internal quotations and citations omitted).
Sufficient
  probable cause exists to find that a sex offender meets the definition of a
  sexually violent predator, as defined by the Act, if the offender has been
  convicted of a sexually violent offense, i.e., lewd act upon a minor.Â  Beaver,
  372 S.C. at 277, 642 S.E.2d at 581.Â  For the purposes of the Act, â€œ[c]onvicted
  of a sexually violent offenseâ€ means a person has:  

	(a) pled guilty to, pled nolo contendere to, or been
  convicted of a sexually violent offense;
	(b) been adjudicated delinquent as a result of the
  commission of a sexually violent offense;
	(c) been charged but determined to be incompetent to
  stand trial Â  for a sexually violent offense;
	(d) been found not guilty by reason of insanity of a
  sexually violent offense; or
	(e)
  been found guilty but mentally ill of a sexually violent offense.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30
  (Supp. 2006).Â   
Probable
  cause to believe someone to be a sexually violent predator requires that the
  evidence presented would lead a reasonable person to believe and
  conscientiously entertain suspicion that the person meets the definition of a
  sexually violent predator.Â  Brown, 372, S.C. at 620, 643 S.E.2d at 122. Â Probable
  cause to believe someone to be a sexually violent predator does not demand a
  showing that such a belief be correct or more likely true than false.Â  Id. at 620, 643 S.E.2d at 123.
III.  THE CIRCUIT
  COURTâ€™S ANALYSIS
As noted earlier, a
  two-pronged test exists under the Act to guide the court in making that
  determination.Â  A person is a sexually violent predator if Â he (1) â€œhas been
  convicted of a sexually violent offenseâ€; and (2) â€œsuffers from a mental
  abnormality or personality disorder that makes the person likely to engage in
  acts of sexual violence if not confined in a secure facility for long-term
  control, care, and treatment.â€Â  S.C. Code Â§ 44-48-30(1) (Supp. 2006).Â  Pursuant
  to the Act, committing a lewd act upon a child under the age of sixteen is a
  sexually violent offense.Â  S.C. Code Â§ 44-48-30(2)(k) (Supp. 2006).Â   
Here, the first
  prong of the statutory requirement defining a â€œsexually violent predatorâ€ was
  satisfied when Valentine pled guilty to â€œlewd act upon a minor under the age of
  sixteen,â€ an offense enumerated under section 48-44-30 as a â€œsexually violent
  offense.â€Â  Therefore, the hearing judgeâ€™s determination regarding
  probable cause hinged upon the second prong:Â  whether Valentine suffers from a
  mental abnormality or personality disorder that makes him likely to engage in
  acts of sexual violence if not confined in a secure facility for long-term
  control, care, and treatment.Â  As referenced above, our supreme court recently
  addressed this second prong in Beaver, a case we find to be
  substantially similar to the one at hand. [4]Â   
In Beaver,
  the supreme court held the circuit court judge erred as a matter of law when he
  found Beaver was not a sexually violent predator based on the following
  factors:Â  the non-violent nature of Beaverâ€™s fondling convictions, the fact
  that a longer sentence could have been imposed upon Beaver, and the Stateâ€™s
  lack of mental health evidence at the probable cause hearing.Â  Beaver, 372
  S.C. at 276-78 n.3, 642 S.E.2d at 580-82.Â  In regard to the hearing judgeâ€™s
  characterization of fondling as a non-violent crime, the Beaver court
  stated that although the charge of committing a lewd act upon a minor is
  considered non-violent for criminal purposes, â€œthe Legislature has deemed it
  appropriate to consider that charge violent for the purposes of the SVP Act.â€Â  Id. at 277, 642 S.E.2d at 581.Â  In addition, the Beaver court found the
  hearing judge committed legal error when he commented on the duration of Beaverâ€™s
  sentence.Â  Id. at 276 n.3, 642 S.E.2d at 581.Â  Furthermore, the supreme
  court acknowledged the State should not be penalized for its failure to produce
  any mental health information at the probable cause hearing because probable
  cause must be found by the hearing judge before such evidence can be obtained.Â  Id. at 278, 642 S.E.2d at 582.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
As in Beaver,
  we find the hearing judge in this case erred by relying on a myriad of factors
  wholly outside the scope of the sexually violent predator determination as
  outlined by the Act.Â  First, the hearing judge relied on the Stateâ€™s offer of a
  plea agreement to Valentine, reducing one charge of lewd act on a minor to
  ABHAN.Â  The hearing judge remarked, â€œ. . . if the State entertained and
  accepted a plea to ABHAN, that tells me something about the strength of that
  case and [its] belief in the allegations of the victim.Â  So you can offer it,
  but it doesnâ€™t really help from my viewpoint.â€[5]Â 
  The State may offer or accept a plea agreement from a person charged with a
  crime for a variety of reasons ranging from a lack of evidence, to the
  realization that testifying at trial will be a traumatic experience for the
  victim.Â  We find no inherent connection between the reasons the State had for entering
  into a plea agreement and the evaluation of whether Valentine suffers from a
  mental abnormality or personality disorder that makes him likely to engage in
  acts of sexual violence if not confined in a secure facility for long-term
  control, care, and treatment.Â   
Second, the hearing
  judge relied on the five years of probation Valentine faced following his
  release from jail as a factor in denying the Stateâ€™s motion, stating â€œI would
  agree with you that he needs [treatment], if he didnâ€™t have probation.â€Â  It is
  clear the hearing judge thought probation provided adequate safeguards against
  Valentineâ€™s propensity to re-offend on the basis of his mental abnormality of pedophilia.Â 
  By creating the Act, our legislature has made it clear that the safeguards
  probation offers to protect society are inadequate for sexually violent
  predators.Â  Therefore, if indeed the hearing judge found that Valentine needed
  treatment, he should have issued an order finding probable cause that Valentine
  was a sexually violent predator.Â  See Brown, 372 S.C. at 622, 643
  S.E.2d at 124 (stating the hearing judge erred by finding no probable cause
  even after acknowledging Brown needed treatment based on his prior convictions
  for voyeurism).Â  Rather than focusing on the safeguards offered by probation, the
  courtâ€™s analysis should have been directed to whether Valentine suffers from a
  mental abnormality or personality disorder which makes him likely to engage in
  acts of sexual violence if not confined.Â   
The
  hearing judge relied on the absence of a psychological exam as evidence
  demonstrating the State did not meet its burden of proof.Â  The State correctly
  pointed out that it was unable to present a psychological examination until it
  demonstrated probable cause that Valentine was a sexually violent predator.Â 
  Nonetheless, the judge opined that the State should amend the statute.Â  The
  ability or inability of the State to have the Act amended is in no way relevant
  to the inquiry of whether the State has demonstrated that Valentine is a
  sexually violent predator.  
Finally,
  the hearing judge considered Valentineâ€™s original sentence as a factor in
  determining whether he was a sexually violent predator, stating â€œ[T]he
  presiding judge heard this, too . . . and he said this guyâ€™s not that big a
  risk; the risk factors arenâ€™t that severe.â€Â  Further, he remarked, â€œ[A] judge
  who has the ability to put him in jail for fifteen years, he puts him in jail
  for five . . . which is significant to me.â€Â  While the sentencing judge
  undoubtedly considered a number of factors in imposing the sentence upon
  Valentine, we must assume the sentencing judge was concerned only with
  criminally punishing Valentine for his past crimes.Â  However, the civil nature
  of confinement under the Act presents quite a different analysis.Â  Under the Act,
  the hearing judge is asked to evaluate whether probable cause exists to label
  the prisoner a sexually violent predator.Â  The fundamental disconnect between
  the criminal nature of punishment, with which the sentencing judge was entirely
  concerned, and the civil nature of confinement, upon which a sexually violent
  predator determination is based, renders the duration of punishment irrelevant.
The hearing judge
  was limited to an analysis based on probable cause under the Act.Â  Instead of
  engaging in such an analysis, the hearing judge reached his decision on the
  basis of the plea agreement, availability of probation, absence of a
  psychological exam, and the sentence imposed.Â  Pursuant to Beaver and
  the language of the Act itself, these factors were not relevant in determining
  whether Valentine suffered from a mental abnormality that made him likely to
  engage in an act of sexual violence.Â   
Moreover, three
  separate probable cause determinations preceded Valentineâ€™s probable cause
  hearing.Â  The initial inquiry was made by the statutorily required
  multidisciplinary team, composed of â€œ(1) a representative from the Department
  of Corrections; (2) a representative from the Department of Probation, Parole
  and Pardon Services; (3) a representative from the Department of Mental Health
  who is a trained, qualified mental health clinician with expertise in treating
  sexually violent offenders; (4) a retired judge appointed by the Chief Justice
  who is eligible for continued judicial service pursuant to Section 2-19-100;
  and (5) an attorney with substantial experience in the practice of criminal
  defense law to be appointed by the Chief Justice to serve a term of one year.â€Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-50 (Supp. 2006).Â  The prosecutorâ€™s committee reviewed
  the multidisciplinary teamâ€™s report and made the second probable cause
  finding.Â  That committee must include, but is not limited to, a member of the
  staff of the Attorney General, an elected circuit solicitor, and a victimâ€™s
  representative.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-60 (Supp. 2006).Â  Finally, the
  preliminary probable cause determination by the circuit judge in Charleston County found the Attorney Generalâ€™s petition set forth sufficient facts to
  establish probable cause to believe Valentine meets the statutory criteria for
  civil commitment.Â   
Considering the
  scope of the Act and the standard for determining probable cause, we are
  convinced the record does not reasonably support the hearing judgeâ€™s finding
  that the State failed to meet its burden of demonstrating probable cause in
  this case.  
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s order and hold that the State
  demonstrated probable cause under the Act.  
REVERSED
  and REMANDED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and ANDERSON, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1] In addition to the accusations made by the friend and
  the step-daughter, Valentineâ€™s daughter also accused him of fondling her;
  however, Valentine denied the charges, and the State did not pursue them.Â  
 
[2] S.C. Code Â§Â§ 44-48-10 to 44-48-70 (Supp. 2006).
[3] Although Valentine has no prior convictions for
  sexual offenses, he has a prior record for public drunkenness and possession of
  marijuana.Â   
[4] We note this decision was not rendered prior to the
  circuit judgeâ€™s ruling in the instant case.
[5] Although the hearing judgeâ€™s written order stated
  Valentineâ€™s probation restrictions would adequately protect the public, and
  that the State failed to present sufficient evidence Valentine suffered from
  any mental abnormality or personal disorder, his comments from the bench
  indicating he considered additional criteria in his determination were improper
  under Beaver. We acknowledge that when there is a conflict between a
  judgeâ€™s oral ruling and the subsequent written order, the latter controls.Â  Parag
    v. Baby Boy Lovin, 333 S.C. 221, 226, 508 S.E.2d 590, 592 (Ct. App. 1998).Â 
  Here, however, as was apparently the case in Beaver, the hearing judgeâ€™s
  comments from the bench were consistent with his written order.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				South Carolina
      Department of Corrections, Appellant,
				v.
				Bennie Mitchell, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Administrative Law Court
Â John Geathers, Administrative Law Judge
Opinion No. 4352
Submitted January 1, 2008 â€“ Filed March
  10, 2008
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Michael Truesdale, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Bennie Mitchell, of Columbia, Pro Se, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â  The South Carolina Department of
  Corrections (Department) appeals the Administrative Law Courtâ€™s (ALC) order requiring
  it to provide an inmate with new shoes.Â  We reverse.Â   
FACTS
Bennie Mitchell is
  an inmate who suffers from pain related to a spinal cord injury.Â  It is not
  clear from the record, but at some point while incarcerated, Mitchell was sent
  outside the prison to visit a neurologist for pain in his legs.Â  In the
  subsequent report, the neurologist recommended Mitchell acquire â€œbetter shoes
  for walkingâ€ that might alleviate his pain.Â  Thereafter, Mitchell submitted
  Step 1 and Step 2 Inmate Grievance Forms requesting the Department provide for
  him â€œmedically recommended support shoes.â€ Â The Department denied both requests,
  and Mitchell appealed to the ALC.Â  The ALC, having received no brief or record
  from the Department, reversed the Departmentâ€™s decision to deny Mitchellâ€™s
  grievance.Â   
The
  Department responded with a motion to reopen the appeal in November of 2006,
  which the ALC denied.[1]Â 
  In December of 2007, Mitchell filed a motion for contempt, and the court
  ordered the Department to purchase him shoes within twenty days.Â  After
  receiving a pair of leather, high top tennis shoes, Mitchell filed a second
  motion for contempt.Â  A second order was issued, requiring the Department to contact
  Mitchellâ€™s neurologist and obtain the written shoe specifications necessary to
  satisfy his previous recommendation. Â This appeal followed.Â  Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Section 1-23-610 of the South
  Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) sets forth the standard of review when the court of
  appeals is sitting in review of a decision by the ALC on an appeal from an
  administrative agency.Â  â€œThe review of the administrative law judgeâ€™s order
  must be confined to the record.â€Â  Id. Â The court of appeals may reverse
  or modify the decision only if substantive rights of the appellant [have] been
  prejudiced because the decision is clearly erroneous in light of the reliable
  and substantial evidence on the whole record, arbitrary or otherwise
  characterized by an abuse of discretion, or affected by other error of law.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Department first argues that the ALC should have dismissed Mitchellâ€™s
  appeal for lack of subject matter jurisdiction in accordance with Al-Shabazz
    v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 527 S.E.2d 742 (2000); Sullivan v. SCDC, 355
  S.C. 437, 586 S.E.2d 124 (2003); Slezak v. SCDC, 361 S.C. 327, 605
  S.E.2d 506 (2004); and Skipper v. SCDC, 370 S.C. 267, 633 S.E.2d 910 (Ct.
  App. 2006). Â We disagree.
Our supreme court recently offered clarification of Al-Shabazz and its progeny as to the ALCâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction in Furtick v.
  South Carolina Department of Corrections, 374 S.C. 334, 649 S.E.2d 35
  (2007). Â In Furtick, the court reiterated Al-Shabazzâ€™s holding
  that â€œthe ALC has subject matter jurisdiction over an inmateâ€™s appeal when the
  claim sufficiently â€˜implicates a state-created liberty interest.â€™â€Â  Furtick,
  374 S.C. at 339, 649 S.E.2d at 38. Â The court further quoted its clarification
  of jurisdiction in Slezak, stating â€œthe ALC has jurisdiction over all inmate grievance appeals that have been properly filed; the ALC however, is
  not required to hold a hearing in every matter.â€Â  Id. at 340, 649 S.E.2d
  at 38 (emphasis in original).Â   
We reject the Departmentâ€™s contention that the ALC should have
  dismissed the appeal because it believes Mitchellâ€™s shoe request does not fall
  within a protected right.Â  Furtick holds that when an inmateâ€™s grievance
  to an ALC does not implicate a state-created liberty or property interest, the
  ALC may summarily dismiss the appeal at its discretion.Â  (emphasis
  added).Â  Thus, the ALC clearly had subject matter jurisdiction to hear
  Mitchellâ€™s appeal.Â  Although the ALC could have addressed whether Mitchellâ€™s
  claim implicated a liberty or property interest, and thus could have summarily
  dismissed the case if it determined Mitchellâ€™s claim did not, the ALC chose not
  to, and heard the appeal.Â  Under Furtick, this was in the ALCâ€™s
  discretion.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â   
The Department next maintains the ALC improperly reversed the partiesâ€™
  burden of proof on appeal.Â  We agree.
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of
  review an ALC must apply when reviewing an agencyâ€™s decision:

	The court may not substitute its judgment for the judgment of the
  agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact. The court may
  affirm the decision of the agency or remand the case for further proceedings.
  The court may reverse or modify the decision if substantial rights of the
  appellant have been prejudiced because the administrative findings, inferences,
  conclusions, or decisions are: 
	
		(a) in violation of constitutional or
  statutory provisions; 
		(b) in excess of the statutory authority
  of the agency; 
		(c) Â  made upon unlawful procedure; 
		(d)  affected by other error of law; 
		(e) clearly erroneous in view of the
  reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the Â Â  whole record;
  or 
		(f) arbitrary or capricious or
  characterized by abuse of discretion or clearly unwarranted Â Â  exercise
  of discretion. 
	

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-380 (A)(6) (2005).
In its order, the ALC explains its rationale in reversing the
  Department by concluding â€œthis court cannot find that the Departmentâ€™s decision
  to deny the Appellantâ€™s grievance was the result of a good-faith exercise of
  the Departmentâ€™s administrative responsibilities and not arbitrary or
  capricious in nature.â€ Â Under the statute stated above, there is no good faith component
  that is required for decisions of the Department.  
Moreover, when appealing an agencyâ€™s decision, the burden rests
  squarely on the appellant to prove that substantive rights were prejudiced based
  on one of six statutory criteria listed above.Â  â€œThe party challenging a
  governmental bodyâ€™s decision bears the burden of proving the decision is
  arbitrary.â€ Â Pressley v. Lancaster County, 343 S.C. 696, 704, 542 S.E.2d
  366, 370 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œThe burden is on appellants to prove convincingly
  that the agencyâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence.â€ Â Waters v. S.C. Land Res. Conservation Commâ€™n, 321 S.C. 219, 226, 467 S.E.2d 913, 917 (1996).
The ALC order is devoid of any finding of evidence adduced by
  Mitchell warranting the ALCâ€™s reversal of the Department.Â  Undeniably,
  Mitchellâ€™s request for medically
  recommended support shoes implicates no state-created liberty interest.Â  Therefore, the ALCâ€™s decision
  must be based on the evidence in the record.Â  We can find no evidence
  indicating the Departmentâ€™s decision was either clearly erroneous, or
  arbitrary, capricious, or characterized by an abuse of discretion.Â 
  Furthermore, Mitchell appears to have received what the neurologist initially
  recommended, i.e., â€œbetter shoes for walking.â€Â  Instead, the ALCâ€™s order
  appears to be based on the Departmentâ€™s failure to file a substantive brief.Â 
 
Finally, the Department contends the ALC erred in not reopening the
  case pursuant to the Administrative Law Judge Divisionâ€™s Rules
  of Procedure, and that the ALC exceeded its authority by reversing the decision of
  the Department.Â  Because we find the determination of the issue above
  to be dispositive in the appeal before us, we need not review Mitchellâ€™s
  remaining contentions.Â  See Futch v. McAllister
    Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999)
    (ruling an appellate court need not
  review remaining issues when its
  determination of a prior issue is dispositive of the
  appeal).
CONCLUSION
The
  ALC erred in improperly reversing the burden of proof and the Departmentâ€™s
  decision on appeal.Â  The ALCâ€™s order is therefore
REVERSED.[2]  
KITTREDGE,
  J., and THOMAS, J., concur.  

[1] We note the Department did not appeal the ALCâ€™s
  denial of its motion to reopen the appeal.
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Mary Ann Turner, Appellant,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Health and Environmental Control and State Accident Fund, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Aiken County
Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4353
Submitted January 1, 2008 â€“ Filed March
  10, 2008
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and
  REMANDED


	
		
			
				Ronald A. Hightower, of Lexington, for Appellant.
				Clarke W. McCants, of Aiken, and Cynthia B. Polk, of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Mary
  Ann Turner appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the South Carolina
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Appellate Panel).Â  Turner contends the
  circuit court erred in finding substantial evidence existed for the Appellate
  Panel to hold she sustained a thirty percent permanent partial disability to
  her back and had reached maximum medical improvement.Â  Turner also maintains
  the circuit court erred in failing to find she is entitled to have her doctor
  designated as the authorized treating medical provider and in failing to find
  she is entitled to an award for travel reimbursement.Â  We affirm in part,
  reverse in part, and remand as follows.Â Â Â Â Â Â   
FACTS/ PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Turner fell and injured
  her back on November 16, 1999, while exiting the South Carolina Department of
  Health and Environmental Control (DHEC) building for a fire drill.Â  Following
  the accident, DHEC provided medical treatment and paid temporary total
  compensation to Turner.Â  Thereafter, a hearing was held before a single
  commissioner.Â  At the hearing, Turner asserted she had injuries to her neck,
  arms, and legs as a result of the accident.Â  Turner also sought payment of
  additional temporary total compensation.Â  The commissioner found Turner had
  reached maximum medical improvement from her injury on October 10, 2001, and
  that she was not entitled to additional medical care.Â  The commissioner also
  found Turner was entitled to a finding of thirty percent permanent partial
  disability to her lower back, and that Turner had not sustained any additional
  injuries.Â Â   
Turner then sought
  Appellate Panel review.Â  Following a hearing, the Appellate Panel affirmed the
  single commissioner, adding, however, that Turner was entitled to additional
  medical care.Â Â Â  Following Turnerâ€™s request for judicial review of the
  Appellate Panelâ€™s decision, the circuit court determined the Panelâ€™s findings
  of fact were insufficient and incomplete, and remanded the matter to the Panel
  to enter additional factual findings.Â   
Pursuant to the
  circuit courtâ€™s order, the Appellate Panel issued a new decision and order,
  again finding Turner sustained a thirty percent permanent partial disability to
  her lower back and had reached maximum medical improvement.Â  The Panel also
  found Turner was entitled to ongoing medical treatment; however, it then ruled
  that Respondents should be responsible for all causally related and authorized
  medical treatment to the Claimantâ€™s lower back until the date of maximum
    medical improvement.Â  Turner appealed the Panelâ€™s decision to the circuit
  court a second time.Â  After the subsequent hearing, the circuit court affirmed
  the Appellate Panel in full, finding that the factual findings and conclusions
  of law were supported by substantial evidence contained in the record.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina
  Administrative Procedures Act governs judicial review of a decision of an
  administrative agency.Â  Clark v. Aiken County of Govâ€™t, 366 S.C. 102,
  107, 620 S.E.2d 99, 101 (Ct.Â  App. 2005).Â  Section 1-23-380(a)(5) of the South
  Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) establishes the substantial evidence rule as the
  standard of review.Â  Under this standard, a reviewing court may reverse or
  modify an agency decision based on errors of law, but may only reverse or
  modify an agencyâ€™s findings of fact if they are clearly erroneous.Â  The court
  reviewing the agencyâ€™s decision should not substitute its own findings of fact
  for those of the agency nor should the court substitute its judgment for that
  of the agency as to the weight of the evidence.Â  Tobey v. L & P Constr.
    Co., 296 S.C. 122, 125, 370 S.E. 2d 897, 899 (Ct. App. 1988).Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.
Turner
  first asserts the circuit court erred in finding the Appellate Panel set forth
  adequate findings of fact and conclusions of law to support its decision in
  this case.Â  We disagree.
The Appellate
  Panelâ€™s findings must be sufficiently detailed to enable the reviewing court to
  determine whether the findings are supported by the evidence.Â  Parsons v. Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 66, 456 S.E.2d 366, 368 (1995).Â  In this case, the
  Appellate Panel amended its original decision and order to include more
  specific findings of fact.Â  In its amended order, the Appellate Panel makes
  reference to specific medical reports establishing the course of treatment for
  Turner, the various diagnoses made as part of her care and treatment, the dates
  on which various providers found her to have reached maximum medical
  improvement, and their opinions regarding the degree of permanent physical
  impairment sustained by Turner as a result of the injury.Â  Moreover, the
  Appellate Panel makes specific reference to those portions of the testimony
  presented to the single commissioner which support the findings and conclusions
  regarding the reasons she left her work and the extent of permanent
  disability.Â  Therefore, we find the circuit court did not err in concluding
  that the Appellate Panelâ€™s findings were sufficiently detailed.Â   
II.
Turner
  also asserts the circuit court erred in concluding that the decision of the
  Appellate Panel is supported by substantial evidence.Â  We disagree.
Turner
  was evaluated by Dr. W. David Redmond who found she sustained a lumbar strain
  and aggravation of a pre-existing degenerative arthritic condition and sustained
  seven percent impairment to her lower back.Â  Dr. Donald Johnson stated Turner
  suffered from degenerative lumbar disc disease and from a cervical strain.Â  He
  also stated that Turner had reached medical maximum improvement and suffered
  ten percent impairment to her back and five percent impairment to her neck.Â 
  Moreover, Dr. Guy Heyl, to whom Turner was referred by her attorney, opined
  that her neck and upper extremity problems were not related to her fall down
  the stairs, and that she had sustained a fourteen percent impairment to her
  back.Â  Finally, Turner was seen by Dr. Jeffrey Rueben in November of 2001, who
  stated he did not recommend any additional treatment.Â   
The
  record, therefore, is replete with evidence sufficient to satisfy the Appellate
  Panelâ€™s findings.Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence that, in viewing the
  record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the same conclusion
  that the [Appellate Panel] reached.â€Â  Lockridge v. Santens of America, Inc.,
  344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œThe possibility of
  drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an
  administrative agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Lee v. Harborside CafÃ©, 350 S.C. 74, 78, 564 S.E.2d 354, 356 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C.
  430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984)).Â  Accordingly, we find the circuit court
  did not err.Â Â Â   
III.
Turner next asserts
  she is entitled to an award of ongoing and future medical treatment pursuant to Dodge v. Bruccoli, Clark, Layman, Inc. et al., 334 S.C. 574, 514 S.E.2d
  593 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  DHEC concedes this issue in its brief; therefore Turner
  is entitled to that award.Â   
IV.
Turner
  also contends Southern Neurological Institute should have been designated as
  the authorized treating medical provider, and DHEC should be required to pay
  all medical expenses associated therewith.Â   
Turner
  argues she is entitled to have her doctors declared the authorized physicians,
  and that defendants are required to pay for such medical costs.Â  This
  proposition is inconsistent with S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-60 (Supp. 2007) and Â§ 42-9-10
  (1985), which establish the rights of the employer and the employee with regard
  to payment for treatments, and ultimately gives great deference to the
  Appellate Panel.Â  This statute does not give a unilateral right to claimants to
  select their treating physician, and such an unencumbered right undermines the
  authority of the commission, as prescribed by the legislature.Â  Accordingly, we
  find there is substantial evidence to support the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision
  not to declare Turnerâ€™s doctors the authorized physicians in this case.Â  
 
V.
Finally,
  Turner contends she is entitled to reimbursement for travel expenses. Turner
  relies on Section 67-1601 of the South Carolina Code of Regulations (1976),
  which is titled â€œExpenses Incurred in Receiving Medical Treatment,
  Reimbursement.â€Â  It states the following:

	A.  The expenses incurred for travel
  to receive medical attention which shall be reimbursed to the claimant are:
	(1)  Mileage to and from a place of medical attention which
  is more than five miles away from home in accordance with the amount allowed
  state employees for mileage; and
	(2)  Actual cost of expenses incurred in using public
  transportation; and
	(3)  Actual cost of reasonable overnight lodging and
  subsistence.
	B.  The claimant shall receive
  reimbursement from the employerâ€™s representative.Â Â Â  

Turner appears to be entitled
  to reimbursement from DHECâ€™s representative under this statute.Â  Moreover, DHEC
  does not address this issue in its brief.Â  See First Union Natâ€™l Bank
    v. FCVS Communications, 321 S.C. 496, 502, 469 S.E.2d 613, 617 (Ct. App.
  1996) (if respondent fails to respond to an issue in his brief, the appellate
  court may treat the failure to respond as a confession that the appellantâ€™s
  position is correct), reversed on other grounds, 328 S.C. 290, 494
  S.E.2d 429 (1997).Â  However, since it is not clear from the record the amount
  of money Turner is seeking for travel reimbursement, we remand this case to the
  circuit court for the purpose of entering an appropriate order remanding the
  case to the Appellate Panel for a hearing solely on the issue of travel
  reimbursement.  
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing reasons, we conclude there is substantial evidence to affirm
  the circuit courtâ€™s findings; however, we modify the order to the extent Turner
  is entitled to ongoing and future medical treatments, and remand the issue of
  travel reimbursement.Â  The decision of the circuit court is accordingly
AFFIRMED
  IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED.
KITTREDGE, J.,
  and THOMAS, J., concur. Â Â Â Â
