THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				James Mellen, Appellant / Respondent,
				v.
				David Patrick Lane, Respondent / Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Charleston County
Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-in-Equity 
Opinion No. 4354
Submitted March 1, 2008 â€“ Filed March 11, 2008

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Donald
  H. Howe, of Charleston, for Appellant / Respondent.
				Deborah
  Harrison Sheffield, of Columbia, and Hugh W. Buyck, of Charleston, for
  Respondent-Appellant.
			
		
	

ANDERSON, J.:Â  After being injured in a brawl outside of a bar, James
  Mellen brought a civil action for assault and battery against David Patrick Lane.Â  The Master-in-Equity found Lane liable for Mellenâ€™s injuries, awarding Mellen
  $200,000 in actual damages, but declining to award punitive damages.Â  Lane
  contends the Master erred in determining his actions were the proximate cause
  of Mellenâ€™s injuries.Â  Mellen maintains the Master erred by denying punitive
  damages.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
In the early
  morning hours of September 23, 2001, Mellen sustained a fractured skull when he
  was struck in the head with a bottle during a melee outside Big Johnâ€™s, a bar
  located in Charleston, South Carolina.Â  At the time of the incident, Mellen was
  twenty-one years old, and attending the College of Charleston.
After leaving work
  around 10 p.m., on September 22, 2001, Mellen and his friend Josh Tarokh joined
  a group of friends who were already at a bar.Â  The group consisted of Stephanie
  Vrla, Mellenâ€™s girlfriend; Vrlaâ€™s roommates, Melissa and Jennifer; Jenniferâ€™s
  boyfriend; and James Trabert.Â  Mellen and his friends relocated to Big Johnâ€™s
  between 11:30 p.m. and 12:30 a.m.Â  Upon arriving at Big Johnâ€™s, Mellen observed
  a group of men, including Lane:

	I
  noticed that there was a group of gentlemen at the bar, kind of loud,
  obnoxious, kind of drunk guys you donâ€™t want to get in their way.
	. . . 
	[Y]ou
  know, they were kind of - - they were definitely having a good time.Â  One of
  the gentlemen was passing shots around, it seems like to whatever girls would
  walk by him.

Mellen stated he
  did not interact with the men inside Big Johnâ€™s, other than â€œ[a]t one point,
  [he] took the shot off the table and [he] placed it back on the bar.â€Â  At
  approximately 1:30 a.m., Big Johnâ€™s issued their â€œlast callâ€ for drinks and
  Mellen and his friend began to leave.Â  Mellen described the altercation and the
  events leading up to it:

	We all
  kind of gathered up inside the bar after they called last call.Â  And we walked
  out the front door onto East Bay Street.Â  And after that we walked around the
  corner to Pinckney Street and started walking down Pinckney Street.
	. . .
	[Lane]
  was standing in the doorway, and I was walking with Stephanie by my side.Â  Her
  friend Melissa and Jennifer, they were in front of us.Â  Mr. Lane was standing
  in the doorway.Â  And I noticed him, he was kind of hassling Melissa and
  Jennifer, kind of, you know, hey, come back in, that kind of thing.Â  And so it
  kind of put me on guard right off the bat.
	. . . 
	Well, we
  came up, and they kept on walking, Melissa and Jennifer.Â  And when we got up
  there, Mr. Lane reached across my body and started grabbing my girlfriend.Â  I
  caught his arm, and I asked him, you know, pretty politely, I said:Â  â€œLeave it
  alone.Â  Weâ€™re leaving.â€Â  And at that point he started saying numerous
  expletives to me.
	. . . 
	I turned
  back to him, you know, said some certain things to him, and then turned to walk
  away.Â  And I remember being pushed very hard in the back.Â  And thatâ€™s all I
  remember after that.Â  And I woke up and I was in the hospital.

Josh
  Tarokh was aware of the group of men in Big Johnâ€™s:Â  â€œThey were just [a] loud,
  obnoxious, drunk crowd.â€Â  Tarokh, who was walking with Mellen, saw Lane shove
  Mellen, and asserted Lane â€œ[kept] pursuing [Mellen],â€ prompting Tarokh to
  â€œ[swing] at Mr. Lane.â€Â  Tarokh recalled the incident:

	I just -
  - immediately after I swung at Mr. Lane, all of his friends at the door, you
  know, they immediately started coming after me.Â  So I just, you know, them swinging
  at me, you know, and I just kind of cover my head, ran about 10 yards away.Â 
  And by the time I turned around, thatâ€™s when Mr. Mellon [sic] was struck, and
  everybody just scattered.
	. . . 
	Amh, you
  know, I had two guys like trying to punch me, and come at me.Â  I saw [Mellen]
  and Mr. Lane in front of each other, you know.Â  But after that, you know - -
  and then after everyone ran, I just saw [Mellen] laying on the ground.
	. . .
	I ran
  towards [Mellen], and then saw that his head was busted open, blood
  everywhere.Â  And I chased after Mr. Lane.
	. . .
	I was
  going to the parking lot behind Big Johnâ€™s.Â  By then Mr. Lane was, you know,
  shutting the door of his car, you know.Â  And I was on the phone with the
  dispatch, you know, and I was screaming at him, telling him to stop.

During
  cross-examination, Tarokh was asked if Mellen fell as a result of Laneâ€™s
  initial push.Â  He responded â€œNoâ€ and confessed he did not see who actually
  struck Mellen in the head, causing Mellenâ€™s brain injuries.
James Trabert was
  involved in the brawl, and attested he â€œthought [he] saw [Mellen] get hit with
  a bottle.â€Â  The Master-in-Equity quizzed Trabert, â€œAnd somebody wearing a
  Citadel polo shirt is who slammed [Mellen] with a bottle?â€Â  Retorting
  affirmatively, Trabert identified Lurie Poston as the bottle wielder.Â   
David Lane
  professed he planned to tailgate prior to and attend the Citadel football game
  on September 22, 2001.Â  He began consuming alcohol at approximately 2 p.m.,
  while tailgating, and continued drinking throughout the day.Â  Lane and his
  comrades left the game and went to Big Johnâ€™s at about 10 p.m., staying there
  until the bar closed.Â  Lane depicted his involvement in the skirmish:

	Well, I
  turned, turned away, and then I was pushed from behind.Â  There were three
  people in front of me, two guys and a girl, and I was shoved from behind.Â  And
  then I hit into the person in front of me, and he went to go - - he went almost
  down.Â  I grabbed him by the back of the shirt to pick him back up.
	. . .
	Then the
  individual with the shirt turned around, the individual on the left turned
  around.Â  The individual on the left shoved his finger in my face, told me donâ€™t
  do it.Â  Weâ€™ll beat the crap out of you, something along those lines.Â  I let out
  an expletive, and I got hit.

When
  questioned about causing Mellenâ€™s injuries, Lane asseverated:Â  â€œNo.Â  I thought
  I was preventing an injury.â€Â  Lane denied reaching for Vrla.  
Laneâ€™s
  friend Peter Swiderski accompanied Lane to the Citadel game and Big Johnâ€™s the
  night Mellen was injured.Â  Swiderski, while declaring he did not see who hit
  Mellen with a bottle, witnessed the altercation:

	I walked
  out.Â  We were walking around the corner of Big Johnâ€™s, make a left walking
  towards the back, and I see David Lane surrounded by about three men.Â  And they
  were, you know punching at them.Â  Iâ€™m like, whatâ€™s going on here.Â  Iâ€™m like
  this is not good.Â  I took off after them, okay.Â  Peeled the guy that was, if
  you have A David Laneâ€™s back was to me, because Iâ€™m coming around the corner.Â 
  I took the guy that was on his right â€“ hand side, pushed him off to the side.Â 
  Me and him got into a scuffle there, okay?Â  And I looked back and the Plaintiff
  was on the ground.

Another companion
  of Laneâ€™s that night was Gregory McHone.Â  McHone remembered the row:

	[W]e
  walked up to [the fight].Â  It looked like some of our buddies were in the mix,
  and we just stepped in and started trying to separate people.
	And at
  some point I remember I had my back to the parking lot.Â  And I remember the
  level of crowd noises increasing, like some particular event had happened.Â  And
  I turned and to my left rear I saw Mr. Mellon [sic].Â  Well, I didnâ€™t know it
  was him, at the time, but I saw a gentleman laying on the ground.

McHone checked on
  Mellen, but Mellen did not answer:Â  â€œI asked him if he was okay, and he didnâ€™t
  respond to me.â€
Lurie Poston is the
  individual Trabert identified as hitting Mellen with the bottle.Â  He advanced
  he and his companions did purchase shots at Big Johnâ€™s but denied they were
  overly rambunctious:Â  â€œWell, you know, we did buy some shots, but we werenâ€™t
  rowdy.Â  You know, we were respectful.â€Â  When asked if he saw what injured
  Mellen, Poston stated:Â  â€œMy impression was he fell.Â  I never saw him get hit.â€Â 
  Acknowledging Trabertâ€™s allegations, Poston offered:

  the fact that he neither foresaw nor should have foreseen the extent of harm or
  the manner in which it occurred does not negative his liability.â€); Matthews,
  239 S.C. at 628, 124 S.E.2d at 324 (quoting Brown, 233 S.C. at 352-353,
  105 S.E.2d at 84-85); Locklear, 193 S.C. at 318, 8 S.E.2d at 325; Small
    v. Pioneer Mach., Inc., 329 S.C. 448, 463, 494 S.E.2d 835, 842-843 (Ct.
  App. 1997) (â€œWhile it is not necessary that the actor must have contemplated
  the particular event that occurred, the actor cannot be charged with that which
  is unpredictable or could not be expected to happen.â€); Hill, 313 S.C.
  at 308, 437 S.E.2d at 182.
â€œHowever,
  even if the intervening acts are not foreseeable, the primary wrongdoer is
  nevertheless liable if his actions alone â€˜would have caused the loss in natural
  course.â€™â€Â  Young, 270 S.C. at 463, 242 S.E.2d at 676 (quoting Benford
    v. Berkeley Heating Co., 258 S.C. 357, 365, 188 S.E.2d 841, 844 (1972)).
In Hensley
  v. Heavrin, 277 S.C. 86, 282 S.E.2d 854 (1981), our Supreme Court examined
  a doctorâ€™s liability for proximately causing his patientâ€™s injuries.Â  Id. at 87, 282 S.E.2d 855.Â  The doctor incorrectly diagnosed his patient with
  syphilis.Â  Id.Â  As a result, the patientâ€™s husband assumed his wife was
  engaged in extramarital activities, and struck her in the jaw, fracturing it in
  two places.Â  Id. at 87-88, 282 S.E.2d at 855.Â  The Court determined the
  doctor could not have reasonably foreseen the patient would be injured by her
  husband as a result of his incorrect diagnosis:Â  â€œ[T]here can be no cause of
  action against her doctor for the battery committed by [her] husband, since
  such an action is an unforeseeable intervening cause of injuries.â€Â  Id. 
 
4.     Intervening Criminal Act

	The
  general rule of law is that when, between [an act] and the occurrence of an
  injury, there intervenes a willful, malicious, and criminal act of a third
  person producing the injury, but that such was not intended by the [original
  actor] and could not have been foreseen by him, the causal chain between the
  [original act] and the accident is broken.

Stone v. Bethea, 251 S.C. 157, 162, 161 S.E.2d 171, 173-174 (1968).Â 
  In other words, when between the time of the original act or omission and the
  occurrence of the injury, a third person intervenes with a willful, malicious,
  and criminal act producing the injury, but the intervening criminal act was not
  intended by the original actor and could not have been foreseen by him as a
  probable result of his own actions, the causal link between the original act
  and the injury is broken.Â  Fortner v.
    Carnes, 258 S.C. 455, 462, 189 S.E.2d 24, 27 (1972); Stone, 251 S.C.
  at 162, 161 S.E.2d at 173-174 (citing Johnston v. Atl. Coast Line Ry. Co.,
  183 S.C. 126, 135, 190 S.E. 459, 462-463 (1937)); Goode v. St. Stephens
    United Methodist Church, 329 S.C. 433, 448, 494 S.E.2d 827, 835 (Ct. App.
  1997).Â  In such case, there is no proximate cause, and therefore, no liability.Â  Id.
Stone addresses an intervening criminal act and how it affects the original actorâ€™s
  liability.Â  Stone, 251 S.C. 157, 161 S.E.2d 171.Â  Stone was injured when
  her vehicle was struck by a thief driving Betheaâ€™s vehicle.Â  Id. at 159,
  161 S.E.2d at 172.Â  Stone avouched Betheaâ€™s negligence by leaving the keys in
  his unattended vehicle, leading to it being stolen, was the proximate cause of
  her injuries.Â  Id. at 160, 161 S.E.2d at 172.Â  On the other hand, Bethea
  asserted the intervening criminal act of the thief stealing his vehicle insulated
  him from the resulting injury.Â  Id. at 160, 161 S.E.2d at 172-173.Â 
  Bethea professed Stone being injured by Betheaâ€™s car, after it was stolen and
  driven negligently by a thief was an unforeseeable consequence of leaving his
  car unlocked, unattended, with the keys inside.Â  Id. at 161, 161 S.E.2d
  at 173.Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court declared:

	It is
  our conclusion that under the evidence in this case that the intervening
  independent act of negligence and willfulness on the part of the thief who
  stole [Betheaâ€™s] automobile was the sole, proximate and efficient cause of the
  injury to [Stone] and such could not have been foreseen by [Bethea] under the
  attendant circumstances and was not a proximate cause resulting from any act of
  negligence on the part of [Bethea].

Id. at 164, 161 S.E.2d at 174-175.Â  The Court affirmed
  the trial judgeâ€™s decision to grant Betheaâ€™s motion for directed verdict.Â  Id.Â  
 
In
  the case sub judice, the Master determined:Â  (1) the intervening
  act of the bottle wielder was not the sole, proximate and
  efficient cause of Mellenâ€™s injuries; (2) the intervention of the bottle
  wielder could have been reasonably foreseen by Lane given the attendant
  circumstances; (3) Laneâ€™s actions were the proximate and efficient cause of
  Mellenâ€™s injuries; and (4) Lane is liable to Mellen.Â  There is sufficient evidence
  in the record to reasonably support the Masterâ€™s conclusions.
Lane
  and his companions were drinking over a twelve hour period prior to the
  altercation at Big Johnâ€™s.Â  The incident occurred around 2 a.m., after the bar
  had its â€œlast call.â€Â  The Master found the testimony of Mellen and his friends
  more credible than Laneâ€™s. Â He determined Lane made rude comments to Mellen as
  he exited Big Johnâ€™s and grabbed at Mellenâ€™s girlfriend.Â  Lane shoved Mellen in
  the back, and the Master reasoned this act proximately caused the fracas, without
  which Mellen would not have been injured.Â  But for Laneâ€™s action, there would
  have been no brawl and no injury.Â  While it is not necessary for Lane to have
  contemplated the exact result of Mellen being struck with a bottle, the
  altercation and actions therein were the natural and probable consequences of
  Laneâ€™s initiation of the fight under the attendant circumstances.Â  The intervention
  of someone hitting Mellen with the bottle did not break the sequence or causal
  connection between Laneâ€™s instigation of the bout and Mellenâ€™s injury.Â  Because
  this intervention was reasonably foreseeable in the attendant circumstances,
  Lane is not insulated from liability.Â  Thus, the evidence amply supports the
  Masterâ€™s factual finding of proximate cause.
5.     Damages Awards
Lane
  argues the evidence in the record does not support the Masterâ€™s actual damages
  award to Mellen.Â  Mellen contends the Master erred in denying him punitive
  damages.Â  We are mindful of the Master-in-Equityâ€™s discretion in awarding
  damages, and the â€œany evidenceâ€ standard of review for actual and punitive
  damages in the present case.Â  We review the awards seriatim.
a.     Actual Damages
Lane
  maintains the evidence does not support the actual damages award.Â  We disagree.
Actual damages are properly called compensatory
  damages, meaning to compensate, to make the injured party whole, to put him in
  the same position he was in prior to the damages received insofar as this is
  monetarily possible. Â See Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 378, 529 S.E.2d 528, 533 (2000).
  Â Actual damages are awarded to a litigant in compensation for his actual loss
  or injury. Â Laird v. Nationwide Ins. Co., 243 S.C. 388, 396, 134 S.E.2d 206, 210 (1964).
  Â Actual damages are such as will compensate the party for injuries suffered or
  losses sustained. Â Id. Â They are such
  damages as will simply make good or replace the loss caused by the wrong or
  injury. Â Actual damages are damages in satisfaction of, or in recompense for,
  loss or injury sustained. Â Barnwell v. Barber-Colman Co., 301 S.C. 534, 537, 393 S.E.2d 162, 163 (1989).
  Â The goal is to restore the injured party, as nearly as possible through the
  payment of money, to the same position he was in before the wrongful injury
  occurred. Â Clark, 339 S.C. at 378, 529 S.E.2d at 533.
Actual or compensatory damages include compensation
  for all injuries which are naturally the proximate result of the alleged
  wrongful conduct of the defendant. Â See Rogers v. Florence Printing Co., 233 S.C. 567, 578, 106 S.E.2d 258, 264 (1958).
  Â The basic measure of actual damages is the amount needed to compensate the
  plaintiff for the losses proximately caused by the defendant's wrong so that
  the plaintiff will be in the same position he would have been in if there had
  been no wrongful injury. Â See Rogers, 233 S.C. at 578, 106 S.E.2d at 264; Hutchison v. Town of Summerville, 66 S.C. 442, 448, 45 S.E. 8, 10 (1903).

	In awarding actual damages in the instant case, the
  Master expounded:
	
		Because
  I find the evidence as to the assault and battery, the proximate cause, and the
  nature and extent of damages have been proved by the preponderance of the
  evidence, I find an award of actual damages is appropriate.
		I find
  that the fractured skull, the need for EMS, the hospitalization at MUSC, loss
  of a semester at college, the need for the Plaintiff to move in with his
  parents to recuperate, and the various aspects of his recuperation as detailed
  by his sister and parents, are all actual damages proximately caused by the
  Defendantâ€™s conduct.Â  Plaintiffâ€™s permanent loss of smell and the closed head
  injury as outlined by Dr. Waid, Plaintiff, and his family are also the direct
  and proximate result of the assault by Defendant.
		The
  evidence establishes that Plaintiff sustained a painful and debilitating
  fractured skull.Â  The first few days were excruciatingly painful and life
  threatening. . . . Because of his fragile state, several weeks passed before he
  was left alone for any significant period.Â  He required help getting around the
  house and continued to subsist in extreme pain.Â  He was nauseated, weak,
  confused, and in extreme pain.
		. . .
		Plaintiff
  does have some permanent injuries.Â  His sense of smell is virtually
  non-existent.Â  There are certain citrus smells he notices at times.Â  His lack
  of smell affects his taste of food.Â  It also presents safety issues. . . . 
		
		He suffered
  a subdural hematoma (i.e., bleeding in his brain) and had a closed head
  injury.Â  The permanent effects of his injury involve loss of certain
  â€œmultitasking skillsâ€ as testified by the Plaintiff and his family and
  supported by the medical evidence of Neuropsychologist Randolph Waid.
		. . . 
		Closely
  associated with the deficiencies in the ability to â€œmultitaskâ€ are the
  secondary factors of increased anxiety, fatigue and frustration.Â  Plaintiff now
  tends to withdraw from the frivolity of crowds and friendly (and even family)
  social interaction.Â  Because he becomes mentally fatigued more easily, he is
  more likely to lose his temper with co-workers or friends.Â  He becomes easily
  flustered and anxious in social situations.
	

The
  Master initially awarded $100,000 in actual damages:Â  $8,000 for past medical
  expenses, $40,000 for past physical pain and suffering, $12,000 for past
  emotional distress, $15,000 for past loss of enjoyment of life, and a
  cumulative $25,000 for actual future damages.Â  Later, the Master amended his actual
  future damages award, averring:

	Having
  considered the merits of the Plaintiffâ€™s argument [to increase actual future damages]
  and the life expectancy tables as well as the sufficiency of evidence tending
  to establish that the Plaintiff will suffer future damages as a result of the
  injuries sustained as a result of the Defendantâ€™s conduct, I hereby alter and
  amend my prior award of actual future damages as follows:
	For
  future physical pain and suffering, I find actual damages in the amount of
  $25,000.
	For
  future emotional distress, I find actual damages in the amount of $50,000.
	For
  future loss of enjoyment of life, I find actual damages in the amount of
  $50,000.

Accordingly, the
  total actual damages awarded to Mellen amount to $200,000.Â  The record contains
  sufficient evidence to support the Masterâ€™s award for actual damages.Â  Mellen
  was a virile young man in his early 20s when he was injured.Â  There was a
  plethora of evidence regarding the cause and effect of Mellenâ€™s skull fracture
  to justify the Masterâ€™s determination of actual damages, and there was no error
  of law or abuse of discretion.
b.     Punitive Damages
Mellen
  contends the Master erred by denying punitive damages.Â  We disagree.
Punitive damages, alternatively known as exemplary
  damages, are imposed as punishment. Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 378-379, 529 S.E.2d 528, 533 (2000).Â 
  Punitive damages are allowed in the interest of society in the nature of
  punishment and as a warning and example to deter the wrongdoer and others from
  committing like offenses in the future. Â Id. Â Moreover, they serve to vindicate a private
  right by requiring the wrongdoer to pay money to the injured party. Â Id.
At
  least three important purposes are served by a punitive damages award: (1)
  punishment of the defendant's reckless, willful, wanton, or malicious conduct;
  (2) deterrence of similar future conduct by the defendant or others; and (3) compensation for
  the reckless or willful invasion of the plaintiff's private rights. Â Id. Â The paramount purpose for awarding punitive damages
  is not to compensate the plaintiff but to punish and set an example for others.
On
  the issue of punitive damages, the highest burden of proof known to the civil
  law is applicable. Â Section 15-33-135 of the South Carolina Code provides:Â  â€œIn any civil action where punitive
  damages are claimed, the plaintiff has the burden of proving such damages by
  clear and convincing evidence.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-33-135 (Supp. 2003). Â Punitive damages can only be awarded where the plaintiff proves by
  clear and convincing evidence the defendant's misconduct was willful, wanton,
  or in reckless disregard of the plaintiff's rights. Â Taylor v.
    Medenica, 324 S.C. 200, 220, 479 S.E.2d 35, 46 (1996); Lister v.
      NationsBank of Delaware, 329 S.C. 133, 149, 494 S.E.2d 449, 458 (Ct.App.1997).
There
  is no formula or standard to be used as a measure for assessing punitive
  damages. However, factors relevant to consideration of punitive damages are:Â  (1)
  the character of the defendant's acts; (2)
  the nature and extent of the harm to plaintiff which defendant caused or
  intended to cause; (3) defendant's
    degree of culpability; (4) the punishment that should be imposed; (5) duration
    of the conduct; (6) defendant's awareness or concealment; (7) the existence of similar
    past conduct; (8) likelihood the award will deter the defendant or others from
    like conduct; (9) whether the award is
  reasonably related to the harm likely to result from such conduct; and (10)
  defendant's wealth or ability to pay.Â  See Gamble v. Stevenson, 305 S.C. 104, 111-112, 406 S.E.2d 350, 354 (1991); see also Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 306, 536 S.E.2d 408, 422 (Ct.App.2000) ( â€œUnder Gamble, the trial court is
  not required to make findings of fact for each factor to uphold a punitive
  damage award.â€).
The South Carolina Supreme Court illuminated the
  discretionary nature of an award of punitive damages in Jordan v. Holt,
  362 S.C. 201, 608 S.E.2d 129 (2005):

	[The Court of Appeals] must
  affirm the trial court's finding of punitive damages if any evidence reasonably
  supports the judge's factual findings. Â An award of punitive damages is left
  almost entirely to the discretion of the jury and trial judge. Â Charles v. Texas Co., 199 S.C. 156, 18 S.E.2d 719 (1942). Â The
  rationale for vesting discretion in the trial court was expressed in Lucht v. Youngblood, 266 S.C. 127, 138, 221 S.E.2d 854, 860 (1976):
	The fact [the trial judge] heard the evidence and was
  more familiar than we with the evidentiary atmosphere at trial gives [the trial
  judge], we think, a better informed view than we have. Â This is particularly
  true when the elements of damage are intangibles and the appraisal depends
  somewhat on the observation of the [witnesses] and evaluation of their
  testimony.
	Finally,
  we conclude the trial court also conducted a post-trial review of the punitive
  damages award using the factors outlined by this Court in Gamble v. Stevenson, 305 S.C. 104, 406 S.E.2d 350 (1991) and
  properly set forth its findings on the record. Â In Gamble, the Court explained
  the trial court should consider: (1) the defendant's degree of culpability; (2)
  duration of the conduct; (3) defendant's awareness or concealment; (4) the
  existence of similar past conduct; (5) likelihood that the award will deter the
  defendant or others from like conduct; (6) whether the award is reasonably
  related to the harm likely to result from such conduct; (7) the defendant's
  ability to pay; and (8) other factors deemed appropriate. Â Id. Â The trial
  court found particularly reprehensible Respondents' ouster of Petitioners from
  the management of the business and Respondents' constant failure to respond to
  Petitioners' requests for meetings and financial information. Â The trial court
  again noted Respondents' misappropriation of the LLC's assets and use of money
  for their own personal benefit. The trial court's findings are supported by
  evidence in the record.

Jordan, 362 S.C. at 207, 608 S.E.2d at 132.Â  In reinstating
  the punitive damages award, the Court emphasized the application of the Gamble factors, the discretion of the fact finderâ€™s award, and the â€œany evidenceâ€
  standard applicable to appellate review of punitive damages awards.

	Here, in the order denying punitive damages, the
  Master opined:
	While the Defendantâ€™s initial
  shove of the Plaintiff that set the brawl in motion was intentional, the
  resulting injuries to Mellenâ€™s head were unintentional; however, I specifically
  found that Defendant was the proximate cause of Plaintiffâ€™s injuries since the
  injuries suffered by the Plaintiff were the natural and foreseeable
  consequences of the Defendantâ€™s actions.
	Plaintiff argues that the
  reckless behavior of the Defendant entitles Plaintiff to punitive damages as a
  matter of right. . . .
	I do not believe that
  Defendantâ€™s reckless conduct necessitates a finding of punitive damages.
  . . .

We
  find no error of law in the Master-in-Equityâ€™s denial of punitive damages.Â  He weighed
  each factor before denying a punitive damages award, as set forth in his
  November 7, 2006, order.Â  While the Master declared in his factual findings,
  â€œLaneâ€™s shove to Mellen in the back constituted a battery and was an
  intentional and deliberate act which was willful, wanton, reckless, and
  malicious under the circumstances,â€ it is completely within his discretion to
  deny a punitive damages award.Â  The Master found Mellen was successful in
  proving by the preponderance of evidence Laneâ€™s conduct was the proximate cause
  of his injuries, but he held Mellen fell short of the clear and convincing
  evidence standard required for a punitive damages award.Â  Because punitive
  damages are not mandatory or obligatory and within the Masterâ€™s discretion, the
  denial of a punitive damages award was proper.Â   
CONCLUSION
We
  rule Laneâ€™s conduct was the proximate cause of Mellenâ€™s injuries.Â  We affirm
  the Master-in-Equityâ€™s order awarding actual damages and denying punitive
  damages.Â  Accordingly, the orders of the Master-in-Equity are
AFFIRMED.
SHORT and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Grinnell
      Corporation d/b/a
				Grinnell
          Fire Protection, Appellant/Respondent,
				v.
				John Wood, Respondent,
				and
				American
      Home Assurance Company, Respondent/Appellant,
				and
				Government
      Employees Insurance Company, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â Perry M. Buckner, III, Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 4355
Heard February 5, 2008 â€“ Filed March 11,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Amy M. Snyder and Sean A. Scoopmire, both of Greenville, for
  Appellant/Respondent Grinnell Corporation d/b/a Grinnell Fire Protection.
				David Whittington, of Summerville, for Respondent John Wood.
				Peter H. Dworjanyn, of Columbia, for Respondent/Appellant American
  Home Assurance Company.
				Stephen F. DeAntonio, of Charleston, for Respondent Government
  Employees Insurance Company.
			
		
	

ANDERSON, J.: Grinnell
  Corporation d/b/a Grinnell Fire Protection (Grinnell) and American Home
  Assurance Company (American Home) appeal from an order of the circuit court
  reforming an automobile insurance policy to include uninsured motorist coverage
  (UM) and underinsured motorist coverage (UIM) in the amount of $5,000,000.Â  We
  affirm.  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
The
  parties agree to the following Stipulation of Facts and Exhibits:

	
		
			1.  
			On or about May 1, 2000, John Wood was injured in a 
			motor vehicle accident while in the course and scope of his 
			employment with Grinnell Corporation DBA Grinnell Fire Protection.
 
		
		
			2.  
			The vehicle driven by John Wood at the time of the 
			accident was owned by Grinnell Corporation DBA Grinnell Fire
  Protection.
 
		
		
			3.   
			American Home Insurance Company (aka American Home 
			Assurance Company and/or AIG) issued a policy of insurance to 
			Grinnell Corporation DBA Grinnell Fire Protection, policy number RMCA5347215
  providing automobile insurance coverage for vehicles owned by Grinnell
  Corporation DBA Grinnell Fire Protection including but not limited to the
  automobile involved in this accident.
 
		
		
			4.
			The insurance policy in question provides for 
			coverage limits of Five Million Dollars.
 
		
		
			5.
			he documents identified as Exhibits 1, 2, and 3 
			attached to the stipulation of fact are agreed to by the parties to 
			be true and accurate copies of the original documents in question 
			and authenticated for admissibility into evidence at the hearing on 
			this matter, said exhibits identified as follows:
  Exhibit 1 â€“ American Home Assurance Company insurance policy issued to Grinnell
  Corporation;
  Exhibit 2 â€“ Premium Agreement between American Home Assurance Company and
  Grinnell Corporation; and
  Exhibit 3 â€“ American Home Assurance Company offer/rejection form for optional
  UM/UIM coverage.
		
	

All
  issues of UIM + UM are deemed properly pleaded and raised.
On
  July 1, 1999, Tyco International (US) Inc. (Tyco), obtained a policy of
  insurance with American Home.Â  At the time Tyco obtained the policy, Grinnell
  was a wholly owned subsidiary of Tyco.Â  The policy provided commercial auto
  coverage with liability limits in the amount of $5,000,000 and applied to
  vehicles owned and operated by Grinnell. Â Along with the policy, Tyco and
  American Home executed a â€œpayment agreementâ€ which required Tyco to reimburse
  American Home up to $500,000 for each claim American Home paid.Â  Using a
  standard form, American Home made an â€œOffer of Additional Uninsured and Underinsured
  Automobile Insurance Coveragesâ€ (the Offer Form) for Tycoâ€™s South Carolina
  policy.
Gerald
  M. Goetz executed the Offer Form for Tycoâ€™s South Carolina policy.Â  At the
  time, Goetz was serving as Vice President of Risk Management for Tyco.Â  He had
  worked in the insurance industry as a risk manager since 1978 and earned
  several degrees relating to risk management.Â  Goetz signed only the
  acknowledgement section of the Offer Form.Â  He testified the Offer Form was not
  completed by Tyco; it was filled out by either American Home or the insurance
  broker.Â Â Â   
Goetz
  asserted he was fully aware of Tycoâ€™s options and the nature of UM and UIM
  coverage when he executed the form.Â  According to Goetz, Tyco was â€œeffectively
  self-insuredâ€ due to the $500,000 deductible, and explained that Tyco would not
  have bought additional UM and UIM coverage under any circumstances because
  doing so would increase its own exposure to liability.Â  Additionally, Goetz professed
  Tyco desired to purchase minimum UM and UIM coverage because it carried workersâ€™
  compensation coverage for employees who might be injured while driving company
  vehicles.Â   
On
  May 1, 2000, John Wood sustained injuries from an accident while driving a
  vehicle owned by Grinnell, his employer at the time.Â  The vehicle was insured
  under the policy American Home issued to Grinnell.Â   
Wood
  brought a claim for workersâ€™ compensation benefits against Grinnell which was
  paid.Â  Wood also sought recovery under UM and UIM coverage in the case of John
    Wood v. Lisa Ackerman and John Doe, 2003-CP-08-615.Â  In that action, which
  is currently pending, Wood served both American Home and Government Employees Insurance
  Company (GEICO), the insurance provider for his personal vehicle.
Grinnell
  filed this separate action against Wood, GEICO, and American Home seeking a
  declaratory judgment that it had successfully rejected UIM and additional UM
  coverage under its policy with American Home.Â  GEICO answered, filing a
  counterclaim against Grinnell and a cross-claim against American Home, asking
  for a reformation of Grinnellâ€™s policy to include additional UM and UIM
  coverage.Â  GEICO requested a declaration that American Home is the primary
  insurance provider for UM and UIM coverage.Â  Wood answered and filed a
  cross-claim against American Home, beseeching a reformation of the policy and
  damages for bad faith.
Following
  discovery, Grinnell, GEICO, and Wood filed motions for summary judgment on the
  issues of the offer of UM and UIM and reformation of the policy.Â  American Home
  joined in Grinnellâ€™s motion at the hearing.Â  The motions were heard on the stipulated
  facts above.Â  The circuit court granted summary judgment to Wood and GEICO. 
 
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
I.  Summary
  Judgment/Sufficiency of Offer
In
  reviewing the grant of a motion for summary judgment, the appellate court
  applies the same standard of review as the trial court
  under Rule 56, SCRCP.Â  Pye v. Estate of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, 563, 633
  S.E.2d 505, 509 (2006).Â  Summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine
  issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a
  matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP (â€œThe judgment sought shall be rendered
  forthwith if the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and
  admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no
  genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to
  a judgment as a matter of law.â€); Young v. South Carolina Dept. of
    Disabilities and Special Needs, 374 S.C. 360, 365, 649 S.E.2d 488,
  490 (2007); Madison ex rel. Bryant v. Babcock Center, Inc., 371 S.C. 123, 134,
  638 S.E.2d 650, 655 (2006); Houck
    v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Ins. Co., 366 S.C. 7, 11, 620 S.E.2d 326, 329
  (2005); Bennett v. Investors Title Ins. Co., 370 S.C. 578, 587, 635
  S.E.2d 649, 654 (Ct. App. 2006); B & B Liquors, Inc. v. Oâ€™Neil,
  361 S.C. 267, 270, 603 S.E.2d 629, 631 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In determining whether
  any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences
  therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party; Law
    v. S.C. Dep't of Corrections, 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648
  (2006); Medical Univ. of South Carolina v. Arnaud, 360 S.C. 615, 619,
  602 S.E.2d 747, 749 (2004); Moore v. Weinberg, 373 S.C. 209, 216, 644
  S.E.2d 740, 743 (Ct. App. 2007); Rife v. Hitachi Constr. Mach. Co.,
    Ltd., 363 S.C. 209, 213, 609 S.E.2d 565, 567 (Ct. App. 2005).  
â€œWhen
  an appeal involves stipulated or undisputed
  facts, an appellate court is free to review whether the trial court properly
  applied the law to those facts.â€ WDW Props. v. City of Sumter, 342 S.C.
  6, 10, 535 S.E.2d 631, 632 (2000); Cowden Enterprises, Inc. v. East Coast
    Millwork Distributors, 363 S.C. 540, 543, 611 S.E.2d 259, 260 (Ct. App.
  2005); Goldston v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 358 S.C. 157, 166,
  594 S.E.2d 511, 516 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In
  such cases, we are not required to defer to the circuit courtâ€™s legal
  conclusions. Dreher v. Dreher, 370 S.C. 75, 79, 634 S.E.2d 646, 648
  (2006); J.K. Constr., Inc. v. W. Carolina Regâ€™l Sewer Auth., 336 S.C.
  162, 166, 519 S.E.2d 561, 563 (1999); McGirt v. Nelson, 360 S.C. 307,
  310, 599 S.E.2d 620, 622 (Ct. App. 2004); In re Estate of Boynton, 355
  S.C. 299, 301-302, 584 S.E.2d 154, 155 (Ct. App. 2003).
The
  sufficiency of an offer of UIM or UM coverage is a question of law for the
  court.Â  See Hanover Ins. Co. v. Horace Mann Ins. Co., 301 S.C.
  55, 389 S.E.2d 657 (1990); Antley v. Nobel Ins. Co., 350 S.C. 621, 567
  S.E.2d 872 (Ct. App. 2002); Bower v. Natâ€™l Gen. Ins. Co., 342 S.C. 315,
  536 S.E.2d 693 (Ct. App. 2000), affâ€™d, 351 S.C. 112, 569 S.E.2d 313
  (2002).
II.  Statutory Construction
The issue of interpretation of a statute is a question of law for
  the court.Â  Univ. of S. California v. Moran, 365 S.C. 270, 275, 617
  S.E.2d 135, 137 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Catawba Indian Tribe of South Carolina v. State of
    South Carolina, 372 S.C. 519, 524, 642 S.E.2d 751, 753 (2007), cert.
      denied, Oct. 1, 2007; Charleston County
        Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n v. Somers,
  319 S.C. 65, 67, 459 S.E.2d 841, 843 (1995).
The cardinal rule of statutory
  interpretation is to determine the intent of the legislature. Â Bass v.
    Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 459, 617 S.E.2d 369, 377 (Ct. App. 2005), cert.
      dismissed as improvidently granted, 374 S.C. 346, 649 S.E.2d 485 (2007); Georgia-Carolina
        Bail Bonds, Inc. v. County of Aiken, 354 S.C. 18, 22, 579 S.E.2d 334, 336
  (Ct. App. 2003); Smith v. S.C. Ins. Co., 350 S.C. 82, 87, 564 S.E.2d 358,
  361 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Gordon v. Phillips Utils., Inc.,
  362 S.C. 403, 406, 608 S.E.2d 425, 427 (2005) (â€œThe primary purpose in
  construing a statute is to ascertain legislative intent.â€).Â  All rules of
  statutory construction are subservient to the one that legislative intent must
  prevail if it can be reasonably discovered in the language used, and that
  language must be construed in the light of the intended purpose of the statute.
  Â McClanahan v. Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 438, 567 S.E.2d
  240, 242 (2002); Ray Bell Constr. Co. v. Sch. Dist. of Greenville County,
  331 S.C. 19, 26, 501 S.E.2d 725, 729 (1998); State v. Morgan, 352 S.C.
  359, 365-66, 574 S.E.2d 203, 206 (Ct. App. 2002); State v. Hudson, 336
  S.C. 237, 246, 519 S.E.2d 577, 581 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œOnce the legislature has
  made [a] choice, there is no room for the courts to impose a different judgment
  based upon their own notions of public policy.â€ Â S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins.
    Co. v. Mumford, 299 S.C. 14, 19, 382 S.E.2d 11, 14 (Ct. App. 1989).
The
  legislatureâ€™s intent should be ascertained primarily from the plain language of
  the statute. Â State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 102, 606 S.E.2d 503, 505
  (Ct. App. 2004); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Stephen
    v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 339, 478 S.E.2d 74, 77 (Ct. App.
  1996).Â  The language must be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject
  matter and accords with its general purpose.Â  Mun. Assâ€™n of S.C. v. AT &
    T Commcâ€™ns of S. States, Inc., 361 S.C. 576, 580, 606 S.E.2d 468, 470
  (2004); Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178,
  420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Hudson, 336 S.C. at 246, 519 S.E.2d at 582. Â 
When a
  statuteâ€™s terms are clear and unambiguous on their face, there is no room for
  statutory construction and a court must apply the statute according to its
  literal meaning. Â Miller v. Aiken, 364 S.C. 303, 307, 613 S.E.2d 364,
  366 (2005); Carolina Power & Light Co. v. City of Bennettsville, 314
  S.C. 137, 139, 442 S.E.2d 177, 179 (1994).Â  If a statuteâ€™s language is
  unambiguous and clear, there is no need to employ the rules of statutory
  construction and this Court has no right to look for or impose another meaning.
  Â Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 373, 585 S.E.2d 292, 298
  (2003); Paschal v. State Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 436, 454 S.E.2d
  890, 892 (1995); see also City of Camden v. Brassell, 326 S.C.
  556, 561, 486 S.E.2d 492, 495 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œWhere the language of the
  statute is clear and explicit, the court cannot rewrite the statute and inject matters
  into it which are not in the legislatureâ€™s language.â€). Â What a legislature
  says in the text of a statute is considered the best evidence of the
  legislative intent or will. Â Bayle v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C.
  115, 122, 542 S.E.2d 736, 740 (Ct. App. 2001). Â The words of a statute must be
  given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced
  construction. Â Durham v. United Cos. Fin. Corp., 331 S.C. 600,
  604, 503 S.E.2d 465, 468 (1998); Adkins v. Comcar Indus., Inc., 323 S.C.
  409, 411, 475 S.E.2d 762, 763 (1996); Worsley Cos. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health
    & Envtl. Control, 351 S.C. 97, 102, 567 S.E.2d 907, 910 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Timmons v. S.C. Tricentennial Commâ€™n, 254 S.C. 378, 402,
  175 S.E.2d 805, 817 (1970) (observing that where the language of the statute is
  clear and explicit, the court cannot rewrite the statute and inject matters
  into it that are not in the legislatureâ€™s language). Â Under the plain meaning
  rule, it is not the courtâ€™s place to change the meaning of a clear and
  unambiguous statute. Â Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578,
  581 (2000); Bayle, 344 S.C. at 122, 542 S.E.2d at 739.Â   
If the
  language of an act gives rise to doubt or uncertainty as to legislative intent,
  the construing court may search for that intent beyond the borders of the act
  itself. Â Morgan, 352 S.C. at 367, 574 S.E.2d at 207; see also Wade
    v. Berkeley County, 348 S.C. 224, 229, 559 S.E.2d 586, 588 (2002) (â€œ[W]here
  a statute is ambiguous, the Court must construe the terms of the statute.â€). Â An
  ambiguity in a statute should be resolved in favor of a just, beneficial, and
  equitable operation of the law. Â Hudson, 336 S.C. at 247, 519 S.E.2d at
  582; Brassell, 326 S.C. at 561, 486 S.E.2d at 495; City of Sumter Police Depâ€™t v. One (1) 1992 Blue Mazda Truck, 330 S.C. 371, 376, 498 S.E.2d 894,
  896 (Ct. App. 1998). Â In construing a statute, the court looks to the language
  as a whole in light of its manifest purpose. Â State v. Dawkins, 352 S.C.
  162, 166, 573 S.E.2d 783, 785 (2002); Adams v. Texfi Indus., 320
  S.C. 213, 217, 464 S.E.2d 109, 112 (1995); Brassell, 326 S.C. at 560,
  486 S.E.2d at 494.
A
  statute as a whole must receive a practical, reasonable, and fair
  interpretation consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of the lawmakers.
  Â See Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. S.C. Second Injury Fund, 363
  S.C. 612, 621, 611 S.E.2d 297, 301 (Ct. App. 2005), cert. denied, June
  2007; see also Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, 354 S.C. at 22, 579
  S.E.2d at 336 (â€œA statute should be given a reasonable and practical
  construction consistent with the purpose and policy expressed in the
  statute.â€). Â The real purpose and intent of the lawmakers will prevail over the
  literal import of the words.Â  Browning v. Hartvigsen, 307 S.C. 122, 125,
  414 S.E.2d 115, 117 (1992).
Courts
  will reject a statutory interpretation which would lead to a result so plainly
  absurd that it could not have been intended by the legislature or would defeat
  the plain legislative intention. Â Unisun Ins. Co. v. Schmidt, 339 S.C.
  362, 368, 529 S.E.2d 280, 283 (2000); Kiriakides v. United Artists Commcâ€™ns,
    Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 275, 440 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1994). Â A court should not
  consider a particular clause in a statute as being construed in isolation, but
  should read it in conjunction with the purpose of the whole statute and the
  policy of the law.Â  See Liberty Mut. Ins. Co., 363 S.C. at
  622, 611 S.E.2d at 302; see also Mid-State Auto Auction v. Altman,
  324 S.C. 65, 69, 476 S.E.2d 690, 692 (1996) (stating that in ascertaining the
  intent of the legislature, a court should not focus on any single section or
  provision but should consider the language of the statute as a whole).
LAW/ANALYSIS


Grinnell
  and American Home argue the offer of additional UM and UIM was a meaningful
  offer, and concomitantly the circuit court erred in reforming the policy.Â  We
  disagree.Â   
In
  addition to mandatory UM coverage, automobile insurance carriers must offer the
  insured additional UM and UIM coverage.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 (2002).

	Automobile
  insurance carriers shall offer, at the option of the insured, uninsured motorist
  coverage up to the limits of the insured's liability coverage in addition to
  the mandatory coverage prescribed by Section 38-77-150. Such carriers shall
  also offer, at the option of the insured, underinsured motorist coverage up to
  the limits of the insured liability coverage to provide coverage in the event
  that damages are sustained in excess of the liability limits carried by an
  at-fault insured or underinsured motorist or in excess of any damages cap or
  limitation imposed by statute. . . .

Id.Â  â€œThe purpose of requiring automobile insurers to
  make a meaningful offer of additional UM or UIM coverage â€˜is for insureds to
  know their options and to make an informed decision as to which amount of
  coverage will best suit their needs.â€™â€Â  Floyd v.
    Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 367 S.C. 253, 262-263, 626 S.E.2d 6,
  12 (2005) (citing Progressive Cas. Ins. Co. v. Leachman, 362
  S.C. 344, 352, 608 S.E.2d 569, 573 (2005)).
An
  offer of additional UM and UIM â€œmust be an effective offer that is meaningful
  to the insured.â€Â  Todd v. Federated Mut. Ins. Co., 305 S.C. 395, 398,
  409 S.E.2d 361, 364 (1991) (citing Dewart v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co.,
  296 S.C. 150, 370 S.E.2d 915 (Ct. App. 1988)).Â  â€œA noncomplying offer has the
  legal effect of no offer at all.â€Â  Progressive, 362
  S.C. at 349, 608 S.E.2d at 571.Â  Hanover Ins. Co. v. Horace Mann Ins. Co., 301 S.C. 55, 57, 389 S.E.2d
  657, 659 (1990).Â  â€œIf the insurer fails to comply with its statutory duty to
  make a meaningful offer to the insured, the policy will be reformed, by
  operation of law, to include UIM coverage up to the limits of liability insurance
  carried by the insured.â€ Butler v. Unisun Ins. Co., 323 S.C. 402,
  405, 475 S.E.2d 758, 760 (1996).Â  Burch v. South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut.
    Ins. Co., 351 S.C. 342, 345, 569 S.E.2d 400, 402 (Ct. App. 2002).
The
  Supreme Court of South Carolina adopted a four-part test for determining the
  sufficiency of an offer of additional UM and UIM in State Farm Mutual Auto.
    Ins. Co. v. Wannamaker, 291 S.C. 518, 521, 354 S.E.2d 555, 556 (1987).Â  The court elucidated that an offer of additional UM and
  UIM coverage is meaningful if:

	(1) the
  insurerâ€™s notification process is commercially reasonable, whether oral or in
  writing; (2) the insurer must specify the limits of optional coverage and not
  merely offer additional coverage in general terms; (3) the insurer must intelligibly
  advise the insured of the nature of the optional coverage; and (4) the insured must
  be told that optional coverages are available for an additional premium.

Id.; Progressive 362 S.C. at 349, 608 S.E.2d at
  571.Â  â€œThe insurer must satisfy all four prongs of the Wannamaker test
  to prove there was an effective offer of underinsured motorist coverage, and
  failure of any one of these prongs vitiates the offer and requires reformation
  of the policy to include underinsured motorist coverage to the limits of
  liability.â€ Ackerman v. Travelers Indem. Co., 318 S.C. 137, 144,
  456 S.E.2d 408, 411 (Ct. App. 1995) (citing Dewart 296 S.C.
  150, 370 S.E.2d 915). Â â€œThe insurer bears
  the burden of establishing that it made a meaningful offer.â€Â  Progressive 362 S.C. at 348-49, 608 S.E.2d at 571.Â  Butler, 323 S.C. at 405, 475
  S.E.2d at 759.
In
  response to the Wannamaker decision, the legislature passed section
  38-77-350, which establishes the requirements for forms used in making offers
  of optional insurance coverages.Â  Progressive, 362 S.C. at 349, 608
  S.E.2d at 571.Â  â€œ[W]hen enacting section 38-77-350, the Legislature did not
  intend to repeal section 38-77-160.â€Â  Butler, 323 S.C. at 407, 475
  S.E.2d at 761.Â  Section 38-77-350 (A) states:

	The
  director or his designee shall approve a form that automobile insurers shall
  use in offering optional coverages required to be offered pursuant to law to
  applicants for automobile insurance policies. This form must be used by
  insurers for all new applicants.Â  The form, at a minimum, must provide for each
  optional coverage required to be offered:
	(1) a
  brief and concise explanation of the coverage,
	(2) a
  list of available limits and the range of premiums for the limits,
	(3) a
  space for the insured to mark whether the insured chooses to accept or reject
  the coverage and a space for the insured to select the limits of coverage he
  desires,
	(4) a
  space for the insured to sign the form which acknowledges that he has been
  offered the optional coverages,
	(5) the
  mailing address and telephone number of the Insurance Department which the
  applicant may contact if the applicant has any questions that the insurance
  agent is unable to answer.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-350(A) (2002).Â   
If
  the insurerâ€™s form complies with these requirements, section 38-77-350(B) provides
  a conclusive presumption.

	If this
  form is properly completed and executed by the named insured it is conclusively
  presumed that there was an informed, knowing selection of coverage and neither
  the insurance company nor any insurance agent has any liability to the named
  insured or any other insured under the policy for the insuredâ€™s failure to
  purchase any option coverages or higher limits.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-350(B) (2002)[1].Â 
  â€œIf the form does not comply with the statute, the insurer may not benefit from
  the protections of the statute.â€ Progressive, 362 S.C. at 349, 608
  S.E.2d at 572 (citing Osborne v. Allstate Ins. Co., 319 S.C. 479,
  486, 462 S.E.2d 291, 295 (Ct. App. 1995)).Â   
Grinnell
  concedes the offer form fails to meet the requirements of section 38-77-350(A),
  so the conclusive presumption of section 38-77-350(B) does not apply.Â  An insurerâ€™s
  failure to comply with section 38-77-350 does not necessarily presage the lack
  of a meaningful offer.Â  See Butler 323 S.C. 402, 475
  S.E.2d 758.Â  The insurer still has an
  opportunity to prove an offer is meaningful under the requirements of Wannamaker.Â Â  See Antley, 350 S.C. at 633, 567 S.E.2d at 878.Â  â€œWhether a
  meaningful offer was made depends on the facts and circumstances of a
  particular case.â€Â  Croft v. Old Republic Ins. Co., 365 S.C. 402, 420,
  618 S.E.2d 909, 918 (2005).Â   
Grinnell
  and American Home assert that while the offer form fails to meet the requirements
  of 38-77-350(A), the offer form still meets the requirements of Wannamaker.Â 
  We disagree.
It
  is axiomatic that a form which fails under the requirements of section 38-77-350(A)
  would not meet the requirements of Wannamaker without evidence outside
  of the offer form.Â  Section 38-77-350(A) sets forth the minimum requirements of
  a form offering optional coverage.Â  Butler 323 S.C. at 408, 475 S.E.2d
  at 761.Â  â€œ[A] form does not necessarily constitute a meaningful offer simply
  because it was approved by the Department of Insurance.â€Â  Floyd, 367
  S.C. at 262, 626 S.E.2d at 12.Â  To meet its burden of proof, an insurer must
  provide evidence outside of the offer form itself to prove satisfaction of the Wannamaker test.Â Â Â Â  
 
An illustration
  of this principle can be seen in McDowell v. Travelers Property & Casualty
    Company, 357 S.C. 118, 590 S.E.2d 514  (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In McDowell an employee sought reformation of his employerâ€™s policy on the ground that
  there was not a meaningful offer of additional UM and UIM coverage.Â  Id.Â  This court conducted a Wannamaker analysis after concluding the offer
  form did not meet the requirements of section 38-77-350(A).Â  Id.Â  We
  ruled the insurer had made a meaningful offer because the contract between the
  parties provided the necessary information which was missing from the offer
  form.Â  Id. at 124, 590 S.E.2d at 517 (â€œMcDowellâ€™s only contention under
  the Wannamaker analysis is that Travelers failed to provide the premium
  amounts for the optional UIM coverage. Although the offer form contained no
  premium amounts in the blanks provided, the contractual agreement between
  Goodyear and Travelers includes a detailed formula for calculating the premium
  for UIM coverage.â€).Â  Essentially, the contract â€œcuredâ€ the offer formâ€™s
  insufficiency.Â  However, without the contract, the insurer would not have
  provided the necessary information.  
The
  present case is distinguishable from McDowell.Â  In McDowell, the sole deficiency was the
  offer formâ€™s failure to provide premium amounts.Â  Id.Â  This court
  determined the offer was still meaningful under Wannamaker because
  premiums could be established from the partiesâ€™ contract.Â  Id.Â  In the case sub judice, the offer form had several shortcomings;
  there is no evidence American Home cured these defects by providing the
  necessary information in some other way.Â   
While
  the form stated that additional coverage was available up to the policy limits, the actual offers of optional coverages printed on the form were for
  amounts far less that the $5,000,000 policy limit.Â  The increased premium charges
  were left blank even though the form itself states that they must be completed.Â 
  The form had been filled out to state that â€œSingle Limit[s]â€ of additional
  coverage were selected, which is clearly inconsistent with a denial of
  additional coverage.Â  Lastly, the form required signatures next to the
  boxes where the insured elects not to choose optional coverage, but no one
  signed those blanks.
To
  illustrate the offer form was a meaningful offer, Grinnell and American Home
  point to evidence of Grinnellâ€™s level of sophistication and understanding of UM
  and UIM insurance coverage.

	[E]vidence
  of the insureds [sic] knowledge or level of sophistication is relevant and
  admissible when analyzing, under Wannamaker, whether an insurer
  intelligibly advised the insured of the nature of the optional UM or UIM
  coverage. It is a subjective inquiry to the extent the insured may offer
  evidence of his understanding, or lack thereof, of the nature of UM or UIM
  coverage. It also is an objective inquiry because the factfinder should
  consider the insureds [sic] knowledge and level
  of sophistication in determining whether the insurer intelligibly explained
  such coverage to the insured.

Croft v. Old Republic Ins.
  Co., 365 S.C. 402, 420-21, 618 S.E.2d
  909, 918 (2005).
Some
  of the omissions in the offer form cannot be reconciled regardless of how
  sophisticated the insured may be.Â  For example, the actual offers of optional
  coverages were for amounts far less than the $5,000,000 policy limit, and the
  form had been filled out to state that â€œSingle Limit[s]â€ of additional coverage
  were selected.Â  Such serious errors may not be mitigated by the insuredâ€™s stature.Â 
  The sophistication level of the insured, while relevant to the sufficiency of
  the advice given by the insurer, does not completely relax the requirement that
  an insurer make a meaningful offer of additional UM and UIM coverage. Indeed,
  insurers are required to make a meaningful offer to even the most sophisticated
  parties because â€œthe Legislature has
  recognized that commercial insureds, like non-commercial insureds, undoubtedly
  run the gamut from the ill-informed to knowledgeable purchasers.â€Â  Id. atÂ  420, 618 S.E.2d at 918.
CONCLUSION
We hold
  that American Home did not make a meaningful offer of additional UM and UIM.Â  We
  rule the circuit court properly reformed the policy of insurance to include UM
  and UIM coverage in the amount of the policy limits.Â   
Accordingly, the order of the
  circuit court is
AFFIRMED.Â  
THOMAS,
  J., concurs.Â  
SHORT,
  J., dissents in a separate opinion.
SHORT, J.,
  (dissenting):Â  I respectfully dissent.
The majority
  opinion distinguishes the facts and circumstances of this case from those in
  this courtâ€™s opinion in McDowell v. Travelers Property & Casualty
    Company, 357 S.C. 118, 590 S.E.2d 514 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  I conclude McDowell applies and would reverse the trial courtâ€™s reformation of the partiesâ€™
  contract.
In McDowell,
  this court found a meaningful offer despite the failure of the offer form to
  meet the Wannamaker test.Â  Id.Â  See State Farm Mut.
    Auto. Ins. Co. v. Wannamaker, 291 S.C. 518, 521, 354 S.E.2d 555, 556 (1987)
  (adopting a four-part test for determining the sufficiency of an offer of
  optional UM and UIM).Â  The court noted that failure to meet the statutory
  requirements â€œdoes not necessarily require reformation of the policy.Â  Rather,
  the insurer bears the burden of establishing it made a meaning offer. . . .â€Â  McDowell,
  357 S.C. at 123, 590 S.E.2d at 516.Â  I find the insurer met that burden in this
  case.
In the typical
  case, the insured is the party seeking reformation.Â Â  This case presents the
  more unusual circumstance of the insured arguing the offer was meaningful and a
  third party seeking reformation.Â  Under the partiesâ€™ payment agreement, Tyco is
  essentially self-insured for the first $500,000 of a claim.Â  Gerald Goetz, the
  Vice President of Risk Management for Tyco, clarified the valid business
  purpose for denying optional UM and UIM.Â  Goetz explained that Tyco would not
  have bought additional UM and UIM because doing so would expose it to
  additional liability.Â  Gerald Goetz asserted he was knowledgeable and aware of
  his options when declining additional UM and UIM.Â  Goetz had worked in the
  insurance industry as a risk manager for over thirty years and had extensive
  education relating to risk management.Â   
I
  would find Goetz made a knowing and informed decision in rejecting the optional
  coverage.Â  See id. at 124-25, 590 S.E.2d at 517 (finding the risk
  manager made a knowing and informed decision).Â  Furthermore, like the court in McDowell,
  I would consider the arrangement between the contracting parties in this case
  and conclude the insurer met its burden of proving it made a meaningful offer
  to Tyco.Â  Moreover, Goetzâ€™s sophistication is a factor to consider in
  determining whether Tyco received a meaningful offer.Â  See Anders v.
    S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 307 S.C. 371, 376, 415 S.E.2d 406, 409 (Ct.
  App. 1992) (finding the sophistication of the insured is a factor that may be
  considered in determining if an offer of optional insurance is meaningful).Â  
 
Although
  this offer may not have been meaningful to the typical insured, under these
  circumstances, considering the sophistication of the insured, I find the offer
  meaningful.Â  See Croft v. Old Republic Ins. Co., 365 S.C. 402,
  420, 618 S.E.2d 909, 918 (2005) (stating â€œ[w]hether a meaningful offer was
  made depends on the facts and circumstances of a particular caseâ€).Â 
  Accordingly, I would reverse.

  it was executed on July 1, 1999.

      Morgan, Appellant,
				v.
				South Carolina Budget and Control Board and South Carolina Retirement Systems, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Administrative Law Court
Marvin F. Kittrell
Opinion No. 4356
Heard February 5, 2008 â€“ Filed March 13,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				William E. Whitney, Jr., of Union, for Appellant.
				Kelly H. Rainsford and David K. Avant, both of Columbia, for
  Respondents.
			
		
	

CURETON, A.J.:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In
  this action to determine the cost to purchase non-qualified service credit
  (Non-Qualified Service) under South Carolina Retirement Systems (Retirement
  Systems), E. Bruce Morgan appeals the order of the Administrative Law Court
  (ALC) requiring the purchase price to be calculated based on Morganâ€™s highest
  salary.Â  We affirm.Â   
FACTS
From 1982 to 1991, Morgan worked for the State of South Carolina and earned eight years of service credit in Retirement Systems.Â  Morgan
  later withdrew these contributions.Â  From 1991 to 1997, Morgan worked for the
  State of North Carolina and earned public service credit toward his retirement
  account (N.C. Public Service).Â  Morgan rejoined Retirement Systems in November
  2000 when he became Mayor of the City of Union, South Carolina.Â   
In 2004, Morgan sought to increase his service credit in
  Retirement Systems.Â  On August 20, 2004, Morgan submitted a request to
  Retirement Systems to purchase credit for his N.C. Public Service and
  additional credit equal to the amount he had previously earned between 1982 and
  1991 for his South Carolina service, but had later withdrawn (Withdrawal
  Service).Â  Retirement Systems acknowledged receipt of his request and informed
  him processing might take up to ninety days.Â  On October 4, 2004, Retirement
  Systems notified Morgan he could purchase Withdrawal Service credit for
  $18,995.95 until April 2, 2005.Â  After Retirement Systems received verification
  of Morganâ€™s N.C. Public Service, it notified Morgan he could purchase N.C. Public
  Service credit for $35,562.91 until April 16, 2005.Â   
Soon thereafter, Morgan visited Retirement Systems in person to
  discuss how it had calculated the price of his N.C. Public Service credit.Â 
  During this visit, Morgan also inquired about purchasing Non-Qualified Service
  credit.Â  Retirement Systems informed Morgan it had based the price of his
  Public Service credit on the $33,592.00 salary indicated in the Withdrawal
  Service invoice.Â  Furthermore, Retirement Systems advised Morgan if he elected
  not to buy Withdrawal Service first, it could recalculate the purchase price of
  his Public Service credit and Non-Qualified Service credit using his
  then-current salary of $6,610.00.Â  Retirement Systems stated Morgan could
  purchase up to five years of Non-Qualified Service based on the $6,610.00 salary.Â 
  Retirement Systems did not advise Morgan he was currently not qualified to purchase
  Non-Qualified Service.[1]Â  
 
Subsequently, Morgan submitted a written request to purchase
  Non-Qualified Service credit and N.C. Public Service credit based on the $6,610.00
  salary.Â  Morganâ€™s letter specified he would purchase Withdrawal Service credit
  later.Â  Pursuant to this letter, Retirement Systems recalculated the price of
  Morganâ€™s N.C. Public Service credit as $6,998.03.Â  The October 28, 2004,
  invoice for Morganâ€™s N.C. Public Service credit included a postscript
  indicating â€œyou are not eligible to purchase non qualified service until you
  have reached 5 years of earned service.â€Â  Four weeks later, Morgan purchased
  N.C. Public Service credit from Retirement Systems. Â 
On November 29, 2004, Morgan again called Retirement Systems,
  which erroneously advised him he could purchase Non-Qualified Service credit
  after his N.C. Public Service credit purchase posted.Â  Nine days later,
  Retirement Systems corrected this error by advising Morgan he must have five
  years of earned service before he could purchase Non-Qualified Service credit.Â 
  Morgan stated he would first purchase his Withdrawal Service credit, which
  would satisfy the earned-service requirement, and would later submit his
  request to purchase Non-Qualified Service credit.Â  However, instead of
  purchasing Withdrawal Service credit first, Morgan visited Retirement Systems
  and requested to purchase Non-Qualified Service credit.Â  Despite the fact
  Morgan had already completed the purchase of N.C. Public Service credit,
  Retirement Systems instructed Morgan to complete a new written request to
  purchase that credit, and he did so.Â   
On
  December 14, 2004, Morgan called Retirement Systems and inquired whether he
  could purchase just enough Withdrawal Service credit to make him eligible to
  purchase Non-Qualified Service credit.Â  Retirement Systems informed him he
  could do so, but if he did, he would be unable to purchase the remainder of his
  Withdrawal Service until the following fiscal year.[2]Â 
  Morgan submitted a written request to Retirement Systems to purchase Withdrawal
  Service credit, providing Retirement Systems with information about the Smith
  Barney IRA account he intended to use to fund the purchase.Â  Two weeks later,
  Retirement Systems notified Morgan the information he had provided was
  insufficient because it failed to indicate whether the Smith Barney IRA
  consisted of pretax funds.Â  On January 10, 2005, Morgan started a new state job
  at a career-high salary of $89,000.00. Â 
Morgan did not contact Retirement Systems again until February 7,
  2005, when he inquired about purchasing Withdrawal Service credit using
  rollover funds from his Wachovia account.Â  In March 2005, Morgan purchased
  Withdrawal Service credit pursuant to the October 4, 2004, invoice using funds
  from a different account than before.Â  Thereafter, Retirement Systems informed
  Morgan that Wachovia had overpaid, and Morgan requested Retirement Systems
  apply the overpayment to his purchase of Non-Qualified Service credit.Â  When Morgan
  learned the cost, he declined to purchase the Non-Qualified Service credit.Â  On
  April 21, 2005, Retirement Systems refunded the overpayment to Wachovia for deposit
  in Morganâ€™s account.Â   
In May 2005, with no other service available for Morgan to
  purchase, Retirement Systems confirmed the cost of Non-Qualified Service credit
  as $155,750.00, based on his $89,000.00 salary.Â  Morgan appealed in a letter to
  the Director of Retirement Systems.Â  Retirement Systems issued a final agency
  determination confirming $155,750.00 as the cost of Morganâ€™s Non-Qualified
  Service credit.Â  Morgan contested and requested the ALC hear this matter.Â  The
  ALC affirmed Retirement Systemsâ€™ final agency determination.Â  This appeal
  followed.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Review
  of a decision by the ALC is confined to the record.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§
  1-23-380(A)(4), 1-23-610(C) (Supp. 2006). Â â€œThe findings of the agency are
  presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial
  evidence.â€Â  Kearse v. State Health & Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 318
  S.C. 198, 200, 456 S.E.2d 892, 893 (1995).Â  â€œâ€˜Substantial evidenceâ€™ is not a
  mere scintilla of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the
  case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow
  reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached
  or must have reached in order to justify its action.â€Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc.,
  276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Morgan
  argues the ALC erred in declining to estop Retirement Systems from calculating
  the cost of Morganâ€™s Non-Qualified Service credit using his current,
  career-high salary because Retirement Systemsâ€™ misinformation and delays
  prevented Morgan from completing his purchase before his salary increased.Â  We
  disagree.Â   
Under
  South Carolina law, active members of Retirement Systems may establish
  service credit for public service, non-qualified service, and previously
  withdrawn service by making payments into the system.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  9-1-1140 (Supp. 2007).Â  Furthermore:Â   

	An
  active member who has five or more years of earned service credit may establish
  up to five years of nonqualified service by making a payment to the system to
  be determined by the board, but not less than thirty-five percent of the
  memberâ€™s current salary or career highest fiscal year salary, whichever is
  greater, for each year of credit purchased.Â  

Â§ 9-1-1140(E).Â  Of the three
  types of purchasable service credit listed above, only previously withdrawn
  service credit may substitute for earned service.Â  Â§ 9-1-1140(J).Â   
Misrepresentations
  by government officials acting within the proper scope of their authority may
  subject the government to estoppel.Â  McCrowey v. Zoning Bd. of Adjustment of
    City of Rock Hill, 360 S.C. 301, 305-06, 599 S.E.2d 617, 619 (Ct. App.
  2004) (citing S.C. Coastal Council v. Vogel, 292 S.C. 449, 453, 357
  S.E.2d 187, 189 (Ct. App. 1987)).Â  However, estoppel is not appropriate where a
  government official or employee with limited authority erroneously provides
  advice beyond the scope of his authority.Â  McCrowey, 360 S.C. at 305,
  599 S.E.2d at 619 (citing DeStefano v. City of Charleston, 304 S.C. 250,
  257-58, 403 S.E.2d 648, 653 (1991)).Â  Estoppel will not lie against a
  government entity where a government employee gives erroneous information in
  contradiction of statute.Â  Office of Personnel Management v. Richmond, 496 U.S. 414, 415-16 (1990).Â  Simply stated, equity follows the law.Â  Smith
    v. Barr, 375 S.C. 157, 164, 650 S.E.2d 486, 490 (Ct. App. 2007).Â   
Estoppel
  based on erroneous advice is inappropriate under the facts of this case.Â  Retirement
  Systems administers South Carolinaâ€™s state-employee retirement plans.Â 
  Providing plan members with correct information concerning their rights and benefits
  is therefore within Retirement Systemsâ€™ purview.Â  Morgan argues Retirement
  Systems misled him concerning his eligibility to purchase Non-Qualified Service.Â 
  However, eligibility to purchase service credit is purely statutory.Â 
  Retirement Systems had no discretion to determine an individual memberâ€™s
  eligibility and thus lacked authority to contradict the statute.Â  Therefore,
  estoppel is improper here under both McCrowey and Richmond.Â  
 
Morgan
  further argues Retirement Systems should be estopped because Retirement
  Systemsâ€™ delays in processing his requests for service credit prevented him
  from effecting the purchases before his salary increased.Â  The doctrine of equitable estoppel may be enforced in
  a court of law as well as in equity
  matters.â€Â  Strickland v. Strickland, 375 S.C. 76, 85, 650 S.E.2d 465,
  471 (2007).Â  â€œThe party asserting estoppel bears the burden of establishing all
  its elements.â€Â  Estes v. Roper Temp. Servs., 304 S.C. 120, 122,
  403 S.E.2d 157, 158 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  A government entity may be equitably
  estopped in matters that do not affect the due exercise of its police power or
  the application of public policy.Â  Grant v. City of Folly Beach, 346 S.C. 74, 80, 551 S.E.2d 229, 232 (2001).Â  Estoppel may apply against a
  government agency.Â  Id. Â A party asserting estoppel against the
  government must prove â€œ(1) lack of knowledge and of the means of knowledge of
  the truth as to the facts in question, (2) justifiable reliance upon the
  governmentâ€™s conduct, and (3) a prejudicial change in position.â€Â  Id.Â  Absent even one element, estoppel will
  not lie against a government entity.Â  Id. Â However, citizens are presumed to know the law and are charged with exercising â€œreasonable care to
  protect [their] interest[s].â€Â  Smothers v. U.S. Fidelity and Guar. Co.,
  322 S.C. 207, 210-11, 470 S.E.2d 858, 860 (Ct. App. 1996).Â   
Morganâ€™s
  estoppel argument fails on the first two elements.Â  First, Morgan argues he
  lacked knowledge because Retirement Systems misled him as to the truth of his
  situation by failing to inform him he could purchase Non-Qualified Service
  credit only after he purchased Withdrawal Service credit.Â  Furthermore, Morgan
  argues Retirement Systems improperly encouraged him to apply to purchase
  Non-Qualified Service credit immediately after his purchase of N.C. Public
  Service credit posted.Â  However, section 9-1-1140 clearly outlines eligibility
  requirements for each type of service.[3]Â 
  Therefore, Morgan had the means to discern for himself whether he was eligible
  to purchase service credit, and thus, he failed to satisfy the first element.Â  
 
For
  the second element, justifiable reliance, Morgan argues he missed his
  â€œdeadlineâ€ because he relied on Retirement Systems to guide him and process his
  requests timely, but Retirement Systems instead misinformed him and caused
  delays.Â  However, Retirement Systems misinformed Morgan on only one occasion,
  correcting its error within nine days.Â  No evidence suggests Morgan acted on
  this misinformation until after Retirement Systems had correctly informed him
  of the need to purchase Withdrawal Service credit first.[4]Â 
  Furthermore, no evidence suggests Retirement Systems was aware of any
  â€œdeadline.â€Â  Retirement Systems noted Morgan was confident he would be
  re-elected as mayor and wanted to purchase additional service before he got a
  â€œreal job.â€ Â However, we do not find these notations sufficient to establish
  Retirement Systems knew Morganâ€™s salary would increase significantly on January
  10, 2005.Â  Rather, Retirement Systems appears to have handled a multitude of
  Morganâ€™s requests, both for information and for action, in a reasonably timely
  manner.Â  Lacking any evidence he justifiably relied on the misinformation, Morgan
  failed to satisfy the second element as well.Â   
For
  the final element, a prejudicial change in position, the record reflects
  Morganâ€™s salary increase permanently raised his cost of purchasing additional
  service credit.Â  This element alone is satisfied.Â  However, without all three
  elements, Morganâ€™s estoppel argument fails.Â   
Equitable
  estoppel against a government entity requires successful proof of all three
  elements.Â  Morgan successfully proved a prejudicial change in position, but he
  failed to prove either lack of knowledge or justifiable reliance.Â  Therefore,
  estoppel against Retirement Systems is inappropriate in this matter.Â   
CONCLUSION
Retirement
  Systems should not be estopped from using Morganâ€™s January 10, 2005, salary to
  calculate the cost of Non-Qualified Service credit, because Morgan fails to
  satisfy two of the three required elements for estoppel against a government
  entity.Â  Morgan has proved neither lack of knowledge nor justifiable reliance.Â 
  Without proving all three elements, Morgan is not entitled to estoppel.Â 
  Accordingly, the order of the ALC is  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and PIEPER, J., concur.

[1] It appears Retirement Systems was unaware at this
  time that Morganâ€™s salary would increase within a few months.Â  Had Morgan
  declined to purchase Withdrawal Service credit, Retirement Systems could not
  have used his former career-high salary of $33,592 to calculate the purchase
  price of other types of credit.Â  Consequently, had Morgan continued to work at
  the $6,610.00 salary until he earned five years of retirement credit,
  Retirement Systems could have calculated the cost of Non-Qualified Service
  credit using his $6,610.00 salary.Â   
[2] See S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-1140(K).Â   
[3] Morgan attempts to analogize Landing Dev. Corp. v.
  City of Myrtle Beach, 285 S.C. 216, 329 S.E.2d 423 (1985), in which
  estoppel was appropriate where an individual had relied upon the Cityâ€™s
  consistent but improper representations concerning a zoning ordinance, and the
  City later sought to enforce the ordinance.Â  However, that case is
  distinguishable from the one at bar because Morgan at all times had the ability
  to review the statute for himself.Â  Moreover, no evidence indicates Retirement
  Systems consistently misinterpreted the statute.Â   
[4] Morgan often
  repeats Retirement Systemsâ€™ statement, â€œYou will not be penalized due to our
  delay.â€Â  A reasonable person might expect this statement to preclude Retirement
  Systems from imposing any late-filing penalties due to processing delays.Â 
  However, Morgan seems to interpret it as an unlimited promise by Retirement
  Systems to indemnify him against any and all changes that might occur during
  the pendency of his request, including those changes within his control.Â  We
  disagree with this view.Â  Morgan undoubtedly knew the effective date and amount
  of his new salary and had the power to decline to accept it.Â  He elected to
  accept it in spite of any consequences to his cost of purchasing retirement
  credit.Â
