THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Gary Robert
      Moore, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4357
Submitted January 1, 2008 â€“ Filed March
  13, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and
  Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PIEPER, J.:  Appellant Gary Robert Moore (Moore) was convicted of
  felony driving under the influence and leaving the scene of an accident
  involving death. Moore asserts the trial court erred in refusing to suppress
  evidence removed from his brotherâ€™s truck because the search exceeded the scope
  of consent. He also asserts the trial court erred in failing to declare a mistrial
  when the solicitor implied that Moore had an affirmative duty to modify his
  statement to police.Â  We affirm.[1]
STATEMENT OF FACTS
On the night of
  October 19, 2002, and into the early morning of October 20, 2002, a truck driving
  on Highway 17 in Horry County hit a pedestrian walking on the median and drove
  off. Police investigated this traffic fatality, received a witness report
  describing the vehicle involved, collected remaining parts of the car from the
  scene of the crime, and notified news media.Â  Thereafter, an off duty officer
  reported a truck with a matching description and called in its tag number. Â Officers
  then used that tag number and went to the home of Moore and his brother. Â Both Moore and his brother were informed of the hit
  and run incident and were asked by the police to give consent to process the vehicle. Mooreâ€™s brother notified the
  police that the he owned the truck but that Moore typically drove it.Â  Both
  brothers consented verbally and in writing to allow processing of the truck by
  the South Carolina Highway Patrol. Â In an abundance of caution, a search
  warrant was obtained before taking parts off the vehicle. Â That warrant was
  challenged as defective at trial; however, the state indicated to the court
  that it was proceeding on its theory of consent and the efficacy of the search
  warrant was never addressed by the trial court.Â  Moore concedes on appeal that
  the search warrant issue is not preserved for our review.[2]
When processing was
  completed on the vehicle, parts were missing and the battery had been removed
  and placed in the bed of the truck. The truck was inoperable at that point and
  had to be towed for return. Â Because of these actions, Moore asserts the
  officers exceeded the scope of any consent given.Â  Mooreâ€™s motion to suppress
  the evidence was denied by the trial court.
At trial, Moore also asserted that the solicitor improperly commented on his constitutional right to
  remain silent by suggesting the defendant had a duty to contact the police to
  correct a mistake in his statement to the police.Â  The trial court denied the
  motion and gave a cautionary instruction to the jury.
From these rulings,
  the defendant now appeals.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€ State
    v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001). The appellate
  court â€œis bound by the trial court's factual findings unless they are clearly
  erroneous.â€ State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 452, 527 S.E.2d
  105, 111 (2000). The appellate court â€œdoes not re-evaluate the facts based on
  its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether
  the trial judge's ruling is supported by any evidence.â€ Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.
ANALYSIS
I
Did the trial court err by
  denying Mooreâ€™s motion to suppress based on the allegation that investigating
  officers exceeded the scope of consent by removing parts of the truck and
  returning it in an inoperable condition?
â€œThe
  admission of evidence is within the discretion of the trial court and will not
  be reversed absent an abuse of discretion.â€ State v. Gaster, 349 
S.C. 545, 557, 564 S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002) (citations omitted). â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when
  the trial court's ruling is based on an error of law.â€ State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 325, 540 S.E.2d 464, 467 (2000) (quoting Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000)).Â  In an appeal from a motion to
  suppress evidence based on Fourth Amendment grounds, our
  review is limited to determining whether any evidence supports the circuit
  courtâ€™s decision.Â  State v. Bowman, 366 S.C. 485, 501, 623 S.E.2d 378,
  386 (2005).
As to his consent
  argument, Moore primarily relies on State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637,
  541 S.E.2d 837 (2001). Â Forrester stands for the proposition that under the
  South Carolina Constitution, â€œsuspects are free to limit the scope of the
  searches to which they consent.â€ Id. at 648, 541 S.E.2d at 843. â€œWhen
  relying on the consent of a suspect, a police officer's search must not exceed
  the scope of the consent granted or the search becomes unreasonable.â€ Id. â€œThe scope of the consent is measured by a test of â€˜objectiveâ€™ reasonableness- what
  would the typical reasonable person have understood by the exchange between the
  officer and the suspect?â€ State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577,
  585-86, 575 S.E.2d 852, 856 (Ct. App. 2003) (citation omitted).Â  Admittedly, a
  cursory review suggests a search which partially dismantled the truck and left
  it inoperable arguably exceeded the scope of consent given.Â  See State
    v. Garcia, 127 N.M. 695, 698, 986 P.2d 491, 494 (N.M. App. 1999), cert.
      granted, 128 N.M. 150, 990 P.2d 824 (N.M. Aug. 11, 1999) (No. 25,837)
  (although an individual consenting to a vehicle search should expect the search
  to be thorough, he need not anticipate the search to include the destruction of
  his vehicle).
However, the case
  at hand is distinguishable from the authority upon which Moore relies.Â  While Moore might have had some interest in the truck being searched pursuant to his status as a
  permissive user, even if the search of his brotherâ€™s truck exceeded the scope
  of Mooreâ€™s consent, it did not violate Mooreâ€™s privacy interests.Â  South Carolina cases such as Forrester, which address the scope of consent given to
  investigating officers, pertain to the expansion of an existing search to
  incorporate a compartment or container not covered by the consent given.Â  In
  the case at hand, the issue is not whether the investigating officers intruded
  into a protected, private or hidden area, but rather, the issue is whether they
  exceeded the scope of consent by damaging or dismantling the truck they were
  searching. The damaging or dismantling of Mooreâ€™s truck may give some right of
  recourse to Mooreâ€™s brother, but affords no specific constitutional right to
  Moore himself based on the facts presented in this case.
Initially, we
  question whether Mooreâ€™s constitutional rights were violated due to his lack of
  any reasonable expectation of privacy in the vehicle since consent to search was
  also given by his brother, the true owner of the vehicle in question.Â  As
  previously mentioned, this case does not involve a violation of Mooreâ€™s right to privacy.Â  For Fourth Amendment purposes, â€œ[a] â€˜seizureâ€™ of property occurs when there is some meaningful
  interference with an individual's possessory interests in
  that property.â€ U.S. v. Jacobsen, 466 U.S. 109, 113, 133, 104
  S.Ct. 1652, 1656 (1984) (citing U.S. v. Place, 462 U.S. 696, 696, 103 S.Ct. 2637, 2638 (1983)). Â The only evidence
  presented was that Moore was a regular driver of the vehicle and thus, was a
  permissive user of the vehicle.Â  Even if Moore were the only one to regularly
  drive the vehicle, since Mooreâ€™s brother, the owner, also consented to the
  search and seizure of the vehicle, Moore cannot now claim that any alleged
  possessory interest in the vehicle was infringed or violated.Â   
In
  the context of a passenger occupant, the United States Supreme Court in Rakas
    v. Illinois, 439 U.S. 128, 99 S.Ct. 421(1978), addressed whether evidence
  seized in an automobile in which defendants had been passengers should have
  been suppressed. Â The Court held that:

	â€œFourth
  Amendment rights are personal rights which, like some other constitutional
  rights, may not be vicariously asserted.â€ Â A person who is aggrieved by an illegal search and seizure only
  through the introduction of damaging evidence secured by a search of a third
  person's premises or property has not had any of his Fourth Amendment rights
  infringed. Â And since the exclusionary rule is an attempt to effectuate the
  guarantees of the Fourth Amendment, it is proper to permit only defendants
  whose Fourth Amendment rights have been violated to benefit from the rule's
  protections. Â There is no reason to
  think that a party whose rights have been infringed will not, if evidence is
  used against him, have ample motivation to move to suppress it. Â Even if such a
  person is not a defendant in the action, he may be able to recover damages for
  the violation of his Fourth Amendment rights, or seek redress under state law
  for invasion of privacy or trespass.

Rakas, 439 U.S. at 133-34, 99 S.Ct. at 425 (citations
  omitted).Â  While there may be
  circumstances under which a non-owner driver can demonstrate the requisite
  expectation of privacy under Rakas to gain standing, no such circumstances have
  been presented in this case. Assuming, arguendo, that a person may have some
  expectation of privacy over that personâ€™s own vehicle parked in the backyard of
  his own residence, Mooreâ€™s constitutional claim is nonetheless unavailing. Â While
  Moore has demonstrated he resided at the location, the record still does not
  suggest such a privacy interest in the vehicle itself to invoke further
  scrutiny by this court. Â He did not have sole custody of the vehicle nor was he
  stopped while he was using the vehicle.Â  We see nothing more of record than his
  status as a permissive user.Â  Any concern raised by virtue of the vehicleâ€™s
  location in the backyard, especially under the South Carolina Constitution, was
  rectified by the consent to take the vehicle from the backyard. Further, as the
  trial court indicated, the only evidence used against him was visually
  accessible on the outside of the vehicle.Â  Thus, any reasonable expectation of
  privacy Moore may have had in the vehicle was not infringed. Additionally, Moore has failed to particularize any injury in fact that he has suffered as a result of
  the search.Â  Accordingly, we find neither a violation of his Fourth Amendment
  rights nor a violation of Art. 1, Section 10 of the S.C. Constitution.Â   
Furthermore, the investigating
  officers had probable cause to search the vehicle obviating the need for expanded
  consent or for analyzing the scope thereof.Â  â€œGenerally, a warrantless search
  is per se unreasonable and thus violative of the Fourth Amendment's prohibition
  against unreasonable searches and seizures.â€ State v. Bultron, 318 S.C. 323, 331, 457 S.E.2d 616, 621 (Ct.App.1995) (citing State v. Bailey, 276 S.C. 32, 274 S.E.2d 913
  (1981)). â€œHowever, a
  warrantless search will withstand constitutional scrutiny where the search
  falls within one of a few specifically established and well delineated
  exceptions to the Fourth Amendment exclusionary rule.â€ Bultron, 318 S.C.
  at 331-32, 457 S.E.2d at 621 (citing State v. Brown, 289 S.C. 581, 347
  S.E.2d 882 (1986)). These exceptions include: (1) search incident to a lawful
  arrest; (2) â€œhot pursuitâ€; (3) stop and frisk; (4) automobile exception; (5)
  â€œplain viewâ€ doctrine; (6) consent; and (7) abandonment. State v. Dupree, 319 S.C. 454, 456-57, 462 S.E.2d 279, 281 (1995), cert. denied, 516 U.S. 1131, 116 S.Ct. 951 (1996).
â€œThe
  burden of establishing probable cause as well as the existence of circumstances
  constituting an exception to the general prohibition against warrantless
  searches and seizures is upon the prosecution.â€ Bultron, 318 S.C.
  at 332, 457 S.E.2d at 621.Â  The record establishes the requisite probable cause
  in this case.Â  Officer Harrelson testified that a witness who viewed the
  collision described the truck as â€œa camouflaged type colored vehicle, an older
  pickup truck and the clincher was that the license tag was mounted on the left
  side of the bumper which is something you donâ€™t see often.â€ Â That description
  was then conveyed to news media, and a day or two later an off duty officer
  called in a license plate number of a vehicle matching that unique
  description.Â  From that license plate information, Officer Harrelson was able
  to obtain an address for the suspect vehicle. Â Upon arriving at that
  address, Officer Harrelson saw the suspect vehicle in the driveway behind the
  residence.Â  Through visual inspection of that vehicle, Officer Harrelson
  noticed that the license plate was off center, the truck was so rusty that at
  night it could appear camouflage in color, and that it had sustained damage to
  front end.Â  Before giving the consent to take the vehicle, and after being
  given Miranda warnings, Moore voluntarily told the officer he had been driving
  on the night in question around the time of the incident.Â  He further indicated
  that he thought he hit an animal or a bump or something and that there were no
  mechanical problems with the car. Â This combination of information is
  sufficient to establish that the officer had probable cause which, when
  combined with one of the exceptions to the warrant requirement, justifies a
  warrantless search of the vehicle.
As
  to those previously listed exceptions, we first look to the automobile
  exception.Â  â€œThe two bases for the exception are: (1) the ready mobility of
  automobiles and the potential that evidence may be lost before a warrant is obtained;
  and (2) the lessened expectation of privacy in motor vehicles which are subject
  to governmental regulation.â€ Â State
    v. Cox, 290 S.C. 489, 491, 351 S.E.2d 570, 571 (1986)
  (citations omitted).Â  In Cox, the
  court found that â€œunder the automobile exception, probable cause alone is
  sufficient to justify a warrantless search.â€ Id. at 492, 351 S.E.2d at
  571-72 (citing California v. Carney, 471 U.S. 386, 105 S.Ct. 2066 (1985)). Â 
Furthermore,
  in State v. Weaver, 374 S.C. 313, 320-21, 649 S.E.2d 479, 483 (2007), the
  supreme court noted that if there is probable cause to search a vehicle at the
  time it is seized, this rationale does not disappear merely because the vehicle
  is taken into police custody or immobilized. Â The court also indicated that it
  does not matter if a few days have passed before the search is conducted. While
  the majority in Weaver suggests it does not matter whether the vehicle
  was on private or public property and the dissent took exception thereto, we
  need not address any further the public / private dichotomy since the concerns
  of both the majority and the dissent are met by the consensual act of Moore and
  his brother allowing the police onto the property to take the vehicle. Â Therefore,
  under the automobile exception to the warrant requirement, the presence of
  probable cause validated the search and seizure of the vehicle despite the
  scope of consent given and impoundment of the vehicle by investigating officers.
We conclude, under
  the circumstances presented, the record herein does not support a violation of
  any reasonable expectation of privacy assertion by Moore to warrant suppression
  of the evidence and we also conclude that Moore failed to particularize any
  specific injury suffered. Moreover, even if the officers exceeded the scope of
  consent, their search of the vehicle was still lawful under the automobile
  exception to the warrant requirement and the evidence was appropriately
  admitted into Mooreâ€™s trial.[3]
II
Did the trial court err by
  failing to declare a mistrial when the solicitor allegedly suggested that Moore had an affirmative duty to modify his statement to police?
Moore argues that
  during closing arguments the solicitor made an impermissible comment on the
  defendantâ€™s right to remain silent when he stated the following:

	Remember
  this.Â  Tim Novembrino, a friend of his, Tim Novembrino said, â€œAfter the police
  talked with him, he comes up and says immediately runs to the phone.â€Â  He says,
	
	â€œTim, I
  was with you last night. Right?â€
	â€œNo, you
  wasnâ€™t at my house.â€ Â 
	â€œI spent
  the night with you on the 20th, the 19th going into the
  20th.Â  Right?â€Â  
	â€œNo.â€
	â€œWell, I
  told the police that.â€
	Tim
  Novembrino said, â€œYou better go back and tell the police something different
  because that is not true.â€
	People,
  you can consider that as evidence of a guilty mind.

The
  decision to grant or deny a mistrial is within the sound discretion of the
  trial court and will not be overturned on appeal absent an abuse of discretion
  amounting to an error of law. State v. Stanley, 365 S.C. 24, 33,
  615 S.E.2d 455, 460 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Rowlands, 343 S.C.
  454, 458, 539 S.E.2d 717, 719 (Ct. App. 2000). Granting of a mistrial is a
  serious and extreme measure which should only be taken when the prejudice can
  be removed no other way. Stanley, 365 S.C. at 34, 615 S.E.2d at
  460.Â   
While
  the state may not directly or indirectly refer to or comment upon a defendantâ€™s
  exercise of a constitutional right, namely his right to remain silent, here the
  solicitor was commenting on what he characterized as Mooreâ€™s attempt to create
  a false alibi.Â  Furthermore, the solicitor simply restated the testimony that
  was already in the record without objection.Â  â€œImproper comments on a
  defendant's failure to testify do not automatically require
  reversal if they are not prejudicial to the defendant.â€ Gill v. State, 346 S.C. 209, 221, 552 S.E.2d 26, 33 (2001). â€œThe defendant bears the burden of
  demonstrating that improper comments on his refusal to testify deprived him of
  a fair trial.â€ Id. â€œFurthermore, even if the solicitor makes an
  improper comment on the defendant's failure to testify, a curative instruction emphasizing the jury cannot consider [the]
  defendant's failure to testify against him will cure any potential error.â€ Id . Â 
The
  trial judge first gave a cautionary instruction to the jury during trial that
  the testimony of the witness about instructing Moore to call the police was not
  to be held against the defendant and the judge further reminded the jury that
  the defendant had the constitutional right to remain silent.Â  In the final
  charge, the judge again stated that Moore did not have the duty to report to or
  call the police. The judge also reiterated the defendantâ€™s right to remain
  silent and that the defendantâ€™s silence may not be considered against him. Â Even
  if the comment by the solicitor was inappropriate, which we do not so hold,
  having considered the entire record and the charge as a whole, the trial judge
  cured the alleged improper inference by the solicitor, if any.Â  Accordingly,
  any alleged error did not prejudice Moore and was therefore harmless.
CONCLUSION
For
  the aforementioned reasons the judgment of the trial court is hereby  
AFFIRMED.
HUFF,
  J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] While we note the existence of a valid search
  warrant may satisfy our concerns about the evidence seized, we nonetheless feel
  compelled to address the arguments on appeal since the state requested the
  trial court to proceed only on the consent theory.
[3] Appellate rules provide that we may affirm a decision upon any grounds appearing in the record. Rule 220(c), SCACR (2006). Â In
  that regard, we note that the plain view doctrine is also potentially
  applicable and was addressed by the trial court.Â  However, one of the elements
  of the doctrine recognized by the South Carolina Supreme Court case is
  inadvertent discovery.Â  State v. Culbreath, 300 S.C. 232, 237, 387
  S.E.2d 255, 257 (1990).Â  Shortly after Culbreath was decided, the United
  States Supreme Court in Horton v. California, 496 U.S. 128, 130, 110
  S.Ct. 2301, 2304 (1990), ruled that the plain view exception to the Fourth
  Amendmentâ€™s warrant requirement applies even if the discovery of the evidence
  was not inadvertent, if the other requirements of the exception are satisfied.Â 
  Due to our disposition and in light of the fact that the South Carolina Supreme
  Court has not yet indicated whether Horton will impact South Carolina
  jurisprudence, especially as it may apply to the South Carolina Constitution,
  we need not address this issue. Â

title: Thomas v. Dootson
description: A directed verdict was granted in this medical malpractice case due to the plaintiff's failure to provide expert testimony.  As notice was the central issue, expert testimony was not necessary.  Therefore, we reverse the granting of the directed verdict.

-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Kelvin Thomas, Appellant,
				v.
				Jeffery
      Dootson, DMD, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4358
Heard January 8, 2008 â€“ Filed March 13,
  2008
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Robert B. Ransom, of Columbia, for Appellant.
			  Charles E. Hill and R. Hawthorne, both of Columbia, for
  Respondent.
			
	  
	

KITTREDGE,
  J:Â  This is an appeal from a directed
  verdict for Dr. Jeffrey Dootson in a medical malpractice case.Â  The disposition
  of this appeal turns on whether there is evidence that Dr. Dootson had notice
  that a surgical drill overheated prior to the injury to the patient, Kelvin
  Thomas.Â  Viewing the evidence in a light most favorable to Thomas, as we must,
  we find evidence Dr. Dootson had notice that the surgical drill was defective
  prior to the injury.Â  As a result, we reverse and remand for a new trial.
I.
During
  oral surgery, Thomasâ€™ mouth was severely burned by a malfunctioning drill.Â 
  Thomas filed a medical malpractice claim against Dr. Dootson and Palmetto Richland Memorial Hospital.[1]Â 
  The trial court directed a verdict for Dr. Dootson at the close of Thomasâ€™
  case.
The
  critical issue at trial, and before us on appeal, is whether Dr. Dootson had
  notice the surgical drill overheated prior to Thomasâ€™ injury.Â  The case was
  tried on the premise that the surgical drill was defective.Â  Beginning with his
  opening statement at trial, Dr. Dootsonâ€™s counsel stated, â€œ[t]he reason this
  injury occurred is quite simple.Â  There was an equipment malfunction.Â  The
  surgical drill that Dr. Dootson was using overheated and burned Mr. Thomasâ€™
  mouth.â€Â  This concession was reiterated on appeal, as Dr. Dootson acknowledged:

	There has never been
  any real dispute that a defective surgical drill resulted in the burn to
  Thomasâ€™ lip.Â  Indeed, the fact was essentially presumed at trial, since the
  Hospital, which had provided the drill, had already settled out of the case.Â 
  The central issue at trial, therefore, was whether Dr. Dootson breached his
  standard of care by using the drill during the surgical procedure.

Dr.
  Dootson is bound by his concessions.Â  See Ex parte McMillan, 319
  S.C. 331, 335, 461 S.E.2d 43, 45 (1995) (stating an issue conceded at trial is
  procedurally barred from appellate review); Shorb v. Shorb, 372 S.C. 623, 628 n.3, 643 S.E.2d
  124, 127 n.3 (Ct. App. 2007) (holding a party is bound by a concession in his
  brief).
Dr.
  Dootson on appeal attempts to resurrect the need for expert testimony and
  recast the issue by stating, â€œ[i]f the equipment at issue had been something
  simpler and more common, that argument might have some merit.Â  The problem for
  Thomas, though, is that the proper operation of a surgical drill is not something within the lay knowledge of jurors.â€Â  (emphasis in original).Â  We
  believe the concession, as noted above, removed the need for expert testimony
  regarding standard of care concerning the operation of the surgical drill.
Were
  we in any event inclined to adopt Dr. Dootsonâ€™s argument that his argument
  concerning the need for expert testimony is properly before us, we would reject
  it.Â  Generally, expert testimony is required in medical malpractice cases to
  show the doctor failed to conform to the required standard of care; however, an
  exception exists when â€œthe common knowledge or experience of laymen is
  extensive enough for them to be able to recognize or infer negligence on the
  part of the doctor and also to determine the presence of the required causal
  link between the doctorâ€™s actions and the patientâ€™s medical problems.â€Â  Pederson
    v. Gould, 288 S.C. 141, 142, 341 S.E.2d 633, 634 (1986).Â  The South
  Carolina Supreme Court has held a tubal ligation rendering an intrauterine
  device or any other birth control device useless constitutes a matter of common
  knowledge.Â  Green v. Lilliewood, 272 S.C. 186, 192, 249 S.E.2d 910, 913
  (1978).Â  If the subject matter of Green is within the common knowledge
  exception, a claim arising from a surgical drill that burns skin on contact
  would fall well within the common knowledge or experience of laymen.
We
  turn to the dispositive issue of notice to determine if evidence of notice
  existed.Â  When reviewing a directed verdict, this court will view the evidence
  and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the nonmoving
  party.Â  Bultman v. Barber, 277 S.C. 5, 7, 281 S.E.2d 791, 792 (1981).Â 
  â€œA jury issue exists where the evidence is susceptible of more than one
  reasonable inference.â€Â  Jones v. Ridgely Commcâ€™ns, Inc., 304 S.C. 452,
  454, 405 S.E.2d 402, 403 (1991).Â  â€œWhen considering directed verdict and JNOV
  motions, neither the trial court nor the appellate court has authority to
  decide credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence.â€Â  Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 300, 536 S.E.2d 408, 419 (Ct. App.
  2000).Â  Further, this court stated in Weaver v. Lentz, 348 S.C. 672,
  680-81, 561 S.E.2d 360, 365 (Ct. App. 2002):

	[I]t is
  not unusual for a case to have contradictory evidence and inconsistent
  testimony from a witness.Â  In a law case tried
  before a jury, it is the jury that must decide what part of the witnessâ€™s
  testimony it wants to believe and what part it wants to disbelieve.Â  Under such
  circumstances, it is not the function of this Court to weigh the evidence and
  determine the credibility of the witnesses.

In
  the case at hand, Thomas presented testimony Dr. Dootson was warned of a drill
  overheating in a previous surgery and the drill being used for Thomasâ€™ surgery
  was hot.Â  At trial, the following exchange occurred without objection during
  the questioning of surgical technician, Michael Ellis:[2]

	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Mr.
  Ellis, thereâ€™s no question, you said, that the drill malfunctioned?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Correct.
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  No
  question that Dr. Dootson was warned about this drill?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Correct.
	Q.Â Â Â Â Â  After
  you had warned him and after it started getting hot, did Dr. Dootson do
  anything to check the drill to see whether it was still safe to use?
	A.Â Â Â Â Â  No.

Ellis also testified when Dr.
  Dootson passed him the drill prior to Thomasâ€™ injury, Ellis noticed the drill
  was â€œwarmer than normal.â€
Additionally,
  the following colloquy occurred without objection during the direct examination
  of surgical technician, Charlotte Rivers:

	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  After
  you noticed the drill was getting hot, did you say anything to Dr. Dootson?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  No.
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  And
  why not?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  He
  had already been told that the drill was hot.
	. . . .
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Was
  [Dr. Dootson] aware there was a problem with the drill before [Thomas] got
  burned?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes.

Accordingly, a jury question
  was presented on the issue of notice, rendering a directed verdict
  inappropriate.
II.
The
  trial court excluded some of the testimony regarding notice as hearsay.Â  We
  address this assignment of error now in the interest of judicial economy.Â  See Floyd v. Horry County Sch. Dist., 351 S.C. 233, 234, 569 S.E.2d 343, 344
  (2002) (addressing the merits in the interest of judicial economy).
â€œâ€˜Hearsayâ€™
  is a statement, other than one made by the declarant while testifying at the
  trial or hearing, offered in evidence to prove the truth of the matter
  asserted.â€ Rule 801(c), SCRE.Â  Conversely, statements offered not for the truth
  of the matter asserted, but rather as evidence of notice, do not constitute
  hearsay.Â  Player v. Thompson, 259 S.C. 600, 610, 193 S.E.2d 531, 535
  (1972).
From
  an evidentiary standpoint, the facts and analysis in Player mirror those
  in this case.Â  In Player, the court held testimony a filling station
  attendant told the defendant she had slick tires prior to the accident did not
  constitute hearsay.Â  Id.Â  The testimony was not offered to prove the
  tires were slick, but only to establish the defendant had notice of her tiresâ€™
  condition prior to the accident.Â  Id.Â  Other evidence established the
  slickness of the tires.Â  Id.
Similarly
  in this case, Thomas attempted to offer additional testimony from Rivers that
  Dr. Dootson had been warned the drill was hot prior to the injury.Â  The trial
  court improperly ruled the statement was hearsay. Â The testimony, just as in Player,
  was not offered for the truth of the matter asserted, but rather as evidence of
  notice.Â  The argument for admissibility is at least equally strong here as in Player,
  for here we are presented with a concession concerning the defective condition
  of the surgical drill.Â  It was error to exclude this testimony.
We
  decline to address the remaining issues.Â  See Ringer v. Graham,
  286 S.C. 14, 20, 331 S.E.2d 373, 377 (Ct. App. 1985) (determining discussion of
  remaining issues was unnecessary when an issue was dispositive in reversing a
  directed verdict).
III.
The
  grant of the directed verdict is reversed, as is the ruling excluding Riversâ€™
  testimony.Â 
  We remand for a new trial.
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J.,
  and THOMAS, J., concur.

[1]  The claim against the hospital was settled
  prior to trial.
[2]  Dr. Dootson argues Ellis solely warned Dr. Dootson a
  drill malfunctioned in a prior surgery; however, this is not necessarily
  consistent with the testimony and is a question for the jury when weighing the
  testimony.

description: Virgil Lee Culbreath appeals from his conviction for trafficking of crack cocaine, asserting the trial judge erred in denying Culbreathâ€™s motion for a mistrial after the Stateâ€™s witness mentioned prior drug dealings with Culbreath.  We affirm.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Virgil Lee
      Culbreath, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Edgefield County
Â Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4359
Submitted February 1, 2008 â€“ Filed March
  18, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Tommy A. Thomas and Tricia A. Blanchette, of Irmo, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  and Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, Office of the Attorney
  General, of Columbia, and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PIEPER, J.: Virgil Lee Culbreath appeals from his
  conviction for trafficking of crack cocaine, asserting the trial judge erred in
  denying Culbreathâ€™s motion for a mistrial after the Stateâ€™s witness mentioned
  prior drug dealings with Culbreath.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Culbreath was indicted in 2004 on one
  count of trafficking crack cocaine and one count of distribution of crack
  cocaine within the proximity of a school or park.Â  Both counts arose from an
  April 30, 2004 controlled sale to a confidential informant.Â Â   
At trial,
  the State called the confidential informant, Kontay Gaines as a witness.Â 
  Gaines testified he had been arrested several times for selling drugs and
  incarcerated twice.Â  Gaines further stated that after he was arrested in
  November 2003, he told law enforcement officials he could buy drugs from Culbreath.[2]Â  The solicitor then asked Gaines how
  he knew Culbreath but instructed him not to talk about any business
  transactions.Â  Culbreathâ€™s counsel moved for a mistrial, contending the term
  â€œbusiness transactionsâ€ inferred drug transactions.Â  The trial court denied the
  motion.Â  Before the jury returned to the courtroom, the solicitor specifically
  instructed Gaines not to talk about any prior drug transactions with
  Culbreath.Â   
During direct examination Gaines testified he met Culbreath in
  1994 and that Culbreath dated his stepsister. Â Gaines proceeded to detail the
  April 30, 2004 controlled sale from Culbreath.Â  Gaines explained he met with
  law enforcement officers at the airport where the officers searched Gaines and
  his vehicle.Â  The officers provided Gaines with $3000 and a beeper.Â  Gaines
  went to Culbreathâ€™s residence and arranged to purchase three ounces of crack
  cocaine for $3000.Â  Once Gaines left Culbreathâ€™s residence, the officers
  contacted Gaines and instructed him to meet them at a nearby church.Â  The
  officers searched Gaines and the vehicle, and changed the battery in the
  beeper.Â  Gaines then drove to a restaurant parking lot to wait for Culbreathâ€™s
  call.Â   
Culbreath pulled up next to Gaines in the parking lot and told
  Gaines to follow him.Â  Gaines followed Culbreath to a house in Edgefield.Â  Once
  inside Culbreath explained he could not get the three ounces Gaines wanted but
  gave Gaines a paper bag containing two ounces of crack cocaine.Â  Gaines paid
  Culbreath $2000, left the house, and drove to a prearranged location to meet
  with the officers.Â  He turned the crack cocaine and remaining $1000 over to the
  officers.Â   
On cross-examination, Culbreathâ€™s counsel asked Gaines if the
  drugs he sold when he was arrested in November 2003 were â€œfrontedâ€ to him.Â 
  Gaines replied, â€œ[y]es sir, from Virgil Culbreath.â€Â  Culbreathâ€™s counsel
  indicated he had a motion, and the trial court indicated it would be
  entertained later.Â  Culbreathâ€™s counsel continued to question Gaines about the
  drugs he purchased from Culbreath on April 30, 2004. Â Gaines was asked if he
  checked inside the package containing the crack cocaine.Â  Gaines replied he did
  not, and then asked if he could say why he did not check the package.Â 
  Culbreathâ€™s counsel asked him â€œwhy,â€ and Gaines responded â€œ[b]ecause I dealt
  with [Culbreath] before and I never had to check it.â€Â  Defense counsel again
  indicated he had a motion, and the trial court stated he could make it at the
  proper time.Â   
After Gaines finished testifying, counsel moved for a mistrial
  based on Gainesâ€™ testimony referring to previous dealings with Culbreath.Â  In
  reply, the State noted Gaines testified, without objection, he told the police
  he knew he could buy drugs from Culbreath.Â  Further, the State argued Gainesâ€™
  subsequent testimony was in response to questions from defense counsel and
  therefore the defense opened the door to the testimony.Â  The trial court found
  counsel opened the door to the testimony by asking whether Gaines had drugs
  â€œfrontedâ€ to him, and then asking him why he did not check inside the package
  he received from Culbreath.Â  Thus, the trial court conditionally denied the
  mistrial motion and instructed Culbreathâ€™s counsel he could provide the court
  with relevant case law the following day.Â   
The
  next morning, defense counsel presented two cases in support of his request for
  a mistrial.[3]Â 
  After reviewing the cases, the trial court denied the motion, finding the cases
  were distinguishable because they involved the Stateâ€™s attempt to introduce
  prior bad acts or prior crimes evidence, while the instant case involved
  responses to questions posed by the defense counsel.Â   
The trial court directed a verdict for Culbreath on the proximity
  charge and submitted the trafficking charge to the jury.Â  Culbreath was
  convicted of trafficking crack cocaine and sentenced to fifteen years
  incarceration.Â  This appeal follows.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Whether to grant or
  deny a mistrial motion is a matter within the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion,
  and the courtâ€™s decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of
  discretion amounting to an error of law.Â  State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1,
  12-13, 515 S.E.2d 508, 514 (1999); State v. White, 371 S.C. 439, 443-44,
  639 S.E.2d 160, 162 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  A mistrial should be declared only when
  absolutely necessary.Â  Council, 335 S.C. at 13, 515 S.E.2d at 514.Â  In
  order to receive a mistrial, a defendant must show error and resulting
  prejudice.Â  Id.Â  It is only in cases of abuse of discretion which result
  in prejudice that this court will intervene and grant a new trial.Â  White,
  371 S.C. at 444, 639 S.E.2d at 162. Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Initially, we note
  that any argument by Culbreath that the trial court erred in denying his motion
  for a mistrial based upon a comment or question made by the solicitor is not
  properly presented for appeal.Â   
â€œIn
  order for an issue to be properly presented for appeal, the appellantâ€™s brief
  must set forth the issue in the statement of issues on appeal.â€Â  Langehans
    v. Smith, 347 S.C. 348, 352, 554 S.E.2d 681, 683 (Ct. App. 2001); see also Rule 208(b)(1)(B), SCACR (â€œOrdinarily, no point will be considered
  which is not set forth in the statement of the issues on appeal.â€).Â   
Culbreathâ€™s
  appellate brief contains only one argument. Â The heading above the argument
  states, â€œ[t]he trial court erred in refusing to grant a mistrial after the
  Stateâ€™s key witness mentioned several times prior drug dealings with
  appellant.â€Â  While Culbreathâ€™s appellate brief recounts the question asked by
  the solicitor, the legal argument presented applies only to the statements made
  by Gaines.Â  Culbreath provides no legal authority or supportive arguments as to
  any improper question asked by the solicitor.Â   
It
  is error for the appellate court to consider an issue not properly raised to
  it.Â  First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514
  (1994).Â  Therefore, this court is limited to addressing the single issue raised
  by Culbreath in his brief as to whether the trial court erred in refusing to
  grant a mistrial after Gaines mentioned prior drug dealings with Culbreath.Â Â Â 
 
Culbreath
  contends Gainesâ€™ references to Culbreathâ€™s prior drug dealings were an
  impermissible attempt to submit evidence of prior bad acts.Â  Further, Culbreath
  claims the references were prejudicial because they were shockingly similar to
  the charge for which Culbreath was on trial.Â   
Generally,
  evidence of prior crimes or bad acts is not admissible to prove the crime for
  which the defendant is charged.Â  State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 416, 118
  S.E. 803, 807 (1923).Â  Such evidence is admissible when it tends to show (1)
  motive; (2) intent; (3) the absence of mistake or accident; (4) a common scheme
  or plan embracing the commission of two or more crimes so related to each other
  that proof of one tends to establish the others; or (5) the identity of the
  person charged with the commission of the crime on trial.Â  Id.Â  The
  evidence of prior crimes or bad acts must be relevant to prove the alleged
  crime.Â  State v. Campbell, 317 S.C. 449, 451, 454 S.E.2d 899, 901 (Ct.
  App. 1994).Â  When the prior bad acts are â€œstrikingly similar to the one for
  which the appellant is being tried, the danger of prejudice is enhanced.â€Â  State
    v. Gore, Â 283 S.C. 118, 121, 322 S.E.2d 12, 13 (1984).Â  â€œ[E]ven if [the]
  prior bad act evidence is clear and convincing and falls within an exception,
  it must be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the
  danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant.â€ State v. Gillian, 373 S.C.
  601, 611, 646 S.E.2d 872, 877 (2007).Â  This balancing process is reflected in
  Rule 403, SCRE.
Notwithstanding,
  a defendant may open the door to what would be otherwise improper evidence
  through his own introduction of evidence or witness examination. Â State v.
    Young, 364 S.C. 476, 485-87, 613 S.E.2d 386, 391-92 (Ct. App. 2005), cert granted, Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 31 at 9 (Jan. 5, 2007) (discussing South Carolina jurisprudence regarding opening the door to otherwise inadmissible evidence).Â 
  A party cannot complain of prejudice from evidence to which he opened the
  door.Â  State v. Robinson, 305 S.C. 469, 474, 409 S.E.2d 404, 408 (1991); Young, 364 S.C. at 485-88, 613 S.E.2d at 391-93, cert granted,
  Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 31 at 9 (Jan. 5, 2007).  
In
  this case, the State did not submit any evidence regarding Culbreathâ€™s prior
  drug transactions and specifically instructed Gaines not to discuss prior drug
  transactions between him and Culbreath.Â  The evidence at issue resulted from
  defense counselâ€™s questioning of Gaines.Â  When counsel asked Gaines whether the
  crack cocaine he was selling in November 2003 was â€œfrontedâ€ for him, Gaines
  replied, â€œ[y]es sir, from [Culbreath].â€Â  Culbreathâ€™s counsel subsequently asked
  Gaines if he checked the package he received from Culbreath, and Gaines
  replied, â€œ[n]o sir.â€Â  Gaines then asked if he could state why he did not check
  the package.Â  When Culbreathâ€™s counsel asked him â€œ[w]hy,â€ Gaines stated
  â€œ[b]ecause I dealt with [Culbreath] before and I never had to check it.â€Â  We
  find the defense opened the door to the references made about Culbreathâ€™s prior
  drug dealing with Gaines.Â  Accordingly we find the trial court did not abuse
  its discretion in refusing to grant a mistrial.Â   
Therefore,
  the decision of the trial court is hereby  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Culbreath
  did not object to this testimony.Â   
[3] Culbreath presented State v. Carter, 323 S.C.
  465, 476 S.E.2d 916 (Ct. App. 1996) and State v. Campbell, 317 S.C. 449,
  454 S.E.2d 899 (Ct. App. 1994) to support his motion for a mistrial.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent.
				v.
				Hoss Hicks #1 Appellant,
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4360
Submitted March 3, 2008 â€“ Filed March 18,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Kathrine H. Hudgins, S.C. Commission on
  Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliot,
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, Office of the
  Attorney General, of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of
  Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Hoss Hicks appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision to grant
  the Stateâ€™s motion to reconsider his sentence, specifically asserting that good
  cause was not shown to require him to register as a sex offender.Â  We disagree
  and affirm.Â   
FACTS
Hicks was indicted for criminal sexual conduct with a minor
  (Victim).Â  At trial, Hicks pled guilty to the lesser offense of assault and
  battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN), although he admitted to 
having had sex with the fourteen-year-old Victim.Â  During sentencing, both
  parties were invited to make statements to the court, and defense counsel indicated
  that he didnâ€™t think Hicks knew where Victim lived. Â Ultimately, Hicks was
  sentenced to ten years imprisonment, suspended upon time served with five years
  probation.Â  Although the State had requested it as an additional condition to
  his sentence, Hicks was not required to register as a sex offender.Â  However, the
  circuit court did include as a condition of his probation, that Hicks not live
  within five miles of Victimâ€™s family and have no contact with the family or Victim.
 
The following day,
  the State moved to reconsider the sentence, arguing Victimâ€™s father was not
  able to attend the plea and wished to be heard by the court.Â  In addition, the
  State sought to clarify defense counselâ€™s assertion that Hicks did not know
  where Victim lived.Â  Upon reconsideration, the court declined to increase
  Hicksâ€™ sentence, but ordered Hicks to register as a sex offender.Â  This appeal
  followed.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œOn
  appeal, the trial courtâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed absent a prejudicial
  abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law.â€ Â State v. Sheldon,
  344 S.C. 340, 342, 543 S.E.2d 585, 585-586 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion
  occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law or, when
  grounded in factual conclusions, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Hicks argues the
  circuit court abused its discretion in reconsidering its sentence. Â We
  disagree.
The
  authority to change a sentence rests exclusively with the sentencing judge and is
  within his or her discretion.Â  State v. Smith, 276 S.C. 494, 498, 280
  S.E.2d 200, 202 (1981). Â A judge or
  other sentencing authority is to be accorded very wide discretion in
  determining an appropriate sentence, and must be permitted to consider any and
  all information that reasonably might bear on the proper sentence for the
  particular defendant, given the crime committed.Â  Wasman v. United States, 468 U.S. 559, 563 (1984).Â  Here, the State made a timely motion to reconsider
  based upon additional information which Victimâ€™s father, who was not present at
  the original sentencing, could provide, as well as to clarify alleged
  misstatements made by Hicksâ€™ counsel during sentencing.Â  We find the circuit
  court acted within its authority in hearing the motion to reconsider Hicksâ€™ sentence.Â  
 
Hicks
  also maintains the circuit court abused its discretion in ordering him to
  register as a sex offender.Â  We disagree.
Section
  23-3-430 of the South Carolina Code (2007) provides the instances in which it
  is appropriate for a court to order a person to register as a sex offender.Â 
  Although ABHAN, the crime to which Hicks pled guilty, is not included in the
  list, Section D provides that:

	[U]pon
  conviction, adjudication of delinquency, guilty plea, or plea of nolo
  contendere of a person of an offense not listed in this article, the presiding
  judge may order as a condition of sentencing that the person be included in the
  sex offender registry if good cause is shown by the solicitor.

S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-430(D) (2007).
Hicks
  contends the State failed to show â€œgood causeâ€ sufficient to require him to
  register as a sex offender.Â As noted earlier, although he pled to ABHAN, Hicks 
admitted at the plea hearing to having sex with the fourteen-year-old Victim. In the reconsideration hearing, the court heard
  from Victimâ€™s father that, contrary to defense counselâ€™s statement during the
  initial sentencing, Hicks did indeed know where Victim lived; Hicks lived
  within a half mile of Victimâ€™s house. Â Describing the nature of Hicksâ€™
  behavior, Victimâ€™s father stated Hicks had been by Victimâ€™s house on numerous
  occasions, both before and after the ABHAN.Â  During the course of several of
  these occurrences, Hicks made gestures towards Victimâ€™s father that could be
  interpreted as confrontational or predatory.Â   
The
  court also heard from Victimâ€™s mother a second time, but she was limited to
  providing information she had not given during the initial sentencing.Â  She confirmed
  Victimâ€™s fatherâ€™s statement that, not only did Hicks know where Victim lived,
  but that it was her understanding from Victim that Hicks had actually been in
  Victimâ€™s house on two occasions.Â  This new information combined with the
  previous statements Victimâ€™s mother made regarding the many girls, similar in
  age to Victim, who lived in the same neighborhood within a half mile of Hicks,
  supports the circuit courtâ€™s finding that good cause was shown. Â Â 
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED[1].
PIEPER,
  J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Jerri L. Abate, Respondent,
				v.
				Alfonso A.
      Abate, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
The Hon. Judy B. McMahon, Family Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 4361
Submitted February 1, 2008 â€“ Filed March
  20, 2008
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
  REMANDED


	
		
			
				Gregory Samuel Forman, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Nathaniel Elliott Barnwell, of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	

CURETON, A.J.:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In this family court action to enforce a divorce
  decree incorporating an agreement between the parties, Father appeals the
  family courtâ€™s order:Â  (1) holding Father in contempt for his failure to give
  Child his prescribed medication during summer vacation, (2) excluding Fatherâ€™s
  work-related childcare expenses from the childcare costs divisible between the
  parties, and (3) denying Fatherâ€™s motion for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in
  part, reverse in part, and remand.[1] Â 
FACTS
Father
  and Mother married in 1993 and had one child in 1999.Â  In 2004, they divorced
  in Charleston, South Carolina, on the ground of one yearâ€™s separation.Â  The
  partiesâ€™ divorce decree (Decree) incorporated a written agreement between the
  parties concerning custody, visitation, and child support.Â  Mother and Child
  subsequently moved to Ohio.Â  Child visited Father in South Carolina pursuant to
  the Decree.Â   
Although
  Mother submitted Childâ€™s medical bills to Father for reimbursement under the
  Decree, Mother obliterated the health care providersâ€™ names and addresses to
  prevent Father from contacting the providers.Â  However, Father successfully
  identified Childâ€™s Ohio pediatrician and psychiatrist, and he contacted them by
  telephone and in letters Father copied to Mother regarding Childâ€™s treatment.Â  In
  June 2005, Father telephoned Childâ€™s Ohio pediatrician and obtained his
  permission to suspend Childâ€™s Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
  medication temporarily.Â  Additionally, in May and July 2005, Father contacted
  Childâ€™s Ohio psychiatrist to obtain his opinion concerning temporarily
  suspending Childâ€™s ADHD medicine.Â  The psychiatrist discussed Fatherâ€™s letter
  with Mother.Â  In July 2005, the psychiatrist sent a letter to Father and
  Mother, declining to make a recommendation in the matter and suggesting they
  obtain a second opinion.Â  Later that month, when Child was visiting Father,
  Father obtained the opinion of a Charleston doctor regarding whether to suspend
  Childâ€™s ADHD medications temporarily in a â€œdrug holiday.â€Â  The Charleston doctor recommended suspending Childâ€™s ADHD medication pending further testing.Â 
  In September 2005, Mother obtained the opinion of a different Ohio doctor regarding
  Childâ€™s diagnosis of ADHD.Â  That doctor found that Child met â€œdiagnostic
  criteria for ADHDâ€ and suggested minor modifications to Childâ€™s medication
  regimen but did not opine concerning any effects on Child from the drug
  holiday.Â   
In
  September 2005, Mother submitted her work-related childcare costs to Father for
  reimbursement in accordance with the Decree.Â  Father reimbursed Mother for less
  than half her expenses, claiming a credit equal to half the amount Father had
  expended for work-related childcare costs while Child was in his care over
  summer vacation.Â   
In
  March 2006, Father obtained and filed an order and rule to show cause against
  Mother for nine alleged violations of the Decree.Â  Father requested attorneyâ€™s
  fees and costs for his prosecution of the show-cause issues.Â  Mother responded
  by obtaining and filing her own rule to show cause against Father, alleging two
  violations of the Decree and requesting attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  The family
  court heard both rules to show cause at the same hearing.Â  Initially, the
  family court found Mother in contempt on three issues and in violation of the
  Decree on three others; additionally, it found Father in contempt on one issue
  and in violation of the Decree on another issue.Â  The family court declined to
  award attorneyâ€™s fees or costs to either party.Â   
Father
  moved for reconsideration of eight issues, including contempt findings and the
  denial of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  After rehearing, the family court still declined to
  award attorneyâ€™s fees but held Mother in contempt on five issues.Â  It held
  Father in contempt on one issue, his refusal to give Child his ADHD medication
  during July 2005.Â  Furthermore, the family court held Father was not entitled to
  a credit for his childcare expenses and must reimburse Mother the amount of the
  money he had withheld.Â  The family court did not hold Father in contempt for
  claiming the childcare credit.Â  This appeal followed.Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Contempt for
  Failure to Medicate
Father
  argues the family court erred in holding him in contempt for failing to give
  Child ADHD medication during summer vacation.Â  We agree.Â   
An
  appellate court should reverse a decision regarding contempt only if it is
  without evidentiary support or the trial judge has abused his discretion.Â  Brandt
    v. Gooding, 368 S.C. 618, 627, 630 S.E.2d 259, 263 (2006).Â  An
  appellate court will reverse a manifest abuse of discretion where the error of
  law is â€œso opposed to the trial judgeâ€™s sound discretion as to amount to a
  deprivation of the legal rights of the party.â€ Â Jeter v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 369 S.C. 433, 438, 633
  S.E.2d 143, 145-46 (2006).Â  The term â€œabuse of discretionâ€ does not reflect
  negatively on the trial court; rather, it merely indicates the appellate court
  believes an error of law occurred in the circumstances at hand.Â  Macauley v.
    Query, 193 S.C. 1, 5, 7 S.E.2d 519, 521 (1940).Â   
â€œContempt
  results from a willful disobedience of a court order.â€Â  Lindsay v. Lindsay,
  328 S.C. 329, 345, 491 S.E.2d 583, 592 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Willful disobedience
  requires an act to be â€œdone voluntarily and intentionally with the specific
  intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to
  do something the law requires to be done; that is to say, with bad purpose
  either to disobey or disregard the law.â€ Spartanburg Co. Depâ€™t of Soc.
    Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988).Â  A party seeking a contempt finding for
      violation of a court order must show the orderâ€™s existence and facts
      establishing the other party did not comply with the order.Â  Hawkins v.
        Mullins, 359 S.C. 497, 501, 597 S.E.2d 897, 899 (Ct. App. 2004). 

We find the family court
  abused its discretion in holding Father in contempt for not giving Child his
  ADHD medication during summer break.Â  Father and Mother agreed, and the family
  court ordered, that:

	Both
  parties shall follow [Child]â€™s pediatricianâ€™s and/or psychiatristâ€™s orders
  regarding medication, and in particular, that he timely and without
  interruption takes his prescribed medicine for ADHD and both parties shall
  ensure that [Child] continues with counseling on a regular basis when he is in
  their respective care.Â  The parties concur that they shall strive to utilize
  drug-free methods of raising [Child].Â  

Two of the Decreeâ€™s three provisions
  concerning Childâ€™s health care required interaction with health care
  providers.Â  However, the family court held Mother in contempt for â€œfailure to
  communicate with [Father] on issues of the childâ€™s health, education, and
  welfare and failure to provide [Father] full accessâ€ to Childâ€™s medical
  records.Â  The family court specifically found Mother redacted the names and addresses
  of Childâ€™s Ohio medical providers from the documents she provided to Father.Â 
  Moreover, Mother withheld the second opinion she obtained concerning Childâ€™s
  ADHD diagnosis from Father until the time of trial.Â  We believe that without
  full access to Childâ€™s Ohio physicians and records, Father could not reasonably
  be expected to perform his obligations.Â   
Absent
  direction from Childâ€™s Ohio physicians, Father attempted to consult with the
  physicians whose identities he divined.Â  Childâ€™s Ohio pediatrician agreed with Fatherâ€™s
  suggestion of a drug holiday.Â  After Childâ€™s current Ohio psychiatrist declined
  to opine concerning a drug holiday, Father presented Child to a Charleston physician for an evaluation and recommendation.Â  After exhausting his contacts
  in Ohio and obtaining the Charleston physicianâ€™s approval of a temporary
  suspension of medication, Father stopped giving Child his ADHD medication.[2]Â   
We
  believe Fatherâ€™s acts demonstrate a good-faith effort to comply with the
  Decreeâ€™s requirement to follow Childâ€™s â€œpediatricianâ€™s and/or psychiatristâ€™s
  orders regarding medication.â€ Â Additionally, we believe Fatherâ€™s temporary,
  physician-sanctioned drug holiday for Child indicates an effort to comply with
  the Decree by exploring â€œdrug-free methods of raising [Child]â€ outside Childâ€™s
  school year to avoid compromising Childâ€™s performance in school.Â  Father did
  not willfully disobey a court order.Â  Therefore, the family court abused its
  discretion in finding Father in contempt for failing to give Child his ADHD medication
  during the summer holiday.Â   
II.  Childcare Costs
Father
  argues the family court erred in excluding his summer 2005 work-related
  childcare expenses from the childcare costs divisible between the parties.Â  We disagree.Â  
 
In
  our view, the agreement on its face does not indicate Fatherâ€™s summer 2005 work-related
  childcare costs should be included in total childcare costs.Â  In any event, the
  agreement contains no provision for Father to obtain credit for his
  work-related childcare costs.Â  â€œUnambiguous marital agreements will be enforced
  according to their terms . . . regardless of the contractâ€™s wisdom or folly, or
  the partiesâ€™ failure to guard their rights carefully.â€Â  Davis v.
    Davis, 372 S.C. 64, 75, 641 S.E.2d 446, 451-52 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  A court
  will only look to extrinsic evidence if an ambiguity exists in the agreementâ€™s
  terms.Â  Id. at 75, 641 S.E.2d at 452.Â  In the case at bar, the Decree
  required that Father â€œcontribute to . . . one-half of
  [Childâ€™s] work related childcare costs.Â  MOTHER shall provide FATHER with
  copies of receipts for same with FATHER reimbursing MOTHER within Thirty (30)
  days.â€Â  (emphasis in original)Â  The parties agreed this provision was
  unambiguous and waived their rights to present additional evidence of intent.Â 
  Interpretation of this provision thus became a question of law.Â  Consequently,
  we see no error in the family courtâ€™s decision to exclude Fatherâ€™s work-related
  childcare costs.[3]Â   
III.  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Father
  argues the family court erred in denying Fatherâ€™s motion for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â 
  We disagree but remand for further consideration of the effects of this appeal
  on the outcome of this matter.Â   
In a
  family court matter, â€œ[t]he award of attorneyâ€™s fees is left to the discretion
  of the trial judge and will only be disturbed upon a showing of abuse of
  discretion.â€Â  Upchurch v. Upchurch, 367 S.C. 16, 28, 624 S.E.2d 643, 648
  (2006).Â   
The
  family court did not abuse its discretion in declining to award either party
  attorneyâ€™s fees in this matter.Â  Under South Carolina law, the family court has
  jurisdiction to determine whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees in a matter properly
  before it.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(A)(38) (Supp. 2006).Â  The family court
  may award attorneyâ€™s fees under different theories.[4]Â 
  Here, the family court evaluated the request on the basis of beneficial
  results.Â  â€œIn making this determination, the court should evaluate the
  requesting partyâ€™s ability to pay, the partiesâ€™ respective financial
  conditions, the effect of the award on each partyâ€™s standard of living, and the
  beneficial results achieved.â€Â  Upchurch, 367 S.C. at 28, 624 S.E.2d at
  648.Â  A beneficial result will not secure an award of attorneyâ€™s fees where the
  other factors do not support such an award.Â  Mazzone v. Miles, 341 S.C.
  203, 214, 532 S.E.2d 890, 895 (Ct. App. 2000).[5]Â   
In declining
  to award attorneyâ€™s fees to either side, the family court found each party had
  achieved beneficial results.Â  Of the nine issues for which Father sought a
  contempt ruling against Mother, the family court held Mother in contempt on
  five and found her in violation of the Decree, but not in contempt, on one.Â  Of
  the three issues for which Mother sought a contempt ruling against Father, the
  family court held Father in contempt on one and in violation of the Decree, but
  not in contempt, on one.Â  It appears each party prevailed on at least one issue
  and successfully defended against at least one issue, thereby achieving a
  beneficial result.Â   
No
  evidence exists concerning either partyâ€™s ability to pay, either partyâ€™s
  financial condition, or the likely effect of such an award on either partyâ€™s
  standard of living.Â  The issues presented to the family court were complex, and
  we believe both parties proceeded in good faith.Â  Accordingly, we find the
  family court did not abuse its discretion in ordering each party to pay his or
  her own attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  However, because we herein reverse the family courtâ€™s
  finding of contempt for Fatherâ€™s failure to medicate, Father is no longer in
  contempt on any issues and has prevailed on six issues.Â  By contrast, Mother
  was found in contempt on five issues and has prevailed on one, the issue of
  Fatherâ€™s claimed credit for childcare costs.[6]Â 
  Consequently, we remand on the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees for consideration of
  the effects of this appeal.Â   
CONCLUSION
As
  to the issue of contempt, we find Father made good-faith efforts to comply with
  the terms of the Decree by giving Child a physician-recommended drug holiday.Â 
  Because Father did not willfully disobey a court order, we find the family
  court erred in holding Father in contempt for temporarily suspending Childâ€™s
  ADHD medication.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the order of the family court on this
  issue.Â   
As
  to the issue of Fatherâ€™s work-related childcare costs, we find the governing
  language of the Decree does not provide for Father receiving credit or
  childcare costs he expended.Â  We find the family court did not err in excluding
  Fatherâ€™s summer 2005 work-related childcare costs from its analysis, and we affirm
  the order of the family court on this issue.Â   
Finally,
  as to the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees, we remand this issue to the family court for
  further consideration in light of this decision.Â   
Accordingly,
  the order of the family court is  
AFFIRMED
  IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED.Â  
HEARN, C.J., and
  PIEPER, J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] No health care provider has specifically warned or
  recommended against a temporary suspension of Childâ€™s medication.Â  Both Childâ€™s
  Ohio pediatrician and the Charleston doctor who provided Fatherâ€™s second
  opinion endorsed the proposed drug holiday.Â  Childâ€™s Ohio psychiatrist declined
  to comment on the proposed drug holiday.Â  The doctor who provided Mother with a
  second opinion made recommendations for modifications to Childâ€™s prescription
  but did not address whether Child should have a drug holiday outside the school
  year.Â   
[3] Our decision today does not preclude the parties from
  petitioning the family court to reinterpret the provision to ascertain the
  intention of the parties.Â   
[4] The issue of whether the family court applied the
  correct standard to the question of attorneyâ€™s fees is not preserved for our
  review.Â  However, we note the family court could have applied the compensatory
  contempt theory enunciated in Miller v. Miller, 375 S.C. 443, 463, 652
  S.E.2d 754, 764-65 (Ct. App. 2007):

	Courts,
  by exercising their contempt power, can award attorneyâ€™s fees under a
  compensatory contempt theory.  Harris-Jenkins v. Nissan Car Mart, Inc.,
  348 S.C. 171, 178-79, 557 S.E.2d 708, 711-12 (Ct. App. 2001). 
  Compensatory contempt seeks to reimburse the party for the costs it incurs in
  forcing the non-complying party to obey the courtâ€™s orders.  â€œIn a civil
  contempt proceeding, a contemnor may be required to reimburse a complainant for
  the costs he incurred in enforcing the courtâ€™s prior order, including
  reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees.  The award of attorneyâ€™s fees is not a
  punishment but an indemnification to the party who instituted the contempt proceeding.â€  
	Poston v. Poston, 331 S.C. 106, 114, 502 S.E.2d 86, 90 (1998); Lindsay
    v. Lindsay, 328 S.C. 329, 345, 491 S.E.2d 583, 592 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œA
  compensatory contempt award may include attorney fees.â€); Curlee v. Howle,
  277 S.C. 377, 386-87, 287 S.E.2d 915, 919-20 (1982) (â€œCompensatory contempt is
  a money award for the [Wife] when the [Husband]  has injured the [Wife] by
  violating a previous court order . . . .  Included in the actual loss are
  the costs of defending and enforcing the courtâ€™s order, including litigation

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Blair Adams, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4362
Heard February 5, 2008 â€“ Filed March 20,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				John G. Reckenbeil, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior
  Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and
  Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Blair
  Adams appeals the circuit courtâ€™s failure to grant his motion to suppress
  evidence.Â  Adams maintains the purpose of the initial traffic stop had been
  fulfilled, and police had no reasonable suspicion, probable cause, or Adamsâ€™ consent to continue the stop.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Police Officer Bradford James pulled Adams
  over during the officerâ€™s patrol of the Park Hills area of Spartanburg.Â  James noticed
  Adamsâ€™ vehicle make a left turn without first signaling, and thereafter James pulled
  the vehicle over.Â  James approached the vehicle and asked Adams to produce his
  driverâ€™s license, vehicle registration, and proof of insurance.Â  James
  testified Adams was visibly nervous and unsure during the encounter, and
  stuttered slightly when answering his questions.Â  James also noticed the
  vehicle had numerous air fresheners hanging from his rearview mirror, and there
  was a box filled with plastic bags in the passenger-side floorboard.[1]Â   
Because of the nervousness displayed by Adams, as well as the
  potential existence of narcotics, and the safety concerns of James standing
  partially in the roadway, James asked Adams to exit and accompany him to the
  rear of the vehicle while he conducted the registration check. Â This check
  revealed Adams was not the registered owner of the vehicle, and that Adamsâ€™ driving license had previously been suspended as a result of a drug conviction.Â  During
  this police dispatch check, a second officer, William Reese came on the scene.Â  
 
While in the presence of Reese, James asked Adams for permission
  to search his vehicle.Â  Conflicting testimony exists as to whether Adams granted James permission to search his vehicle.Â  James testified Adams initially did
  not understand his rights, and that he asked James whether he could say no to
  the request.Â  Reese testified he arrived during this conversation and told Adams â€œyou do not have to give consent if you donâ€™t want to.â€Â  Thereafter, both James and
  Reese testified Adams gave consent to search the vehicle.Â  Adams meanwhile,
  testifying only to the issue of consent, maintained he never granted the
  officers permission to search his vehicle, and after he attempted to leave, the
  officers searched his vehicle without his consent to do so.
According to both officers, Reese remained with Adams at the rear
  of the vehicle while James conducted the search.Â  An initial inspection
  revealed a quantity of white powder in the center console.Â  James field-tested
  the powder, revealing a positive indication for cocaine.Â  Adams was then placed
  under arrest.Â  A subsequent search incident to the arrest revealed an
  additional 11.75 grams of powder that field-testing indicated was cocaine, as
  well as a set of digital scales.Â  Â Â 
A grand jury indicted Adams for trafficking in cocaine.Â  During
  the ensuing bench trial, Adams made a motion to suppress the evidence found in Adamsâ€™ vehicle as a product of an illegal search, which was denied.Â  Subsequently, a bench
  trial was held, and the circuit court found Adams guilty of trafficking cocaine,
  and sentenced him to twenty-five years imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed. Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The admission of
  evidence is within the discretion of the circuit court and will not be reversed
  absent an abuse of discretion. Â State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564
  S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002). Â An abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of
  the circuit court either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error
  of law. Â State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 325, 540 S.E.2d 464, 467
  (2000).
In criminal cases, an appellate court only reviews
  errors of law.Â  State v. Butler, 353 S.C. 383, 388, 577 S.E.2d 498,
  500 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545
  S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001)).Â  We are bound by the circuit courtâ€™s factual findings
  unless we find that they are clearly erroneous.Â  This standard of review also applies
  to preliminary factual findings in determining the admissibility of certain
  evidence in criminal cases.Â  Id.Â  We are limited in our review of Fourth
  Amendment search and seizure cases to determining whether there is any evidence
  to support the circuit courtâ€™s finding.Â  State v. Bowman, 366 S.C. 485,
  501, 623 S.E.2d 378, 386 (2005).Â  An appellate court will reverse only when
  clear error exists.Â  Id.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Adams maintains the purpose of the initial
  traffic stop had been fulfilled, and police had no reasonable suspicion,
  probable cause, or Adamsâ€™ consent to continue the stop.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note
  Adams does not appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order finding James had probable
  cause to initiate a traffic stop based on his observation of Adams making a
  turn without an appropriate turn signal.Â  Where probable cause exists to
  believe that a traffic violation has occurred, the decision to stop the
  automobile is reasonable per se. Â Whren v. United States, 517 U.S. 806, 810 (1996).Â  When a vehicle has been lawfully detained for a traffic violation, a
  police officer may order the driver to get out of the vehicle without violating
  the Fourth Amendmentâ€™s proscription of unreasonable searches and seizures.Â  Pennsylvania v. Mimms, 434 U.S. 106, 111 (1977).Â  In carrying out the stop,
  an officer â€œ â€˜may request a driverâ€™s license and vehicle registration, run a
  computer check, and issue a citation.â€™ â€ United States v. Sullivan,
  138 F.3d 126, 131 (4th Cir. 1998) (citation omitted). Â However, â€œ[a]ny further detention
  for questioning is beyond the scope of the [] stop and therefore illegal unless
  the officer has a reasonable suspicion of a serious crime.â€ Â Id.Â  
 
Our inquiry then
  requires an analysis of whether James detained or seized Adams anew, thereby
  triggering the Fourth Amendment and potentially rendering any subsequent
  consent to a search of his vehicle invalid, or if the encounter turned into a
  consensual one invoking no constitutional scrutiny.Â  See State v. Williams, 351 S.C. 591, 599, 571 S.E.2d 703, 707-08 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  James
  testified the entire encounter from the initial detention to the arrest of Adams took no longer than ten minutes.Â  Additionally, James testified he requested Adamsâ€™ consent to search his vehicle within thirty seconds of receiving the return call on
  the vehicle registration check.Â  This request was made before James had
  returned to his cruiser to fill out the necessary paperwork to issue Adams a citation.Â  As stated above, Reese arrived on the scene at approximately the same
  time, and both officers testified Adamsâ€™ consent to search the vehicle was
  given a short time later.Â  Therefore, we find Adamsâ€™ disputed consent was given
  within the initial parameters of the lawful detention.
â€œWarrantless
  searches and seizures are reasonable within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment
  when conducted under the authority of voluntary consent.â€ Â Palacio
    v. State, 333 S.C. 506, 514, 511 S.E.2d 62, 66 (1999). â€œUndoubtedly, a law
  enforcement officer may request permission to search at any time. However, when
  an officer asks for consent to search after an unconstitutional detention, the consent
  procured is per se invalid unless it is both voluntary and not an exploitation
  of the unlawful detention.â€ State v. Pichardo, 367 S.C. 84, 105, 623
  S.E.2d 840, 851 (Ct. App. 2005). Â Whether consent to a search is voluntary is a
  question of fact to be determined from the totality of the circumstances. Â State
    v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 656, 576 S.E.2d 168, 179 (2003).Â  See also State v. Brockman, 339 S.C. 57, 66, 528 S.E.2d 661, 665-66 (2000)
  (applying a â€œclearly erroneousâ€ standard of review in determining whether trial
  judge properly held defendant consented to search).Â   
In the case before
  us, both James and Reese testified that permission to search the vehicle was
  sought within five minutes of the initial detention.Â  Furthermore, Reese
  testified that when Adams inquired as to whether he could refuse the search
  request, Reese advised him he did not have to consent.Â  According to the
  testimony, Adams consented to the search immediately thereafter.Â  Based on the
  totality of the circumstances, the circuit court did not abuse its discretion
  in finding Adams gave his consent to search his vehicle, and that the consent was
  voluntary in nature.
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
PIEPER, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] Testimony from a second police officer to arrive on
  the scene, William Reese, explained that multiple air fresheners in one vehicle
  is â€œa very good indicatorâ€ of the presence of narcotics because of the
  freshenersâ€™ ability to mask the odor of drugs.Â
