THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ex Parte: 
				Brandon Smith,
          as Personal Representative of the Estate of Tracy Smith, Deceased, Appellant,
				v.
				Auto-Owners
      Insurance Company, Respondent,
				___________________
				In Re: 
				Lewis Lesesne
          Scott, Plaintiff,
				v.
				Wayne K.
      McGraw, Jr., Defendant.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 4363
SubmittedÂ  December 1, 2007 - Filed March
  31, 2008 
Formerly Unpublished Opinion No.
  2008-UP-004
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January
  2, 2008
Withdrawn, Subsituted and Refiled March
  31, 2008
Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Daniel Lawrence Prenner, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Robert Eric Davis, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

CURETON, A.J.:Â  In this
  action to recover under a policy of underinsured motorist coverage, the Estate
  of Tracy Smith (the Estate) argues the statutory definition of â€œinsuredâ€ does
  not restrict an insured from having more than one household for purposes of
  insurance coverage.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
 
FACTS
Ernest
  and Brenda Smith (collectively the Smiths) purchased land in Spartanburg County and established a residence there (the Spartanburg County home) in the
  1970s.Â  Later, the Smiths subdivided some of the acreage and deeded ownership
  of ten acres to each of their four sons.Â  Ernest retained, in his name alone,
  ownership of this home and the land immediately surrounding it.Â  In 1989, while
  still living at the Spartanburg County home, the Smiths purchased a second home
  in Laurens County (the Laurens County home).Â   
The
  Smiths lived at the Spartanburg County home, periodically visiting the Laurens County home as their â€œsummer home.â€Â  When Brenda retired in November of 1999, she
  moved to the Laurens County home.Â  While he visited his wife in Laurens County on occasion, Ernest continued to work full-time and lived at the Spartanburg   County home.Â  Ernest retired in March of 2003 and moved to the Laurens County home with Brenda.Â  However, Ernest continued to work part-time in Spartanburg   County after his retirement.Â  Ernest occasionally stayed in the Spartanburg   County home when working and kept some personal items and clothing there.Â  Ernest
  did not have his driverâ€™s license updated to reflect his Laurens County address.Â  However, Ernest stated he â€œconsidered [his] household after March 2003 to be
  with [his] wifeâ€ at the Laurens County home.Â   
Tracy
  Smith was the Smithsâ€™ 42-year-old son.Â  In May of 2004, Tracy was living in the
  Spartanburg County home.Â  He would occasionally visit his parents at the Laurens County home, but he did not live there.Â  On May 24, 2004, Tracy was a passenger in
  an automobile owned and driven by Wayne K. McGraw, Jr.Â  McGrawâ€™s vehicle
  collided with Lewis Lesesne Scottâ€™s vehicle, and Tracy was killed in the
  accident.Â  Tracy had no automobile insurance at the time of his death.Â   
At
  the time of Tracyâ€™s death, Ernest owned and paid taxes on the Spartanburg County home.Â  He did not maintain insurance on that home.Â  The Smiths insured their
  automobiles through Auto-Owners Insurance Company (Auto-Owners).Â  The
  automobile insurance policy listed the Laurens County home as the Smithsâ€™
  residence.Â   
After
  the accident, Scott sued McGraw.Â  Tracyâ€™s son, Brandon Smith, intervened on
  behalf of the Estate and subsequently joined Auto-Owners as a defendant.Â  Scott
  and McGraw settled with each other and with the Estate and are not parties to
  this appeal.Â  The Estate and Auto-Owners submitted the issue of â€œwhether Tracy
  Smith qualifies as an insured under Ernest and Brenda Smithâ€™s underinsured
  motorist coverageâ€ to the trial court for determination.Â  In an order dated
  September 28, 2006, the circuit court ruled Tracy Smith was not an insured
  party under his parentsâ€™ policy.Â  This appeal followed.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  determination of coverage under an insurance policy is an action at law.Â  Nationwide
    Mut. Ins.Co. v. Prioleau, 359 S.C. 238, 241, 597 S.E.2d 165, 167 (Ct. App.
  2004); see also Kizer v. Kinard, 361 S.C. 68, 71, 602 S.E.2d 783,
  785 (Ct. App. 2004) (determination of whether underinsured motorist coverage
  applies is an action at law).Â  In an action at law, tried without a jury, the
  appellate courtâ€™s standard of review extends only to the correction of errors
  of law.  Pope v. Gordon, 369 S.C. 469, 474, 633 S.E.2d 148, 151 (2006).  We
  will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact unless those findings are
  â€œwholly unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an erroneous conception or
  application of the law.â€  Gordon v. Colonial Ins.
    Co. of Cal., 342 S.C. 152, 155, 536 S.E.2d 376, 378 (Ct. App. 2000).
The
  determination of resident relative status is a question of fact, and thus, we
  will not disturb the circuit courtâ€™s ruling if the record contains any evidence
  supporting it. Â Id. at 155, 536 S.E.2d at 378.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Estate
  argues the circuit court erred in ruling that Tracy Smith was not an insured
  resident of his parentsâ€™ household.Â  We disagree.Â   
In
  South Carolina, the definition of â€œinsuredâ€ includes â€œrelativesâ€ of the named
  insured and his or her spouse, as long as those relatives are â€œresident[s] of
  the same household.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-30(7) (2002).Â  In this case, no party
  disputes that Tracy was a relative of the Smiths.Â  A determination of whether Tracy qualified as an insured under his parentsâ€™ policy necessarily requires an examination
  and a comparison of where Tracy and each of the named insureds resided.Â  The
  circuit court engaged in factfinding concerning Ernest and Tracyâ€™s presence at both
  the Spartanburg County and Laurens County homes and ruled Tracy did not reside
  in the same household as the Smiths.Â  Therefore, because neither party disputed
  Tracy lived at the Spartanburg County home, the circuit courtâ€™s order implicitly
  ruled that Ernest resided in the Laurens County household.Â   
Section
  38-77-30(7) of the South Carolina Code defines â€œinsuredâ€ to include both the
  insured person or persons named in a policy and â€œwhile
  resident of the same household, the spouse of any named insured and relatives
  of either.â€Â  No statute provides guidance concerning whether an insured may
  maintain more than one household simultaneously.Â  Although the courts have
  contemplated the meaning of â€œresident relativeâ€ on numerous occasions,[2] the issue of whether an insured may
  reside in multiple households simultaneously is one of first impression.Â  Our
  task here is limited to determining whether facts in the record supported the
  circuit courtâ€™s finding the Smiths and Tracy did not reside in the same
  household.Â  Consequently, we do not reach the issue of whether an insured may
  reside in multiple households.
The circuit court found the evidence conclusively established Tracy
  and his parents resided in two separate households in May 2004.Â  To reach this
  conclusion, the circuit court necessarily undertook a two-prong analysis.Â 
  First, the circuit court determined where each of the Smiths resided.Â  The
  record reflects that in May 2004, Tracyâ€™s only residence was the Spartanburg   County home.Â  Tracy occasionally visited his parents at the Laurens County home but did not live there.Â  In May 2004, Brendaâ€™s only residence was the Laurens County home.Â  In May 2004, Ernest lived at the Laurens County home with Brenda,
  having moved there from the Spartanburg County home when he retired in March of
  2003.Â  However, Brenda testified that Ernest kept clothes, toiletries, and
  other items at the Spartanburg County home for his personal use when he stayed
  there following his retirement.Â  Ernest maintained duplicate items at the Laurens County home.Â  
 
The conflict in this matter revolves around the time Ernest spent
  at the Spartanburg County home, the time Ernest resided in the Laurens County home, and his intention with respect to these homes and his son.Â  Because
  the record supports the assertions that Ernest resided in both homes, the
  circuit court was required to proceed to the second prong of its analysis.Â  
 
In the second prong of the analysis, the circuit court applied the Buddin standard of â€œone, other than a temporary or transient visitor,
  who lives together with others in the same house for a period of some duration,
  although he may not intend to remain there permanently.â€Â  250 S.C. at 339, 157
  S.E.2d at 636.Â  We note that in 1996, our supreme court adopted a similar but
  somewhat more stringent approach to determining residency.Â  State Farm Fire & Casualty Co. v. Breazell, 324 S.C. 228, 478 S.E.2d 831 (1996).Â  Under the Waite test enunciated in Breazell,
  a person resides in a household with another if he or she:

	1) liv[es] under the same roof; 2) in a close, intimate, and
  informal relationship, and 3) where the intended duration of the relationship
  is likely to be substantial, where it is consistent with the informality of the
  relationship and from which it is reasonable to conclude that the parties would
  consider the relationship in contracting about such matters as insurance or in
  their conduct in reliance thereon.

Breazell, 324 S.C. at 231, 478 S.E.2d at 832 (citing A.G. by Waite v. Travelers Ins. Co., 331 N.W.2d 643 (Wis. Ct. App.
  1983)).Â   
In applying the Waite test to Ernestâ€™s two possible
  households, we agree with the circuit court that Ernest was a resident of the Laurens County home and was a temporary, transient visitor to the Spartanburg County home.Â  Waite requires residents to â€œliv[e] under the same roof . . . in a close,
  intimate, and informal relationshipâ€ that anticipates both a substantial length
  and some durability.Â  Id.Â  Brenda and Ernest lived in the Laurens County home together as husband and wife, thus satisfying the first two factors.Â 
  Ernest considered his home to be with Brenda at the Laurens County home.Â  His purpose in leaving that home was to work, and he returned there when not
  working.Â  Ernest and Brendaâ€™s living arrangements in the Laurens County home also satisfied the third factor, that the relationship be lengthy and durable.Â 
  Using the Laurens County address, Ernest and Brenda purchased homeowners and
  automobile insurance, filed joint tax returns, received mail, and paid bills.Â 
  These acts clearly satisfy the final factor, confirming Ernestâ€™s residency at
  the Laurens County home under Waite.Â   
By contrast, Ernestâ€™s presence at the Spartanburg County home does not appear to satisfy all of the Waite factors for residency.Â  Ernest
  and Tracy did indeed live together, at least for part of each week.Â  Ernestâ€™s
  work schedule necessitated his visits to Spartanburg County.Â  Depending upon
  his employerâ€™s needs, he would be in Spartanburg between two and four days per
  week.Â  With regard to the second Waite factor, Ernest and Tracy appear
  to have enjoyed a â€œclose, intimate, and informal relationship,â€ given that they
  were father and son and the record does not indicate that their living
  arrangement included any restrictions or formal division of household
  responsibilities.Â  However, this relationship fails to satisfy the third
  factor.Â  No evidence in the record indicates Ernest and Tracy intended their
  living arrangement to be substantially long or durable or that they treated
  their living arrangement as anything but a matter of temporary convenience.Â 
  Ernest and Tracy did not insure their automobiles together or share the
  responsibilities of taxes or household bills.Â  Ernest did not insure the Spartanburg   County home at all.Â  Although Ernest may have spent up to four nights per
  week in the Spartanburg County home, it appears he stayed there merely as a matter
  of convenience and in lieu of renting a hotel room.Â   
Therefore, the circuit court did not err in finding Ernest had
  only one household in Laurens County that he shared with his wife.Â  His use of
  the Spartanburg County home did not constitute maintenance of a second
  household, and Tracy did not qualify as an insured under his parentsâ€™
  automobile insurance coverage.
CONCLUSION
The
  circuit court did not err in finding Tracy did not qualify as an insured under
  his parentsâ€™ automobile insurance coverage.Â  The record indicates Tracy lived in Spartanburg County and his parents lived in Laurens County.Â  Further, Ernestâ€™s
  occasional visits to the Spartanburg County home did not constitute
  establishment of a household with Tracy.Â  Therefore, Tracy was not an insured
  under his parentsâ€™ policy.Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is 
 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and PIEPER, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.Â   
[2] See, e.g., Buddin v. Nationwide Mut. Ins.
  Co., 250 S.C. 332, 340, 157 S.E.2d 633, 637 (1967) (asserting nephew who
  actively participated in uncleâ€™s household activities and who did not intend to
  live elsewhere was a resident relative of uncle); Auto Owners Ins. Co. v. Horne, 356 S.C. 52, 68, 586 S.E.2d 865, 874 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. denied August 4, 2004 (finding child of divorced parents was not a resident relative
  of her non-custodial parentâ€™s household); Auto Owners Ins. Co. v. Langford,
  330 S.C. 578, 584, 500 S.E.2d 496, 499 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding grandchild and
  great-grandchild who occasionally visited named insured were not â€œinsuredsâ€).
